webTitle: Flower power clears path to summit for Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Flower power clears path to summit for Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst:
South Africa 222-7
Zimbabwe 223-8
Zimbabwe won by two wickets
fields.trailText: While England's cricketers went deep-sea fishing off East London yesterday, South Africa found themselves in hot water here.
fields.body:
While England's cricketers went deep-sea fishing off East London yesterday, South Africa found themselves in hot water here.

Zimbabwe's thrilling two-wicket win, off the last ball of the innings, leaves the host nation under pressure to beat England under lights tomorrow back in East London. All three teams, with two games to play apiece, stand level with two victories from four matches.

But on net run rate, which could yet decide who makes the final in Johannesburg on Saturday week, Zimbabwe head the table with England second and South Africa bottom. If this was football it might be described as the group of death.

A seventh-wicket partnership of 91 between the captain Andy Flower (59) and Guy Whittall (39) saw Zimbabwe to the brink of victory. But then both men fell in quick succession leaving the tailenders Heath Streak and Gary Brent needing four off the last over.

With one run needed from three deliveries Zimbabwe were clear favourites. But after two dot balls it needed a scrambled bye off the last delivery to see them home.

Zimbabwe, chasing 223 for victory, might have hoped for an easier target after having South Africa 112-6. Once again the home side had cause to be grateful to a depth charge from the local hero Lance Klusener for reaching their eventual total of 222-7.

His unbeaten 65 from 84 deliveries displayed a measure of self-restraint by his own pugilistic standards. But after the fall of wickets at regular intervals his seventh-wicket stand of 82 with Jacques Kallis was pivotal, and he made a good Zimbabwe fielding side pay heavily for dropping him before he had scored, behind the wicket, and again at 17.

Kallis, who scored a solid 52 from 96 balls, was seventh out at 194 and after that the man called Zulu added a rapid 28 with Shaun Pollock (14). Towards the end of his innings Klusener struck Grant Flower for successive sixes over midwicket but his straight man, Pollock, later turned out to be the villain of the piece by sending down his 10 overs at a cost of 55 runs.

An agitated-looking Cronje said afterwards: "This makes everything very tight. To be sure of getting to the final we now have to win both our finnal two matches. We simply didn't get enough runs today."

 Glenn McGrath, named Australian cricketer of the year this week, ripped through the Pakistan top order at the Melbourne Cricket Ground to set up an easy six-wicket victory for the hosts in the opening game of the three-match final series to the tri-nations one-day tournament.

McGrath reduced Pakistan to four for three in a devastating two-over burst and Australia cruised to the target of 154 with half-centuries by Michael Bevan and Ricky Ponting.

webTitle: Stricken Swindon send out financial SOS

fields.headline: Stricken Swindon send out financial SOS
fields.standfirst: First Division club calls in administrators to stem £25,000 weekly losses
fields.trailText: Financially stricken Swindon Town placed themselves in emergency care yesterday when they called in the administrators to rescue them.
fields.body:
Financially stricken Swindon Town placed themselves in emergency care yesterday when they called in the administrators to rescue them.

Swindon, who have been losing £25,000 a week, have been stringently cost-cutting this season, dismissing 15 backroom staff only last month, but the rapid escalation of their problems appeared to catch the English game by surprise, with even the Football League initially unaware that the club had hastily arranged a press conference yesterday at the London headquarters of the accountants Kroll Buchler Phillips, who have extensive experience of football crises.

The club are between £2m and £3m in debt, are projected to make a £1.5m trading loss this season, and needed to repay between £250,000 and £500,000 immediately.

Disturbingly, the distress signal was launched when they could not repay the most pressing debt, £214,000 to the Inland Revenue - a sum which would appear manageable for a Nationwide First Division club, albeit one rooted to the bottom.

Although David Buchler is adamant Swindon "will be saved" and that the reprieve offered by the three-month administration period will enable the club to fulfil their fixtures this season, he is not confident others will survive in future. "You could have casualties in the next two to three years."

Swindon's chairman Cliff Puffett, who took charge four months ago, readily agrees. "I seriously believe we're the first of many. You'll see others in trouble in a matter of months."

He can see no solution "unless you do something about the wage situation". He suggested a lower basic wage for players, topped up by performance-related pay.

In Swindon's case, Puffett admitted, a dream conceived two years ago had turned into a financial nightmare. "We tried to chase the dream of returning to the Premier League. That needs quite a financial commitment to players' wages. It also depends on 12,000-13,000 coming through the gate. But we're down to 5,500 fans, a 40% drop over the last decade."

He conceded that further players would have to be sold and admitted that Swindon, who have enjoyed only one season in the top flight (1993-94), have now even considered part-time football: "You have to live within your means." The administrators, however, are not keen to pursue that path and are confident Swindon will remain a fully professional club.

Buchler, whose team have helped out Oxford, Luton, Millwall and Barnet, said that administration was the only option in the face of a winding-up order. Swindon's plight "is a common problem," he said. "Too many football clubs are not run as a business, and out of the 92 professional teams in this country only about 10 are making money."

He believes players' contracts will have to be changed to take account of relegation, because the upward wage spiral is unalterable. "Market forces are unfortunately driving the problem. And market forces will prevail."

webTitle: Hot stuff from the ice fields

fields.headline: Hot stuff from the ice fields
fields.standfirst: Iceland's success at raising its game has made it a rich and popular source of inexpensive talent
fields.trailText: As Vivek Chaudhary reports, Iceland's success at raising its game has made it a rich and popular source of inexpensive talent.
fields.body:
A country that counts volcanoes, geysers and hot springs among its tourist attractions is accustomed to explosions.

A country whose national team have never qualified for the finals of a major championship, where average league attendances are 900 and where there are no full-time professional footballers is unaccustomed to success at the beautiful game.

Fortunately for many Icelanders, their most recent explosion has not come within the terra inferna of the snow-capped isle but from the country's spartan dressing rooms and shabby pitches. It is an astonishing success story which has led to one of Europe's smallest and most isolated communities making its footballing mark across the continent.

There are about 70 Icelandic footballers plying their trade at clubs around Europe, from the Premiership and Bundesliga to second division Greek and Italian football. In Britain alone there are 22 Icelandic professionals, and more are on the way.

Even if the majority are playing at unglamorous, cash-strapped clubs on the lookout for a bargain, the emergence of Icelandic players on the European scene is phenomenal given limited facilities, a population of only 277,000 and the fact that the nation's footballers play on grass for only five months of the year, May to September.

Watford recently signed the Icelandic striker Heidar Helguson; he scored on his debut against Liverpool, and Watford's manager Graham Taylor declared that an explosion of Icelandic players was about to take place.

Eyolfur Sverrisson has been a pillar of the Hertha Berlin defence, Rikhardur Dadason and Thordur Gudjonsson have made a huge impact in Norway and Belgium, and Tottenham are said to be signing a 16-year-old midfielder who may be the best of the lot.

For European scouts and agents there are rich pickings to be had in Iceland, whose players were barely known outside their home towns let alone their shores as little as two years ago.

For the players rolling off the production line, the toughest opponents are often poor training facilities, meagre win bonuses and arduous weather.

Just consider this: at an indoor equestrian centre just outside Reykjavik last week, where the soft earth is more accustomed to hooves than studs and the stench of horse dung filled the air, the players of IBV, one of Iceland's leading clubs, were undergoing their daily training session after returning from work. A couple of the players may earn win bonuses of up to £200 a game but the majority of the team are willing to play for a minimal fee, and these are among the elite of domestic footballers.

IBV are based in Heimaey, capital of the Vestmann Islands, population 5,000, which lie just off the coast of Iceland. Half the team are in Reykjavik for the close season because of winter weather that makes training impossible and because there is more chance of finding work.

"Our matches often get cancelled at the last minute because of the wind," said the coach Kristinn Jonsson. "Sometimes we can't get to away matches because we can't leave the island. Visiting teams and their fans sometimes can't get home. These are the conditions that our players have to put up with but that makes them more dedicated. They are willing to work harder than most other players in Europe."

Five of last season's team, which finished second in the league, are now playing at clubs across Europe, including Ivar Ingimarsson, who recently signed for Brentford and scored in their 1-0 win at Blackpool last Saturday.

Ingimarsson and his colleagues can date the beginnings of their success to 10 years ago, when Iceland's football association (IFA), sick of having nothing to cheer about, implemented a strategy to raise the nation's game.

There was never any doubt within Icelandic football circles that the country possessed footballers with the right physical and mental attributes to succeed. The problem, the administrators felt, lay with the coaches.

"We felt that we really needed to work on the coaches because they are the ones who pass knowledge on to the players," said Asgeir Sigurvinsson, the association's technical director and one of the first Icelandic footballers to play outside his country.

"Our coaching methods have improved over the past few years and we made a real effort to focus on this. Our players have always had the appetite for football and the ability to do well but the coaches weren't always able to bring out the best in them."

Former players such as Gundi Kjartansson, who is currently the Iceland Under-18s coach, were sent on Fifa-approved courses across Europe in an attempt to improve their knowledge of the game and study tactics.

"Our boys have always had a very good fighting spirit," said Kjartansson. "They are very hungry, they are big and strong and they will never let a team down. But we could not always harness this tactically and that is something we learnt to do by attending these courses.

"It really helped our understanding of the game. Players can only improve if the coach knows more about the game than they do."

The appointment of Gudjon Thordarson as national team coach in 1995 gave further impetus to the game's development. His reign also put Icelandic footballers in the international shop window.

Thordarson is now manager of Stoke City and part of an Icelandic consortium, along with Sigurvinsson, that took over the club last year. Under his guidance Iceland moved from 63rd to 43rd in the Fifa world rankings. They held the world champions France to a 1-1 draw in Reykjavik in the Euro 2000 qualifiers and narrowly lost 3-2 in Paris last year.

"We cannot overestimate what Thordarson did for the national team," said the IFA press officer Omar Smarason. "It really improved confidence and the rest of Europe sat up and took notice."

Though Iceland languishes in mid-table in the world football league, it is rooted to the foot of the world crime league. This has proved to be a blessing in disguise for Olafur Gardarsson, one of the country's few criminal lawyers and Iceland's first Fifa-approved agent.

"As a lawyer in Iceland you have to spread yourself a bit thin: there's not much crime," he concedes. "In the last two years my work in football has really taken off and there is enormous interest from other European clubs in Icelandic players."

Gardarsson, who works closely with several Premiership clubs, represents 40 players, 20 of whom are playing abroad and the remainder lining up moves to European clubs. A 16-year-old he represents was recently wanted by Liverpool, Leeds and Watford but opted to join a first division Dutch club instead.

Gardarsson claims that the first clubs to take Icelanders seriously were in Norway and Denmark. Watford paid £1.5m for Helguson from the Norwegian club Lillestrom, but Gardarsson feels that English clubs have missed out on some bargain buys by ignoring Iceland until now.

"There has been a knock-on effect," he said. "Many of our players were in Scandinavia and that's where English clubs noticed their ability. It's only recently that English clubs have started coming to Iceland directly but they are still slow in acting. Watford could have signed Helguson for £300,000 three years ago if they'd moved quicker."

The cost-effectiveness of Icelandic players in an increasingly inflated European transfer market also makes them attractive to clubs continually looking to save money and unearth a cost-price gem.

Icelandic clubs, suffering from poor gates and low turnover, have been quick to seize on the demand for their players knowing that their style, strength and pace suit the English game in particular. Iceland is rapidly emerging as a sellers' market with clubs openly proclaiming their intention to produce as many players as possible with the aim of selling them abroad.

The Icelandic champions KR Reykjavik, the biggest club in the country, recently floated on the stock market stating their intention to sell or loan out as many of their players as possible. Last season an average of four to five scouts from around Europe attended their home games.

With an annual turnover of £650,000 and an average home gate of 2,500, the highest in Iceland, KR nevertheless generate almost 50% of their revenue from the sale or loan of players.

Of last season's championship-winning team, one player has been sold to Preston North End, two loaned to Stoke City, one sold to a Norwegian club, one loaned to a Belgian club, two are on loan at a Greek club with a view to a permanent move and three recently returned from a loan spell at a German second division club.

"Clubs know they can get a good honest player for a good price," said their chief executive Magnus Orri Schram. "Technically our players are very good and they are willing to work hard. They are a manager's dream."

Iceland's football explosion looks set to continue and, for the man responsible for touting his country's young talent to clubs across Europe, the reasons may be a lot simpler than originally thought.

Not only are they big, strong and exhibit Viking characteristics but, joked Gardarsson: "Our boys do not complain about the food, they do not complain about the weather, they are used to hard work and they all talk English."

fields.headline: Euro-fringe threat to English players
fields.trailText: Football authorities yesterday called for a limit on the number of foreign players requiring work permits admitted to England.
fields.body:
Football authorities yesterday called for a limit on the number of foreign players requiring work permits admitted to England, even though they conceded that substantial changes would have to be made to European law if the future of home-produced players in the game were to be safeguarded.

Representatives of the Premier and Football Leagues and the Football Association, addressing a panel of MPs investigating work permits for foreign footballers, urged changes to the system, claiming that transfer fees and wages were spiralling and young home-produced players were being denied the opportunity of first-team football.

Officals conceded, however, that part of the problem lay with the number of players from the European Economic Area (EEA), a separate association of countries with economic ties, embracing Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. EEA players, like those from the European Union, do not require work permits.

The 1995 Bosman ruling, which removed restrictions on footballers from EU countries, also covers players from the EEA. Prior to Bosman, only three foreign players from anywhere outside Great Britain and Ireland were permitted per team.

Football officals conceded to MPs that the number of non-European footballers actually requiring work permits was quite small compared with players from the EEA. There are currently 25 players requiring work permits in all three divisions of the Football League, only 1% of the total number in that league, and 30 in the Premiership.

Responding to MPs' ques tions whether EEA players needed to be limited and whether work-permit players posed much threat, Graham Noakes of the FA replied: "If there were changes to the European law then we would be able to make more changes. We have to operate within EU law and cannot limit the number of EEA players coming into this country."

EEA players have become particularly popular over the past two seasons mainly because of their price and their ability to adapt to the game here.

The Premier League wants to introduce a quota system of two work-permit players per club plus one under-18 player.

Football authorities want the department for employment to tighten up its work-permit system to ensure only top-class footballers are allowed to join English clubs.

Authorities fear that the development of young players is being hampered and that second-rate foreign players are being given easy access to the English game.

Mike Foster, the Premier League secretary, said: "We have a responsibility to the English game and the development of English players." But he added: "We have to strike the right balance so that our coaches can still have access to all the best players from outside our boundaries."

The MPs also heard that clubs in the lower leagues had been particularly affected by the arrival of foreign players.

Andy Williamson of the Football League said that over the past four years the level of transfers between his league and Premiership clubs had fallen by 42%. "Historically, lower-league clubs have survived on the sale of players to higher-division clubs."

fields.headline: Chairman's wife arrested
fields.trailText: The wife of the Gillingham chairman Paul Scally was arrested on suspicion of possessing a class A drug, hours after the giantkilling victory over Sheffield Wednesday.
fields.body:
The wife of the Gillingham chairman Paul Scally was arrested on suspicion of possessing a class A drug, hours after the giantkilling victory over Sheffield Wednesday.

Lisa Marie Scally, a cabaret singer, was arrested in a Maidstone nightclub in the early hours of Sunday morning.

It is believed she had been celebrating with her husband and the club's players after the Gills reached the quarter-finals of the FA Cup for the first time in their history.

Kent Police said yesterday: "A 25-year-old woman was arrested at 3am on Sunday at Ikon in connection with possession of class A drugs.

"The woman was released on police bail until February 11 while further inquiries take place." A police source later confirmed that Mrs Scally was the woman involved.

Neither Mrs Scally, who goes by the stage name Lisa Marie Valente, nor a spokesman for Gillingham was available for comment yesterday.

Manchester United are confident that their pitch will be fit to host England's World Cup qualifier against Germany, should the Football Association choose it for the game on October 7.

Old Trafford, with a capacity nearing 67,000 next season, is the favoured venue while Wembley is being rebuilt, despite the playing surface having to be relaid five times in the past 18 months. But the club reckon the latest pitch will prove successful.

"The ground staff have been working extremely hard and the pitch is definitely a lot better," said Sir Alex Ferguson.

Ivory Coast's players have been detained in a military camp for what the government describes as their own safety since their return home from the African Nations Cup. The Elephants were eliminated in the first round.

Tottenham have released the Italian full-back Paolo Tramezzani, who was signed for £1.6m from Piacenza in June 1998. Fulham hope to sign Everton's Republic of Ireland left-back Terry Phelan, 32, on a free transfer today.

webTitle: Vidmar sets Rangers on a romp

fields.headline: Vidmar sets Rangers on a romp
fields.trailText: With a minimum of fuss, Rangers collected another win last night. Billy Dodds may not have scored the goal he wanted against his former team-mates at Dundee United but it hardly mattered in a one-sided contest.
fields.body:
With a minimum of fuss, Rangers collected another win last night. Billy Dodds may not have scored the goal he wanted against his former team-mates at Dundee United but it hardly mattered in a one-sided contest.

Worryingly, for a match that is normally highly competitive, Tannadice was not even full. Many fans have no stomach to watch what has become little more than the ritual slaughter of the innocents.

It may have been the thought that a victory over United would carry them nine points clear of Celtic that inspired the leaders to come out of the traps so quickly. It would be wrong to say that they were contemptuous but by establishing a two-goal cushion after only 23 minutes they had made a huge mark on the game.

Both goals came from an unexpected source, the Australian full-back Tony Vidmar. But even he would have to admit that he received help in huge measure from the United goalkeeper Alan Combe.

Giovanni van Bronckhorst was the creator of both goals, striking left-footed inswinging corners. In the ninth minute, Combe was able to place a hand on the ball but it slipped away from him and Vidmar pushed it over the line. In the 23rd minute, he did not get that close.

Lorenzo Amoruso took enough of the United defence with him, including Combe, and the ball rather struck Vidmar on the shin before rico cheting off the United defender David Partridge over the line.

United had a single chance. Just after half-time, David Hannah's cross was headed strongly by Jim Hamilton, but Stefan Klos saved.

Although Rangers took their foot off the accelerator for a period, they demonstrated their class in the 67th minute when virtually every player touched the ball in a move that embraced over 20 passes before Rod Wallace's header at the far post established a three-goal lead.

Even then, Rangers were not finished, Tugay Kerimoglu supplied the ball for Neil McCann for the fourth goal.

webTitle: Electric Elliott puts Leicester into final

fields.headline: Electric Elliott puts Leicester into final
fields.standfirst: Leicester win 1-0 on aggregate
fields.trailText: With a delicious sense of timing, Leicester City delivered the perfect riposte to their detractors and dispelled a few myths along the way. A towering header from the stand-in striker Matt Elliott in first-half stoppage time steered Leicester to a Wembley date with Tranmere Rovers and the prospect of a seventh appearance beneath the twin towers in eight years.
fields.body:
With a delicious sense of timing, Leicester City delivered the perfect riposte to their detractors and dispelled a few myths along the way. A towering header from the stand-in striker Matt Elliott in first-half stoppage time steered Leicester to a Wembley date with Tranmere Rovers and the prospect of a seventh appearance beneath the twin towers in eight years.

They may have been written off in some quarters, but Martin O'Neill's gallant side just love upsetting their illustrious counterparts. Last night they produced a performance of industry, endeavour and, yes, no shortage of skill.

Villa arrived with something of an inferiority complex, having failed to beat their Midlands neighbours in 12 years. They also faced the added challenge posed by a Leicester side bristling with fierce indignation, following an acrimonious bout of mud slinging between O'Neill and an anti-Leicester faction boasting Ken Bates and Arséne Wenger among its honorary members.

John Gregory is surely up for election himself after some of his barbed remarks about Leicester's much-criticised defensive methods during the scoreless first leg at Villa Park a week earlier. However, those acquainted with Leicester know only too well that they are never better than at times of adversity.

As is his wont, O'Neill could not resist taking a few more pot shots at his detractors in his programme notes, and his players exuded a stubborn air of defiance in obliging Gregory's wish that "they would actually cross the halfway line".

Leicester's critics were almost made to eat their words early in a one-sided opening half, only for Emile Heskey to shoot straight at David James after being given a clear sight of goal thanks to Gareth Barry's mistake.

James then followed up his colleague's faux pas with one of his own that came close to presenting Robbie Savage with an open goal. Villa's jitters were becoming increasingly evident as they struggled to suppress the usual succession of rampaging bursts from a bullish Heskey.

When Stefan Oakes arrowed a venomous left-foot drive that beat James all ends up - only to ricochet back into play off the goalkeeper's right-hand post - Leicester could have been excused for suspecting that fate was against them.

But the home side did not have to wait long. In virtually the last move of the half Savage swung over a right-wing delivery for Elliott to head beyond James, despite the close proximity of Ugo Ehiogu.

Leicester's goalkeeper Tim Flowers, in stark contrast to James, was a virtual spectator apart from sporadic flurries in the second half. The home supporters were determined to milk the moment with chants of "boring, boring Villa", and there was more than a hint of sarcasm when Leicester's half-time summariser and occasional jester Alan Birchenall exclaimed he had been almost "sent to sleep" by the events of the opening period.

But whether the club's bank manager was so chuffed by the side's survival in this competition was another matter. Leicester have reached a provisional agreement with Liverpool to sell Heskey for £7 million at the end of the season, but the Merseyside club have made it clear during fresh negotiations that they are willing to increase the transfer fee to push the deal through early once the player is free of cup involvement.

Thanks to the events of last night, that will not be the case until after February 27 - when Leicester and Tranmere do battle for a slice of Wembley glory.

fields.headline: Sheringham's timely touch
fields.trailText: Manchester United took a long time to disturb a disciplined, tightly organised Sheffield Wednesday defence last night and when they did begin to find their range they were frustrated by a series of saves by Pavel Srnicek.
fields.body:
Manchester United took a long time to disturb a disciplined, tightly organised Sheffield Wednesday defence last night and when they did begin to find their range they were frustrated by a series of saves by Pavel Srnicek.

Wednesday's Czech goalkeeper deflected a header from Teddy Sheringham and a powerful shot from Roy Keane over and then blocked Dwight Yorke's header on the line.

But in the 73rd minute he was beaten when Ryan Giggs sent Teddy Sheringham through and the striker slipped the ball into the net under the goalkeeper's body as Srnicek and Peter Atherton converged.

With 10 points out of the last 15, Wednesday were entitled to approach the game feeling more chipper than just over a month ago. Yet their removal from the FA Cup by Gillingham at the weekend was an indication of just how fragile the new-found confidence of Danny Wilson's team was.

Wednesday knew that merely avoiding defeat would be no small triumph. Sir Alex Ferguson's team were eager to lengthen their stride at the top and this offered a valuable opportunity to increase the pressure on the erstwhile leaders Leeds.

A swift, shrewd through-pass from Niclas Alexandersson, which cut out Roy Keane and Nicky Butt in midfield, might have served Wednesday better had Wim Jonk not been more inclined to shoot instead of setting up Gilles de Bilde for an airy shot over. When Jonk did drive one in from 25 yards Mark Bosnich parried the ball with some difficulty.

There was a nice shape and movement about Wednesday's football, Alexandersson and Phil Scott giving width and balance. In addition the quick passing and interchanging of positions in the approaches to goal had United's defence momentarily confused.

Wednesday, however, tended to shoot from too great a range. They needed to get more men into the area to exploit some early territorial advantage.

Initially, United appeared in no hurry to up the tempo or seek opportunities to catch the opposition on the break. They were content to spar with Wednesday and neither Keane nor David Beckham made more than sporadic contact with Yorke and Sheringham, who was again preferred to Andy Cole up front.

Then towards half-time United began to move the ball about more briskly, with Giggs beginning to turn Wednesday'on the left. This is often the way of things when United are in the road; one moment they are a minimal threat, the next they always seem to have two or three players running into spaces near goal.

They might have gone ahead on the half-hour. A prodigious clearance from Bosnich reached Yorke in the penalty area and the Tobagan held the ball up under pressure before laying it back to Sheringham, who stretched out a foot to waft the chance over the bar.

By half-time it was a case of Wednesday thinking they might have scored while United knew they should have done. United were starting to dominatebut their finishing still had not reflected the pace and imagination of their build-ups.

Nevertheless Beckham was a growing influence, not only through his crosses but also his ability to pick out colleagues with precise long passes to feet. Yorke should have done better with one of these gifts towards the end of the first half and the chance ended with Pavel Srnicek scrambling a narrow-angled shot from Sheringham around a post.

To give his attack an extra option Ferguson replaced Butt with Paul Scholes, who had missed the World Club Championship to have a hernia operation. United needed a bigger element of surprise in to break down the determined defending of Des Walker and Atherton, and Scholes will always provide that.

He it was who prompted a smothering save from Srnicek after Steve Haslam had conceded a panicky corner which marked the first sign of nerves in Wednesday's defence. Then a cushioned pass from Scholes to Giggs had the opposition struggling to clear the danger, and just past the hour Srnicek punched a header from Sheringham over after the striker had met Beckham's corner from the left at the near post.

webTitle: Mandelson takes power to suspend assembly

fields.headline: Mandelson takes power to suspend assembly
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson will pass emergency legislation giving him the power to suspend Ulster's executive and assembly, he said in a statement to the Commons this evening.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson will pass emergency legislation giving him the power to suspend Ulster's executive and assembly, he said in a statement to the Commons this evening.

But Downing street stressed that legislation to allow the suspension of the Stormont assembly was being taken "as a contingency" and no date would be set for suspension once the necessary legislation had been rushed through the Commons in the next few days.

The legislation will buy the government more time in which to continue pursuing a diplomatic solution to the impasse over the IRA's failure to begin decommissioning its weapons.

Mr Mandelson said the government had "to be prepared to suspend the institutions" if there was "a clear loss of confidence in the peace process". By suspending them, "our purpose will be to preserve them from collapse."

He added that the de Chastelain report said there had been no decommissioning of arms by any major paramilitary group: "If this continues it is totally unacceptable."

Tony Blair's official spokesman said there was still a chance that the prime minister and his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern would hold a special summit tonight in Cornwall to assess the situation.

Mr Blair's spokesman said: "We have always known there has to be decommissioning. The report that General de Chastelain produced earlier this week cannot say for certain how we take that process forward and there has to be that clarity.

"For these reasons he [Mr Mandelson] is going to be taking the power as a contingency to do what would be necessary should we make no further progress."

The spokesman stressed the peace process was still "far further forward than we have been in the past and it is important people do not over-exaggerate the extent of what the prime minister has admitted is a crisis."

Tonight's announcement follows a day of feverish activity between London, Dublin and Belfast.

Mr Blair interrupted his tour of Devon to make several phone calls. He spoke twice to Mr Mandelson and had two lengthy conversations with Mr Ahern.

In the Dail, Mr Ahern said that when he met Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams and chief negotiator Martin McGuinness on Wednesday he had made clear the need for "clarity" from republicans on decommissioning.

"If that is not achieved there is no alternatives," he said. "I made it clear yesterday in the straightest and bluntest terms possible, in front of a number of witnesses, that that is what the government desires."

The latest crisis follows General John de Chastelain's report into decommissioning which concluded that there had been no handover of IRA weapons.

The Ulster Unionists have warned that they will destroy the power-sharing administration by walking out if the government does not suspend the devolution in the IRA decommissioning.

With Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble's post-dated letter of resignation to his party's ruling council due to take effect tomorrow, ministers are clearly running out of time.

Mr Adams tonight issued a last ditch appeal to Mr Trimble to meet for talks and repeated his warning that, if the administration was suspended, IRA decommissioning would be more difficult than ever to achieve.

"I believe that the crisis can be resolved if the political will is there. The process does not have to collapse. It can be saved," he said. "There is no reason why the de Chastelain report, essentially a progress report, cannot be taken up positively by the British government and the Ulster Unionist party."

Seamus Mallon, deputy leader of the SDLP and the cabinet's top Catholic minister, said the IRA bore much of the responsibility for the crisis. He noted that the disarmament commission was formed in 1997, and it was reasonable to ask the IRA that if it ever intended to disarm, "why not now?"

"To refuse when everything else of substance within the Good Friday accord has been implemented and put in train fuels the reasonable suspicion ... that the IRA as an organisation is incapable of renouncing violence or the threat of violence for political purposes," Mr Mallon said.

"I made it clear yesterday in the straightest and bluntest terms possible, in front of a number of witnesses, that that is what the government desires." The latest crisis follows General John de Chastelain's report into decommissioning which concluded that there had been no handover of IRA weapons. The Ulster Unionists have warned that they will destroy the power-sharing administration by walking out if the government does not suspend the devolution in the IRA decommissioning. With Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble's post-dated letter of resignation to his party's ruling council due to take effect tomorrow, ministers are clearly running out of time. Mr Adams tonight issued a last ditch appeal to Mr Trimble to meet for talks and repeated his warning that, if the administration was suspended, IRA decommissioning would be more difficult than ever to achieve. "I believe that the crisis can be resolved if the political will is there. The process does not have to collapse. It can be saved," he said. "There is no reason why the de Chastelain report, essentially a progress report, cannot be taken up positively by the British government and the Ulster Unionist party." Seamus Mallon, deputy leader of the SDLP and the cabinet's top Catholic minister, said the IRA bore much of the responsibility for the crisis. He noted that the disarmament commission was formed in 1997, and it was reasonable to ask the IRA that if it ever intended to disarm, "why not now?" "To refuse when everything else of substance within the Good Friday accord has been implemented and put in train fuels the reasonable suspicion ... that the IRA as an organisation is incapable of renouncing violence or the threat of violence for political purposes," Mr Mallon said.

fields.headline: President agrees to far-right coalition
fields.standfirst: 'Nobody has to fear anything in Austria' says Haider as new coalition sign pact and issue declaration
fields.trailText: Austrian president Thomas Klestil agreed to swear in a coalition government including Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party despite an international outcry and threats of political isolation by Austria's European partners.
fields.body:
Austrian president Thomas Klestil agreed to swear in a coalition government including Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party despite an international outcry and threats of political isolation by Austria's European partners.

Klestil's office said the ceremony will take place at noon on Friday.

The head of state was clearly reluctant to sanction the new coaltion. Mr Klestil made his feelings plain yesterday, saying he would approve the coalition only against his better judgment because he feared Austria would suffer internationally.

"If I were to swear in this government, I would not do it out of personal conviction, because I fear that Austria would suffer internationally," Mr Klestil told NEWS magazine. But, he added: "In a democracy, a parliamentary majority has to be respected. Personal preferences do not count."

Mr Haider's Freedom party and Mr Schuessel's People's party hold 104 seats in the 183-seat parliament. Mr Klestil cannot call a new election unless parliament first votes to dissolve itself

The announcement is likely to trigger a series of diplomatic measures against Austria by the rest of the European Union, which warned Vienna that its EU membership could be suspended if the government veers from European standards of democracy and human rights.

Earlier today, Conservative leader Wolfgang Schuessel and Mr Haider formalised a coalition pact today and issued an unprecedented declaration committing the coalition to the basic principles of European democracy.

They also signed a document, "Responsibility for Austria - A future in the heart of Europe", was intended to reassure other nations that a coalition including Mr Haider's party would remain committed to the EU, human rights, and western democratic values. The signing took place in the Hofburg Palace, Vienna, against a backdrop of whistles from protestors outside the palace.

"Nobody has to fear anything in Austria," Mr Haider told a joint news conference with Mr Schuessel. "We will try to convince the international community that the new government is a reform government."

Mr Schuessel and Mr Haider's joint declaration pledged that their federal government would maintain an "unswerving adherence to the spiritual and moral values which are the common heritage of the peoples of Europe and the true source of individual freedom, political liberty and the rule of law, principles which form the basis of all genuine democracy."

"The federal government works for an Austria in which xenophobia, anti-Semitism and racism have no place," it added.

Austria's future chancellor Wolfgang Schuessel has "dirtied his hands" by joining far-right leader Joerg Haider in a "scandalous" government pact, French European affairs minister Pierre Moscovici said.

webTitle: Blair hits out at countryside critics

fields.headline: Blair hits out at countryside critics
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown on Blair's rural ride
Martin Wainwright: We have no country bumpkins here
fields.trailText: Tony Blair admitted to a farming crisis in Britain today but insisted that towns and countryside share the same problems.
fields.body:
Tony Blair admitted to a farming crisis in Britain today but insisted that towns and countryside share the same problems.

In a plea to unite the country Mr Blair repeated his view that the north-south divide is less important than differences within regions and hit out at those those "who seek to divide town and country".

The speech to businessmen at Exeter University marked the first stage of his planned two-day visit to Devon and Cornwall after criticisms that his Government was neglecting rural Britain.

The prime minister said that while farming needed short term assistance, people in the countryside were more likely to be working in booming service sector or technology jobs than those in the cities.

"The idea that the whole of rural Britain is declining is to undersell its real achievement," he said.

On his arrival, he was met by a handful of protesting farmers. One shouted to him: "You're killing the British pig industry." Mr Blair conceded that the countryside did have its specific difficulties.

"Yes, there are problems. Farming, in particular, is in crisis. Yes, some of these problems are specifically rural, like bus services and post offices," he said.

"But there are villages, towns and cities in very rural parts of Britain that face the same problems as the rest of Britain. We aren't two nations - we are one nation. Same values. Same challenges. Often, though not always, common solutions," he added.

The prime minister's speech followed publication this morning of a cabinet office report on rural Britain which said that while there were pockets of poverty in the countryside, rural areas did fare well compared to cities and towns in many areas - such as better achieving schools and a reduced fear of crime.

"To describe the whole of Britain outside the main conurbations as existing in this state of crisis is to lose all sense of balance and it is balance that we need in this argument," he said.

fields.headline: Blair's rural ride
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown takes the rose-tinted spectacles away from Labour's vision of the countryside
fields.trailText: The ways of Tony Blair get curiouser and curiouser. Today he is in Cornwall,   delivering the message that country life is really rather super. Unemployment   down; low crime rates; nice views, that kind of thing.
fields.body:
The ways of Tony Blair get curiouser and curiouser. Today he is in Cornwall, delivering the message that country life is really rather super. Unemployment down; low crime rates; nice views, that kind of thing.

Environment minister Michael Meacher this morning praised the Dear Leader for leaving London to see the countryside for himself. "To go out and meet people on the spot who are going to give him a piece of their minds - and I'm sure they will - I think shows courage," he said.

To put it another way, it shows Blair at his banal, twittering worst, substituting a cheap photo-op for action. He will no doubt lament the drastic decline in farm incomes, and piously urge countryfolk to embrace change. Once again the great British myth, of an ancient unbroken rhythm of rural life which must adapt or die, will be rolled out. It's farcical: country life changes faster and more frequently than urban life, and always has. Farm incomes are important, but they are only part of a complex pattern which deserves more than cliche and platitude.

This article is being produced in Chipping Norton, on the edge of the Cotswolds, a town happily combining urban convenience and bucolic charm. Tony Blair, were he to come here on one of his rural rides, would no doubt be delighted by the signs and symptoms of local prosperity: the squadrons of spotless Range Rovers, the Michelin-starred restaurant, the busy shops. Best of all, he would be cheered to know that in the whole of West Oxfordshire district, there are just 345 registered jobseekers. That's an unemployment rate of 0.7%.

So we are doing very nicely, thank you very much Mr Tony. Or are we? Let's take a quick, very non-New Labour, peek beneath the surface.

Local employers are crying out for labour, but not to the extent of digging deep into their pockets. The local economy is dominated by retailing, agriculture, and tourism, all notoriously low-paying and seasonal. Most of the jobs currently on offer in the local newsagent's window, or in the district newspapers, are unskilled, part time, and typically pay around £4-£5 an hour.

Chipping Norton is 75 miles from London. The centripetal pull of the capital is strong. But the nearest station is four miles away, and the rush-hour return fare on the appallingly crowded and unreliable train is the best part of forty quid. There is a decent local bus service during the day, but virtually none at night. As a market town, there is a natural economic catchment area of villages and hamlets - maybe 20,000 people in all - who have no public transport to speak of.

Other public services have been pared down or flogged off. The ancient borough was destroyed in 1974, and replaced by a parish council. Local government is seated at Witney and Oxford, both twenty miles away. There is no longer a court in the town, nor a local newspaper. The rail branch line and the Crown post office have long gone. The local secondary school is secure, because all the others in the district have been closed, but the cottage hospital is limping along with reduced facilities, and is under constant threat.

The housing market, unless you are an estate agent, is in crisis. London folk will no doubt be envious to learn that you can still pick up a small cottage, or even a modest semi, for (just) under £100,000. Very nice for well-off commuters or retirees, but horrendous if you are on £5 an hour.

This lightning sketch of the underside of Chipping Norton will no doubt produce a cynical chuckle in more deprived parts of the countryside. Cornwall, for example. It is to be hoped that as he breezes and bumbles through that lovely but cruelly ill-served county, our millionaire prime minister will get the message that rural and small-town concerns deserve more than condescending pap from cityfolk.

webTitle: We'll have no country bumpkins here

fields.headline: We'll have no country bumpkins here
fields.standfirst:
Ahead of Tony Blair's speech claiming that rural life has improved, Martin Wainwright considers the changing face of the countryside
Plus: Great balls of fire
fields.trailText: Ahead of Tony Blair's speech claiming that rural life has improved, Martin Wainwright considers the changing face  of the countryside
fields.body:
It must be deeply satisfying to squash a chocolate eclair into the jowls of the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, and Tony Blair had better be wary of similar missiles when he tours the west country today. But no amount of flying confectionery will win the countryside the serious attention it deserves. It's more a matter of putting your own house - or cottage - in order.

The eclair thrower, Birgit Cunningham, makes the point rather nicely, as she curls up sinuously for photographers with her mane of blond hair and a bowl of strawberries. There may be an element of the girl-with-pearls whose engagement photo always came after the succulent property advertisements in Country Life; but this is no Farmer Gillian or pheasant-shooting Lady of the Manor.

Before taking up bun-hurling, Ms Cunningham was executive secretary to a vice-president of Universal Studios in Los Angeles; she has an archaeology and anthropology degree and parents who are in banking and organic cookery. This is the sort of character who may well answer the door draped with roses and wisteria in Midsomer Mallow nowadays; the countryside is no longer the part-feudal, part intensive-farming landscape that many of us vaguely imagine.

It is, however, still richly planted with the traditional British crop of conservatively minded self-interest; the belief that - unlike miners or textile workers whose jobs have been destroyed by economic and social change - rural ways of earning a living must continue, subsidised if necessary, for ever.

Farmers who placard their fields and barns with Eat British Food signs are apparently unaware of their own domestic surroundings; do they flick their remotes at British-made TV sets, drink British sherry and imagine that their M&S underwear was mass-produced in Britain? William Hague's call for schools, hospitals and the army to eat British food is the economics of PlaySchool (or, given his formidable intelligence, the more sinister economics of populism).

Where the country lobby is right is in shouting out its pain - and expressing it via flying eclairs - to insist on the attention of Britain's centralised, overwhelmingly metropolitan government. Those of us who live in cities and towns in the English regions will all say amen to that. But the message needs to reflect the changing, and reinvigorating nature of the 21st-century rural population; and it needs to puncture the complacency of Tony Blair with up-to-date detail.

For example: a study published today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation confirms the prime minister's view that young people are less likely to be jobless for long in the countryside than they are in towns. But it also dissects, as the prime minister didn't, the unrewarding, tedious nature of much of the work and the absence of any real career development path in, for instance, tourism and farming.

It shows too, and very precisely, an abysmal ignorance among rural employers about the opportunities of the New Deal. And that begs the question: why isn't the government crusading out its New Deal teams - from Sheffield, say, to Hadfield (famous home of TV's macabre rural parody The League of Gentlemen)?

Next time Ms Cunningham flings a missile, let it be a fortune cookie with questions like this curled up inside. And meanwhile she might rustle up her LA contacts to encourage the growth of e-commerce in the countryside. Telecottages are as pretty as farms, and more profitable.

Joseph Rowntree Foundation
The League of Gentlemen

Great balls of fire

In a world where mankind can seem invincible, it is good for the soul to hear how dim we can be. The fact that scientists do not yet understand exactly how ice-skates work is somehow reassuring; Nature still has secrets for our children and their children to unlock.

One of the oldest ones may have fallen, though, according to the other Nature, the learned magazine which reports from the frontiers of knowledge. Two scientists in New Zealand - a country, like Belgium, too often under-rated - have put forward a convincing theory to explain what "ball lightning" is.

Seen by fewer than one in 100 of us, but never forgotten by the lucky ones, the ethereal fireballs float for up to 15 seconds close to the ground, scorching nearby objects and sometimes appearing to bounce. For fans of Tinkerbell, the sad news is that they are almost certainly soil particles flung up by a lightning strike and briefly converted into very high temperature silicon. Still, skates and the relationship of speed, steel and melting ice remain elusively beyond our ken.

webTitle: Consultants sent in as three LEAs condemned

fields.headline: Consultants sent in as three LEAs condemned
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday pressed ahead with its plans to hand failing schools over to the private sector as it ordered intervention in three poorly performing Labour-controlled education authorities - including the Sheffield constituency of the education secretary, David Blunkett.
fields.body:
The government yesterday pressed ahead with its plans to hand failing schools over to the private sector as it ordered intervention in three poorly performing Labour-controlled education authorities - including the Sheffield constituency of the education secretary, David Blunkett.

Ministers announced a big recruitment drive to hire more consultants to help with the expected increase in interventions, following the publication of three highly critical reports by the schools watchdog, Ofsted, into education services in Leeds, Rotherham and Sheffield.

Chris Woodhead, head of Ofsted, admitted that all three reports were disturbing, but singled out the findings on Leeds - one of the biggest local education authorities in England - as by far the most serious and "shocking".

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, said consultants would be sent within weeks into all three authorities, but she expected significant transferral of school support services in Leeds to the private sector.

Ofsted identified weak leadership in Leeds in the past as the main reason for the current "parlous state" of the authority. Leeds council was unable to recruit an education director for four years, it claimed, partly because of perceptions of political interference.

A catalogue of weaknesses, particularly at secondary school level, include failure to monitor the progress of schools or support those causing concern. Mr Woodhead condemned the damage caused by political interference in the education service, with councillors competing for funding for schools in their own wards.

Sheffield was considered more positive due to recent improvements in management and leadership, but Mr Woodhead said it was still "a mixed picture". The authority needed to take urgent steps to improve support for its most disadvantaged children. In Rotherham, inspectors found "strategic drift, inadequate use of information and poor planning", coupled with "a lack of vision, leadership and effective management and ... inadequate funding".

Mr Woodhead strongly denied having a pro-privatisation agenda, despite claims by Leeds teaching unions that they were being made victims of a political conspiracy. "My job is to report honestly and accurately on strengths and weaknesses. What happens afterwards is a matter for politicians."

But he revealed that inspectors had "serious concerns" about nearly 40% of the local education authorities in England they had visited - 23 out of 59. So far, services have been put to the private sector in the London boroughs of Islington and Hackney.

Ms Morris said the government was expanding its list of approved consultants to meet the expected increase in the number of LEA interventions. But she insisted that the government saw a continuing role for LEAs.

She also denied that the evidence of the poor running of schools in Labour-controlled councils should be embarrassing for Mr Blunkett, who was Sheffield city council leader in 1985 and whose Brightside constituency is in the city. "The only embarrassment to the secretary of state would be if we failed to act where under-achievement is identified."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "David Blunkett was leader of the council. Now he is a Sheffield MP and in charge of the country's education system.

"He should stop trying to run the country's schools from Whitehall and pay some attention to what is happening in his own backyard."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "Privatised LEAs are being pumped with additional resources not previously made available to 'failing' councils."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "David Blunkett was leader of the council. Now he is a Sheffield MP and in charge of the country's education system. "He should stop trying to run the country's schools from Whitehall and pay some attention to what is happening in his own backyard." Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "Privatised LEAs are being pumped with additional resources not previously made available to 'failing' councils."

webTitle: Leeds LEA calls in the consultants

fields.headline: Leeds LEA calls in the consultants
fields.standfirst: Ofsted report reveals "strange" practices in education authority as Leeds calls in the consultants
fields.trailText: Ofsted report reveals "strange" practices in education authority as Leeds calls in the consultants
fields.body:
RATS and MICE have gnawed away at the trust in fair play which was once rock solid among parents and the schools which look after 117,000 children in Leeds.

The acronyms stand for two highly unusual funds available to every city councillor to spend in their ward, with results which the schools minister Estelle Morris described yesterday as "strange".

One school's goodie-bag from RATS (the larger fund, nicknamed because the smaller is called Members Involvement in Community Expenditure) reached £45,000 in a year, while others got peanuts or nothing because their councillors preferred tree-planting or elderly people's homes.

"The result," says the damning report from Ofsted, whose director Chris Woodhead was visibly goggling at the rodent budgets during his press conference, "builds an element of incoherence into educational funding, removes the allocation of funding to the greatest need, and undermines equitable capital funding for schools."

Worse, according to Leeds shadow education spokesman, Liberal Democrat councillor Brian Cleasby, is an unofficial pattern of 'political spending', which saw a primary school in his ward - where Labour almost always come bottom - wait 14 years for new paint, while one on his Labour counterpart*s patch was spruced-up twice.

"Worse still," says Mr Cleasby, "is the political control and meddling in management which have driven some senior staff out and stopped others applying for jobs here." His council colleague Brian Jennings described an enlightening train journey two years ago with a London education director who told him: "People wouldn't touch Leeds with a bargepole."

The Ofsted report goes straight to the point in its introduction, linking weak staff leadership to councillors' 'heavy involvement' in education, and quoting the district auditor and a head-hunting firm - hired in some desperation in 1997 to find an education director - as expressing alarm about political interference. The everyday grumbles of Mr Cleasby were highlighted spectacularly when two senior Labour councillors had dinner with a possible candidate who was then invited to apply, failed to get the job and won £60,000 from the already-squeezed Leeds budget in a race discrimination settlement.

"We need to make crystal clear where the dividing line is for councillors," said Ms Morris, whose consultants will spend the next 12 weeks deciding whether Leeds can put its own house in order or will have to go, humiliatingly, to outside providers. "Of course effective politicians are essential, but they and the officers must be entirely clear about their respective roles, and governors and schools must understand that as well."

Leeds' Labour leadership drew comfort yesterday from the "historical nature" of the worst criticism, emphasising Ofsted's use of the word "auspicious" to describe leader Brian Walker's "strong commitment to maximum delegation of authority to officers and greater transparency" and the appointment, after four rudderless years, of a permanent education director. The man who took the helm 14 months ago, Keith Burton, said: "I have never worked anywhere before where I have had so many delegated powers. We accept the criticisms of our weaknesses in the Ofsted report and we are revamping our education action plan. It will be carried out with the consultants' help and with strong staff leadership."

Mr Walker also underlined new protocols for councillor/staff dealings and signalled a "hands-off" future, with an independent monitoring body including the vice-chancellors of both Leeds universities and the Catholic Bishop of Leeds. But at least one other prominent local worthy has turned a place down, on the ground that forthright criticism would not be genuinely welcomed; and the refusal of any councillors involved in past interference to resign leaves the Liberal Democrats and the smaller Conservative group completely cynical.

Optimists, however, point to Sheffield where a similar situation three years ago has developed - in spite of the multiple problems facing all large cities - into strong officer leadership within overall political guidelines.

Sheffield's education director Jonathan Crossley-Holland described his own city's mixed Ofsted report yesterday as fair and balanced and said: "Things here were in disarray, which is Ofsted-speak for a shambles. But the Labour council, and now the Liberal Democrats, have encouraged strong staff leadership, setting general directions but recognising how many decisions must be decided on professional, not political grounds."

webTitle: Pressure grows for a universal campaign

fields.headline: Pressure grows for a universal campaign
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has ordered a review of the Government's policy towards developing countries after being presented with figures predicting a devastating cycle of ever-deepening poverty in Africa, write Ewen MacAskill and John Carvel .
fields.body:
Tony Blair has ordered a review of the Government's policy towards developing countries after being presented with figures predicting a devastating cycle of ever-deepening poverty in Africa, write Ewen MacAskill and John Carvel .

While access to basic education is rising throughout the world, it is falling in Africa. By 2015, the United Nations' target date to achieve universal education, 54m African children will not even be receiving a basic education, exacerbating the poverty trap.

Pressure groups such as Oxfam want Mr Blair to lead a campaign to make universal education a priority in the way the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, has been in the forefront of the fight to reduce third world debt.

The issue is on the agenda at this week's education meeting in Rio de Janeiro of the E9 group of high-population countries (Indo nesia, Brazil, India, China, Egypt, Mexico, Bangladesh, Pakistan and Nigeria), but the key focus is the April meeting of world leaders in Dakar, Senegal, to discuss how to bridge the education gap.

Mr Blair held a meeting at Downing Street last December to discuss the issue with representatives from the Foreign Office, the Education Department, the Depart- ment for International Development and the British Council.

fields.headline: Reuters poised to float Instinet
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The information group Reuters is understood to have made a firm decision for a partial flotation of its electronic share brokerage business Instinet and a restructuring of its fund management arm.
fields.body:
The information group Reuters is understood to have made a firm decision for a partial flotation of its electronic share brokerage business Instinet and a restructuring of its fund management arm.

Sources said the long-awaited flotation of Instinet is expected to be announced next Tuesday when Reuters details its internet strategy for 2000 and also its results.

Analysts are looking for the group to post a pretax profit of £575m for last year.

Reuters declined to comment yesterday on the speculation. Its shares soared 35p to 966p yesterday, having recovered from last October when the stock was languishing below 550p.

A troubled conference call to analysts in October by chief executive Peter Job saw the share price of Reuters slide because of concerns about his leadership and the company's strategic direction.

Reuters is also expected to announce plans for its Greenhouse Fund, which holds a portfolio of internet investments.

Last month Reuters lured one of Goldman Sachs senior executives, David Lockwood, to head the Greenhouse Fund which was set up in 1994 and is valued at more than $1bn (£622m).

Some of the volatility of Reuters share price last year was attributed to concerns about the sales growth at Instinet because of the fierce competition among online brokers for institutional business.

Lorna Tilbian, analyst at West LB Panmure, said there had been long-term speculation, that Reuters would eventually float Instinet to crystallise its hidden value.

Instinet was acquired by Reuters in 1987. Since then it has become the largest communications network for equity orders in the United States.

The group has built a strong reputation for offering after-market trading to its leading customers, mostly large institutions, that want access to liquid stocks when most major stock markets are closed.

It is expected to offer retail trading services by April.

The group is also poised to enter two more potentially lucrative markets - institutional fixed-income trading and initial public offerings.

These businesses will need major investment from its owner and, if successful, could secure the business for several years.

Analysts have also been waiting to see if Reuters would sell some more of its stake in Nasdaq-listed Tibco Software, in which it holds a 63% stake.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter rated Reuters a "strong buy" last month, claiming the company's core business was still undervalued.

The broker also said that while Instinet was still facing competitive pressures, a partial flotation of the division would remove uncertainty and allow further investment in the core business.

fields.headline: Nigeria 2 - 0 Morocco
fields.standfirst: Second half report
fields.trailText:
4 A quiet start, with Morocco seemingly content to hold the home nation.
10 The first clear-cut chance of the game. A through ball from Kanu releases Tijani Babangida. The Ajax man bears down on goal, but loses his cool somewhat and allows a scrambling Fouhami to make a save.
19 Babayaro is fouled five yards outside the Morocco box. Jay Jay Okocha steps up to take the kick and cracks it against the bar.
29 Goal Nigeria 1 - 0 Morocco A low cross-field pass from Adepoju finds Finidi George unmarked 25 yards from goal. Finidi controls the ball with his right foot, and then drives it with his left. The ball flies over Fouhami and flies into the net, seemingly gathering pace as it does. Surely the best goal of the tournament so far.
34 Against the run of play, Morocco graft out a chance. The speedy Salaheddine Bassir escapes the attentions of his marker on the edge of the area. But just as he is about to pull the trigger, Taribo West pulls off a vital last-ditch tackle.
43 Bassir comes close again when he races away down the right, cuts inside and shoots from the edge of the area, forcing Shorunmu to make to make another fine save.
45 Substitution: Mohamed El Badraoui on for Salaheddine Bassir.
Morocco defend well as Kanu tries to force his way through the centre. A series of crunching tackles ends in a booking for Said Chiba. Nigeria win a corner deep into stoppage time. Babayaro takes but Fouhami charges out to the edge of the area to punch clear.
Half-time

fields.headline: Nigeria 2 - 0 Morocco
fields.standfirst: First half report
fields.trailText: Nigeria: Ike Shorunmu; Godwin Okpara, Furo Iyenemi, Taribo West, Celestine Babayaro; Tijani Babangida, Mutiu Adepoju, Augustin Okocha, Benedict Akwuegbu; Finidi George, Nwankwo Kanu
fields.body:
Nigeria: Ike Shorunmu; Godwin Okpara, Furo Iyenemi, Taribo West, Celestine Babayaro; Tijani Babangida, Mutiu Adepoju, Augustin Okocha, Benedict Akwuegbu; Finidi George, Nwankwo Kanu

Morocco: Khalid Fouhami; Rachid Neqrouz, Jamal Sellami, Lahcen Abrami; Adbelilah Sabre, Said Chiba, Taher El Khalej, Youssef Mariani, Mustapha Hadji; Ahmed Bahja, Salaheddine Bassir

46 Substitutions: Gbenga Okunowo on for Furo Iyenemi, Julius Aghahowa on for Benedict Akwuegbu. Nigeria get the second half underway.. They build from the back and push Morocco somewhat willingly back into their own half before Julius Aghahowa sees his shot well saved by Fouhami.
48 Hadji comes close with a long-range shot but the ball is mustered well by Shorunmu.
49 Morocco are content to sit back as Nigeria advance to the edge of the Morocco area once more.
54 Nigeria appear to be playing at half pace despite Morocco encouraging them to come forward.
59 Morocco wake up a bit and start to get the hang of moving upfield.
63 A Nigerian corner is passed back in to Aghahowa who rifles in a shot that rebounds off the legs of a Moroccan defender.
65 Okocha races around the edge of the area, drifts inside and fires in a shot from the right corner of the penalty area; Fouhami saves.
68 Babangida finds himself in space on the right but blows a golden chance to increase Nigeria's lead; he cuts into the area and, intead of passing to Kanu who is up in support, he crashes into the Moroccan defence and looses possession.
70 Substitution: Adil Ramzi on for Ahmed Bahja. Booking: El Khalej for swinging an arm at Aghahowa. Okocha takes the resulting free-kick from 30 yards out, gets the ball around the wall and Fouhami makes a hash of the save, but Morocco manage to clear.
72 Babangida has a great shot saved and the follow up from Taribo West also fails to find the target.
74 All Nigeria now as Morocco play a risky strategy of... well, not trying very hard at all by the looks of it.
77 Substitutions: Garba Lawal on for Mutiu Adepoju, Rachid Benmahmoud on for Taher El Khalej.
78 Finidi races up and attempts a one-two but the move is cut short by a flurry of Moroccan legs.
80 Aghahowa continues to look the most likely to get a second for Nigeria with his movement around a frankly sedentary Moroccan defence. When Finidi feeds him in a good position on the left from the centre of the park, however, his return ball only gives away possession.
81 Goal: Nigeria 2 - 0 Morocco Aghahowa latches onto a long ball just outside the penalty area; with two Moroccan defenders to beat, the 17-year-old chases the ball before lifting a delicate shot over the advancing Fouhami. As if the quality of the goal was not enough, Aghahowa then celebrates with five consecutive back-flips.
85 Morroco come close to a consolation goal. Saber's cross requires a desperate headed clearance from Taribo West to keep it out of goal.
Full time Nigeria join Tunisia as qualifiers from Group 4 and go on to meet Senegal in the quarter-finals.

fields.headline: Fed piles on rate pressure
fields.standfirst: US economy maintains searing pace
fields.trailText: The US Federal Reserve yesterday moved to quash the threat of inflation derailing America's record economic expansion, by raising rates for the fourth time in seven months.
fields.body:
The US Federal Reserve yesterday moved to quash the threat of inflation derailing America's record economic expansion, by raising rates for the fourth time in seven months.

In a widely expected move, the US central bank increased the federal funds rate by a quarter-point to 5.75%. US base rates are now the same level as the UK's. It also raised the less widely used discount rate by a quarter-point to 5.5%.

Wall Street took yesterday's move calmly but most economists believe further interest rate rises are on the cards. David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G Lanston, said: "This is the beginning of a series of cautious rate hikes aimed at slowing the economy's growth rate to a more sustainable pace."

After rising 60 points ahead of the Fed announcement, the Dow Jones share index lost all that and was six points down at 11,034 in midday trading.

The Fed's open market committee hinted that yesterday's move would not be the last. It
said: "The committee remains concerned that over time increases in demand will continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, even after taking account of the pronounced rise in productivity growth.

"Such trends could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's record economic expansion."

Yesterday's move came as the US economy broke all records for uninterrupted growth, entering its 107th month of expansion. In the last quarter of 1999 the economy grew at an annual rate of 5.8%. Unemployment has fallen to a 30-year low while households have gone on a debt-fuelled spending spree.

Robert Rubin, the former US treasury secretary, said last night that policymakers should be worried about the build-up of imbalances in the US economy.

Some analysts believe the economy has entered a "new paradigm" where old economic rules no longer apply.

But Mr Rubin said this view was "contrary to all of human
history with respect to markets and economies, and that should be a sobering caution." In a speech to the London School of Economics he warned that complacency was the biggest threat to the global economy.

A record trade deficit, tight labour markets, a low personal savings rate and stock valuations which were high by conventional measures were factors he cited as potential problems for the US economy.

In yesterday's announcement, the Fed for the first time employed a new disclosure policy which it hopes will remove some of the confusion that arose in markets over the past year over its announcements about potential future actions.

The Fed said that future "risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future".

This statement does not guarantee that there will be future rate increases but puts financial markets on notice that the Fed continues to be worried about inflation.
