fields.headline: Putting us in the picture
fields.standfirst: It started life as a power station. Now it intends to become the most important modern art museum in the world.  Jonathan Jones  talks to the team behind Tate Modern's mission - to challenge the very way we look at art
fields.trailText: It started life as a power station. Now it intends to become the most important modern art museum in the world. Jonathan Jones talks to the team behind Tate Modern's mission - to challenge the very way we look at art
fields.body:
'We're creating a major, major museum of modern art and we're rethinking what that is at the same time. I think it's possibly the most thorough rethinking of how you present a historic collection." Lars Nittve, director of Tate Modern, laughs at his own audacity. "That's quite a claim, isn't it? But no, I dare to say that."

Nittve strolls around the office annexe behind Bankside power station, where his team are writing explanatory wall texts and arranging the transfer of artworks from the Tate Gallery further up the Thames at Millbank. He and his two colleagues in the triumvirate that will run Tate Modern, programme curator Frances Morris and director of exhibitions and displays Iwona Blazwick, seem to be enjoying themselves.

They have the good fortune to be driving a juggernaut among cultural institutions. There has been no lack of huge building projects in Britain at the dawn of the new century, or massive claims for projects that are in reality rather slight. But the new Tate is not another folly; its consequences will be profound. It's the first national museum of modern art Britain has ever had. It also has aspirations to be the most important modern art museum in the world.

It won't be difficult to sell the architecture of Tate Modern, carved out of the power station's brown brick hulk by Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron. As the builders start to pull out and the curators move in, the contrast between the vast turbine hall and the warm, glowing lightboxes and subtly designed gallery spaces hanging above makes for a surprisingly intimate space. "It's quite friendly in some strange way," says Nittve, "given that it's such a very tough building."

What might be harder to explain to people, however, is the iconoclastic and radical programme of art display that Nittve, Tate chief Nicholas Serota and their team plan for Tate Modern. This museum is not setting out just to be popular, but to challenge the way we think about art.

To grasp the scale of this ambition you have to look back more than 70 years to 1929, when the Museum of Modern Art - big MoMA - opened in New York. This was a museum that set out not simply to preserve the art of the past but to alter that of the future. When we say or picture "modern art", the image in our heads is one shaped by MoMA, and by one of its directors in particular, Alfred H Barr. In 1936, Barr published a diagram of modern art that defined it as an evolutionary sequence of "isms". The flow chart looks strange today: neat arrows connect big printed words and show how cubism connects to Suprematism which connects to Bauhaus as does constructivism. If you follow another arrow from cubism you get Dadaism and surrealism and everything meets up in abstract art. Which, conveniently for MoMA and American art, meant that by 1950 Jackson Pollock was recognised as the climax of artistic evolution.

Tate Modern is the first institution to have the cheek to stand up to MoMA and set out to dismantle, once and for all, what curators at Bankside call in icy tones "the Barr model". For some time now, artists, art historians and art museums have railed against this image of modern art as an evolution. For one thing it is a story with an ending - it culminates in abstract art and everything after, from Andy Warhol to today's young British artists, becomes so much decadence. For another, it always was part of an American nationalist myth.

Not that the new Tate Gallery plans to impose on the 21st century a new nationalist evolutionary scheme, a neat Tate wall text in place of Barr's diagram explaining how Picasso and Duchamp lead to Damien Hirst. But the new museum is as ruthless as New York was in its heyday. It looks at the history of modern art from the standpoint of London now. It dismantles hierarchies, mocks the grand narrative, and asserts that art in Britain today is as exciting and significant as Picasso or Pollock.

When the builders started to tear the old industrial machinery out of Bankside, a team of curators at the Tate Gallery started to rethink the history of modern art and how it could be presented in a museum. Frances Morris is a long-standing Tate curator who has commissioned the nonagenarian installation artist Louise Bourgeois to be the first artist to work in Tate Modern's turbine hall. She is also responsible for overseeing the huge team installing the opening displays as art is brought in from the Tate Gallery.

"At Millbank there was an underlying notion of a succession of avant-garde gestures," she says, "almost the Barr model. And I think we wanted to move away from that. From the perspective of the year 2000 it doesn't accommodate a vast history of art in the 20th century."Ever since Nicholas Serota announced his grand projet, the question of what will be put in it has been a running joke. There are reasons for scepticism; whatever the Tate says, its own earlier history - in the 30s it had a director who was hostile to modern art and so didn't buy any - has left gaps in the collection compared to somewhere such as MoMA. Since the announcement of the Tate Modern project in December 1992 there have been moves to put these right by acquisitions and loans.

But it turns out they have been thinking along somewhat grander terms than simply filling a space. Probably most of us, even though we may go to the Turner Prize show and perhaps enjoy contemporary art, have an assumption at the back of our minds that the jury is out on this art, that it doesn't belong in the same pantheon as Picasso. Morris says simply: "We're not trying to impose an endpoint or a dead end. We're trying to open doors. We wanted to bring the beginning and the end of the 20th century together."

To get away from what it sees as the monolithic history of modern art as a series of "isms", the new museum will present four separate cuts through art since 1900, four separate "suites" of displays. These neatly fit the long, rectangular shape of the galleries disposed on each side of Bankside's big brown chimney. You won't find a progression in any of the suites from cubism through Suprematism to abstract art. Instead you will find juxtapositions of art across time.

Perhaps the most provocative of these will be in the room in which a Picasso still life can be seen next to the most controversial artwork ever bought by the Tate Gallery, Carl André's Equivalent VIII (1966), the infamous bricks which caused a bitter public row when they were acquired in the 1970s. Picasso's 1914 Still Life, a masterpiece of cubist assemblage, is a three-dimensional wooden relief representing a glass, a hunk of bread and a knife, with a piece of curtain fabric hanging down to represent a tablecloth - everyday objects, a bit like bricks, Tate Modern seems to be suggesting.

Provocative in another way will be the showing of British painter Howard Hodgkin next to one of his influences, the French "intimist" painter Bonnard - one of the themes of Tate Modern's opening displays being that British art is central to the story of modern art. The contemporary American-born but British-based artist Susan Hiller gets a whole room to herself for her collection of objects and texts inspired by London's Freud Museum.

"One of the things that happens in museums," says Morris, "is that the works become part of the history of the museum and lose the context of their making." One of the opening displays will centre on Picasso's Weeping Woman, one of the Tate's most treasured paintings. The museum has always shown this painting of a jagged, cut-up woman whose tears turn into butterflies simply as a modern classic. The new display will put it back in history, using film footage, photographs, posters and documents to tell the story of how it came to Britain in 1938 along with Guernica as part of a fundraising tour for the republican cause in the Spanish civil war.

This desire, as Morris puts it, "to make more of a connection between art and life" informs several Bankside displays. One will examine Primitivism in France at the beginning of the 20th century, the passion for African and Oceanic masks that runs through Picasso's Cubist paintings and returns in Surrealism. The art in which you can see a pursuit of the "primitive" will be shown next to artefacts and documents setting it in the context of European empire.

Tate Modern will be the first museum of this scale to give the ephemeral gestures of recent avant-gardes the same status as Cubism or Surrealism. The Fluxus group, wacky 60s art radicals who valued spontaneity and chance and counted Joseph Beuys and Yoko Ono as members, get a big display to themselves that includes a floor-to-ceiling chess set and a ping pong table.

The presence at Tate Modern of Blazwick "signals that being out there in the scene is central," says Nittve. A former director of exhibitions at the ICA and a prominent figure in the London art world, her brief is to establish a link between the museum and young artists. "I love that energy in London right now," says Blazwick. "I want it to somehow flow through us as well." Opening attempts include a display called Between Cinema and a Hard Place that surveys large-scale installations and video art and stars a host of international artists.

Nittve's dream is to combine in Tate Modern the authority of a museum and the excitement of what he calls "a stage for contemporary culture". It was conceived when the London art scene was starting to become internationally renowned. Today, there is still a great deal of life in the new British art. When MoMA opened in New York it provided a theatre of contemporary art that inspired Jackson Pollock. What will happen when London's young artists get into Bankside is anyone's guess.

They will have to wait their turn, though. The first of the vast Unilever commissions in the turbine hall is by Bourgeois, who showed at Peggy Guggenheim's gallery Art of This Century in the 1940s alongside the Abstract Expressionists and who is the most provocative figure in contemporary art. Bourgeois is, says Morris, "a symbol of Tate Modern". The old history of modern art denied this kind of continuity: there was the great modern art of Picasso and then there was all that rubbishy conceptual stuff you see today. Tate Modern takes this attitude and chucks it in the Thames.

"It's essential to what we're doing that there will always be an element of contemporary art," says Nittve, "that there will always be living artists working in the space."

Yet there are difficulties in making a museum a centre of creativity rather than a storehouse of the past. Museums have an institutional weight that can make them clumsy commissioners of the new. The London art scene is flourishing but Tate Modern's pre-opening programme, which has been running around Bankside for the past couple of years, did not tap into the current all that successfully. Too much of it felt contrived, even twee.

But who wouldn't wish them well? The team at Tate Modern seem down-to-earth. The real value of their museum for living art is exactly what the value of MoMA was for American artists in the middle of the 20th century. It will up the game. Just as seeing Picasso challenged young American artists, so competing with Bourgeois will be a goad to young British artists. With luck, this space will inspire them to think big and with a sense of history.

"What we need to do when we bring voices in from outside," says Morris, "is offer them a sense of authority and purpose and seriousness." Just what the art of this century needs.

Museums that changed art history

Vatican Belvedere

This courtyard in the Vatican, where Renaissance artists could see classical statues, influenced art more than any other museum in history.

Louvre

When the Louvre opened in Paris as a public museum in 1793, French artists got a permanent storehouse of art to challenge them.

Petrograd Museum of Artistic Culture

St Petersburg's museum of modern art, which existed briefly in the 1920s, defined Russian revolutionary art.

Art of the Century

In the 1940s Peggy Guggenheim founded her Manhattan space Art of This Century. It became a catalyst for modern American art.

Museum of Modern Art

This New York museum codified "modern art"and shaped contemporary art as we know it. Jackson Pollock's reputation was made here as was Jasper Johns' and Frank Stella's.

 Tate Modern opens on May 12

webTitle: Hanged man's family lodge racism protest

fields.headline: Hanged man's family lodge racism protest
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The family of a black man found hanged in Telford has formally complained to the police complaints authority, alleging that the investigation was bungled because of police racism.
fields.body:
The family of a black man found hanged in Telford has formally complained to the police complaints authority, alleging that the investigation was bungled because of police racism.

Jason McGowan, 20, was found suspended from railings by a busy road on new year's eve. His widow, Sinead, 23, believes he was murdered by a racist gang rather than taking his own life.

Five months earlier his uncle, Harold, whom his family claim suffered a race hate campaign, was found hanging. Jason had been investigating his uncle's death and the McGowans had received further threats warning them to halt their inquiries.

Sinead McGowan says police were too quick to assume Jason's death, like Harold's, was suicide.

The complaint alleges that West Mercia police failed to investigate Jason McGowan's death thoroughly because he was black and that they treated his family poorly.

The news will come as a blow to the force, already under pressure because of the attention on the case.

On Tuesday it agreed with the McGowans that a fresh investigation would be launched into both deaths and allegations of racial harassment. It did not admit that its detectives had made any errors.

Mrs McGowan has asked the solicitor Imran Khan to represent her. He acted for Stephen Lawrence's parents, and helped secure a damning judgment against the Metropolitan police in that case that institutional racism had hampered their inquiry.

Mr Khan said Mrs McGowan wanted control of the investigation removed from West Mercia police and handed over to Scotland Yard's race and violent crimes task force. That is headed by the deputy assistant commissioner, John Grieve.

Such a step would be unprecedented and require the consent of West Mercia's chief constable, Peter Hampson.

Mr Khan said: "The family has filed a formal complaint that the investigation into the death of Jason McGowan was not thorough. Police did not conduct a full and proper investigation into the death because of the victim's race.

"They are also complaining about the treatment of the family by police during the inquiry."

An independent force should take over the investigation into Jason's death. "Jason's family will be asking for a completely independent force to investigate the death of Jason at least.

"This is to avoid the suspicion that West Mercia might simply conduct a perfunctory investigation and come back with the same conclusion in order to minimise the criticism they could face over their original investigation.

"The family want Scotland Yard's race and violent crimes task force to take over."

A PCA spokesman said they were waiting to receive documentation regarding the McGowan case from Mr Khan and declined to comment further.

It is expected an outside force will investigate the complaints under the PCA's supervision.

West Mercia police confirmed last night that the deaths of Harold and Jason McGowan had been logged as racial incidents, but declined to say whether they had been investigated as such.

Mrs McGowan and friends last saw Jason at 11.30pm on new year's eve at a pub. He was described as being in good spirits and stepped out for fresh air.

He was found the following morning hanged by his own leather belt.

His uncle, aged 34, is alleged to have been told he was on a far-right death list after denying entry to white youths while working as a doorman at a Telford pub.

fields.headline: Share tipping
fields.trailText:
Why is Piers Morgan in trouble?
The stock exchange and the Press Complaints Commission are investigating the Mirror editor after he bought around £20,000 worth of shares in a technology company the day before his newspaper tipped its shares, doubling the share price.
fields.body:
Why is Piers Morgan in trouble?
The stock exchange and the Press Complaints Commission are investigating the Mirror editor after he bought around £20,000 worth of shares in a technology company the day before his newspaper tipped its shares, doubling the share price.

What was the company?
Viglen Technology is a computer hardware company owned by business tycoon Sir Alan Sugar, also the chairman of Tottenham Hotspur and former executive of Amstrad.

Where did the tip appear?
In the City Slickers column written by Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, who were brought on to the Mirror on the recommendation of Kelvin McKenzie, former editor of the Sun. They revealed "exclusively" on January 18 that the Viglen company was about to set up an internet arm, even though this had been known since Christmas. Newspaper and television share tipsters can have an enormous impact on stock market prices, especially on so called penny shares. Show Me The Money, Channel 4's share tipping programme has had a huge impact on share-trading patterns. While it was on air at the end of last year, there was an explosion of sharebuying by small investors. The city watchdog, the financial services authority, was so concerned it issued a warning to retail investors about the danger of dealing in small illiquid stocks. The internet has fuelled the boom in retail trading with sites like Motley Fool and Hemmington Scott.

What are the rules for financial journalists and tips?
The PCC code of conduct on financial journalism states that even where the law does not prohibit it, journalists must not use for their own profit financial information they receive in advance of its general publication, nor should they pass such information to others. Journalists must not write about companies in which they or their close families hold a significant financial interest without disclosing the interest to their bosses. They must not buy or sell shares about which they have recently written or intend to write about in the near future.

What has Mr Morgan had to say?
Mr Morgan, who was forced to defend his share dealings to the board of Trinity Mirror, the parent company of his paper, said he was happy to cooperate with the PCC. In a statement, he said: "My purchase of the shares was made six hours before the City Slickers obtained their story from Viglen's chief executive."

Have there been past cases of financial tipsters getting into trouble?
The most famous case occurred in the mid-1980s when Wall Street Journal share tipster R Foster Winans was convinced of fraud and given an 18-month prison sentence. Winans had been buying shares in companies as well as passing on the information to his gay lover before tipping them in the influential Heard on the Street column. He made only $30,000 in profits from his activities, but his case played an important part in American law on insider dealing, which eventually led to the downfall of Ivan Boesky, a leading financial figure of the 'greed is good' era.

What happens next?
The PCC inquiry is expected to last about a month. The stock exchange, which never comments on specific investigations, is understood to be investigating both Mr Morgan's dealings and the role of City Slickers share-tipping column, and has referred the case to the department of trade and industry. Insider dealing is an offence under the financial services act and it is the DTI that prosecutes in such cases. In the preliminary stages, the stock exchange uses computers to determine who has made a transaction and when, and can identify "unusual" market activity. fields.bodyText: Why is Piers Morgan in trouble? The stock exchange and the Press Complaints Commission are investigating the Mirror editor after he bought around £20,000 worth of shares in a technology company the day before his newspaper tipped its shares, doubling the share price. What was the company? Viglen Technology is a computer hardware company owned by business tycoon Sir Alan Sugar, also the chairman of Tottenham Hotspur and former executive of Amstrad. Where did the tip appear? In the City Slickers column written by Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, who were brought on to the Mirror on the recommendation of Kelvin McKenzie, former editor of the Sun. They revealed "exclusively" on January 18 that the Viglen company was about to set up an internet arm, even though this had been known since Christmas. Newspaper and television share tipsters can have an enormous impact on stock market prices, especially on so called penny shares. Show Me The Money, Channel 4's share tipping programme has had a huge impact on share-trading patterns. While it was on air at the end of last year, there was an explosion of sharebuying by small investors. The city watchdog, the financial services authority, was so concerned it issued a warning to retail investors about the danger of dealing in small illiquid stocks. The internet has fuelled the boom in retail trading with sites like Motley Fool and Hemmington Scott. What are the rules for financial journalists and tips? The PCC code of conduct on financial journalism states that even where the law does not prohibit it, journalists must not use for their own profit financial information they receive in advance of its general publication, nor should they pass such information to others. Journalists must not write about companies in which they or their close families hold a significant financial interest without disclosing the interest to their bosses. They must not buy or sell shares about which they have recently written or intend to write about in the near future. What has Mr Morgan had to say? Mr Morgan, who was forced to defend his share dealings to the board of Trinity Mirror, the parent company of his paper, said he was happy to cooperate with the PCC. In a statement, he said: "My purchase of the shares was made six hours before the City Slickers obtained their story from Viglen's chief executive." Have there been past cases of financial tipsters getting into trouble? The most famous case occurred in the mid-1980s when Wall Street Journal share tipster R Foster Winans was convinced of fraud and given an 18-month prison sentence. Winans had been buying shares in companies as well as passing on the information to his gay lover before tipping them in the influential Heard on the Street column. He made only $30,000 in profits from his activities, but his case played an important part in American law on insider dealing, which eventually led to the downfall of Ivan Boesky, a leading financial figure of the 'greed is good' era. webTitle: Sam Wood: A Night at the Opera

fields.headline: Sam Wood: A Night at the Opera
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 53: Sam Wood's A Night at the Opera
fields.trailText: You could say that the Marx Brothers' humour was often cruel and defiantly misogynistic. But they laid the ground for the Pythons and others to till, and their nose-thumbing at proprieties shows Jewish-American humour at its most original
fields.body:
When I first saw the Marx Brothers I wasn't overly enthusiastic. I preferred Laurel and Hardy (I still do), or even Abbott and Costello (a grave mistake). Part of the trouble was that, every time I went to see a Marx Bros epic, the audience laughed so much that I couldn't hear more than a quarter of the verbal gags. At that time, just after the second world war, they were so popular amongst the intelligentsia they often mocked that you almost took against them.

I now know better. And the only question is whether one goes for the anarchic, if more awkward, Paramount movies like Monkey Business and Duck Soup, certain masterpieces of anti-bourgeois insanity, or the smoother, music-oriented MGM films like A Night at the Opera and A Day at the Races. Most aficionados prefer the Paramount films; these hardly enhanced but seldom interfered with the Brothers' comedy. One American critic wrote that the films never did the Marx Brothers justice.

But A Night at the Opera is marginally my choice, because it was the film that changed all that, as producer Irving Thalberg fulfilled his promise to make "a big-time act using small-time material" into big time all the way.

"Don't worry about a thing", Thalberg said to Harpo, "You get me the laughs and I'll get you the story". He insisted that they took the show out on the road as a stage attraction in order to hone it to perfection. The famous stateroom scene, in which the brothers and several passengers pack into one small ship's bedroom, became a classic as a result: apparently no one laughed until it had been embellished by the Brothers on stage with a series of ad-libs that were eventually added to the script.

The film has several amazing sequences - notably the contract-tearing farrago between Groucho and Chico, and the crazy finale in which Harpo does a Tarzan act on the flyropes perfectly in time with Verdi's music. Its level of invention is high from the moment Harpo fences with the starchy opera-house conductor, misleading the orchestra until the overture to Il Trovatore turns into a rousing rendition of Take Me Out to the Ball Game, while Groucho paces the stalls selling peanuts.

Despite the sentimental songs from Allan Jones and Kitty Carlisle, who also provide the unlikely romance, the assaults on grand opera are at least as icono clastic as anything the dadaists committed to the screen earlier. Bunuel, for one, loved them. Considering this was an MGM super-production it seems a miracle that Thalberg permitted it to be sabotaged so thoroughly. His successors did not, and the Brothers found themselves adrift in MGM movies that did them scant justice.

You could say that the Brothers' humour was often cruel and defiantly misogynist. But they laid the ground for the Pythons and others to till, and their nose-thumbing at proprieties shows Jewish-American humour at its most original. There's the scene when Harpo climbs through a porthole into the cabin of a liner where three bearded men are sleeping. He picks up a pair of scissors with his eyes alight, lifts a beard and a butterfly flutters out. What is this if it isn't surreal?

Credits:
Director Sam Wood
Writers James Kevin McGuinness, George S Kaufman
Starring The Marx Brothers, Kitty Carlisle, Allan Jones
US, 1936, 93 minutes

fields.headline: Farming? This is milking
fields.standfirst: The agricultural lobby's calls for cash sound hollow to the mining communities of the north-east
fields.trailText: The agricultural lobby's calls for cash sound hollow to the mining communities of the north-east
fields.body:
Tony Blair has a countryside crisis on his doorstep. As an MP of the shires - Durham, actually - he knows all about plunging family incomes and rising unemployment caused by the collapse of what is, essentially, a rural industry.

From the mid-80s to the mid-90s alone, this industry shed at least 200,000 jobs, leaving once-prospering villages devastated and isolated, and some families near-destitute.

Yet this crisis has been largely out of sight and mind, a festering sore on the landscape which rarely figures on any political agenda. That is because these non-farming country types are an undemonstrative lot, with little lobbying clout, bloodied, bowed and beaten.

Nothing has matched the rapid decline of the mining industry and the disappear ance of more than 160 collieries - certainly not the run-down of farming, bad as it has been.

Farming accounts for just 1.5% of Britain's workforce overall. Even in the shires, it is barely more than 4%. Yet, inexplicably, farming still wields a degree of power and influence out of all proportion to its economic standing.

Now that the well-funded Countryside Alliance - otherwise known as the country sports lobby - has widened its net to embrace agricultural concerns, we can expect an even louder chorus claiming that this government (never the last one) is presiding over some mythical destruction of rural traditions and jobs.

Listening to the apocalyptic vision painted at the annual meeting of the National Farmers' Union, and the genuine cries of hardship, you would think that farming was - at last - being forced to face the reality of the market place like every other industry.

Hardly. In the UK, farmers, now pressing Mr Blair for even more government aid - are currently subsidised to the tune of around £5bn annually, with the barley barons alone getting more than £1bn. Indeed, two years ago it was revealed that 15 big farming businesses could each depend on annual cheques from the taxpayer of £500,000 apiece to compensate them for subsidy cuts in the early 90s; a further five got a handy £1m each.

Compare this feather- bedding to the crisis on Tony Blair's doorstep. His Sedgefield constituency has been successfully diversifying away from coal - but now the wives of the former pitmen are losing their jobs as another industry, meant to take up the slack from the contraction of mining, goes to the wall.

We hear little about the run-down of the textile industry, often located in those old coalfield areas near the countryside. Yet between 1998 and 1999, 41,000 jobs were lost in the UK - and that is before further redundancies, caused by Marks & Spencer withdrawing contracts in favour of overseas manufacturers, begin to bite.

Barry Morris, general secretary of the Knitwear, Footwear and Apparel Trades Union, says: "We want to know why farming warrants billions in subsidies when our industry gets barely a mention." He sees job losses now running at an "unprecedented scale" of 750 a week. But like steel, and coal before it, the textile industry has to survive in the harsh, and of ten unfair reality of the global market.

The prime minister knows this only too well. Hundreds of his own constituents have lost their jobs over the past year or so; scores more will soon head for the dole when two clothing factories in Peterlee new town, just over his constituency border, close with the loss of a further 800.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and fellow north-east MP, is doing his best to stem the tide with a textile task force designed to preserve as many of the in dustry's remaining 290,000 jobs as possible. But, of course, he can never muster (even if EU rules allowed) anything like the support going to farming.

So Blair is standing firm. Rightly. For the government's own countryside agency is telling him that while sectors of farming are in great difficulty, there is certainly no countryside crisis. On the contrary, twice as many jobs are now being created in rural areas as in cities.

The decline in agriculture is being matched by a big population drift from conurbations to country towns. Industries, from cottage enterprises to tourism and hi-tech are being created.

Indeed, the rush to the countryside, home to a fifth (9.3m) of the English population alone, looks like accelerating at such a pace that the government now faces the challenge of repopulating cities. It also, urgently, has to address the more deep-seated problems caused by the collapse of coal.

John Prescott realises that Britain's old mining communities need rescuing, which is why he launched a special task force in an attempt to bring them some hope. In South Yorkshire, where the collapse has devastated townships, incomes are now among the lowest in the European Union. The county has been granted an £800m, six-year EU programme designed to create new businesses.

There is one problem. The government has to find another £8m in "matching aid" to release this Euro cash - modest when you consider the £5bn annually going into farming. Unbelievably, it is having difficulty finding the money.

webTitle: Head down the Park, the Street and the Lane for treble

fields.headline: Head down the Park, the Street and the Lane for treble
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man who knows the quickest route between Ascot and Uttoxeter, thinks he may have spotted a tasty treble this weekend
fields.trailText: There's an extremely tasty away-win treble lurking among Saturday's Premiership fixtures. It may not be the one I'm about to recommend - but there appears to be a strong case for supporting the three sides set to visit Pride Park, Filbert Street and White Hart Lane.
fields.body:
There's an extremely tasty away-win treble lurking among Saturday's Premiership fixtures. It may not be the one I'm about to recommend - but there appears to be a strong case for supporting the three sides set to visit Pride Park, Filbert Street and White Hart Lane.

First to the crucial relegation fixture at Derby, where Sheffield Wednesday will hope for a win on the back of the massive improvement in their game. Despite going down on Wednesday night to a Teddy Sheringham speciality - the nick-of-time winner - Danny Wilson's men looked excellent in defence. That display was, at least, encouraging. But not enough on its own to merit an investment.

So forget the Gillingham Cup defeat and look instead to their London defeat of Spurs by a single goal to nothing. Bear in mind also the fact that Jim Smith's men are weathering the worst recent home sequence in the Premiership - their last six have included a straight run of four losses. Make no mistake, the game will be a cruncher but Ladbrokes' 3-1 about the Yorkshire side returning home in triumph looks more than generous.

Middlesbrough will line up against Leicester confident in the knowledge that their last two league visits to Filbert Street have yielded two wins. They will also take heart from the fact that, were it not for Juninho's penalty miss, they'd have more than likely turned over Manchester United last week.

That Old Trafford outing, coupled with a rock-solid draw at Anfield two weeks back, should leave Bryan Robson's men primed to exploit a Leicester City run ragged by cup exploits and riddled with injury. In fact, if Martin O'Neill pulls this one off he'll arouse suspicions that his remaining players are not human, but in fact a highly durable brand of cyborg. Boro will miss Brian Deane, who is still struggling with a rib injury, but should nevertheless be backed at a best priced 5-2 - or 12-5 at Ladbrokes, the best price for this particular treble.

The final leg should fall into place at White Hart Lane where Chelsea have not been defeated in their last 11 visits. Sunday's FA Cup win over Leicester on Sunday extended their unbeaten run to ten games and reminded the world at large that George Weah has been allocated more skill than is strictly fair. On Saturday, expect him drag George Graham's defenders out of position leaving Chris 'missed again' Sutton enough room to open the scoring. You can get 9-1 from bluesq.com

John Scales should return in time for this derby, which Spurs lost by five clear goals two seasons ago, but Les Ferdinand is likely to sit it out. He was omitted from the reserve team that played Southampton earlier this week and is likely to be sidelined for a further fortnight.

Chelsea, on the other hand, welcome Frank Leboeuf back to the fold after his absence from Sunday's cup tie with Leicester. History and current form both point to the visitors, who have been priced at 6-4 with Ladbrokes.

Recommended treble
Derby v Sheffield Wednesday - away win
Leicester v Middlesbrough - away win
Tottenham v Chelsea - away win

webTitle: 'The critics don't like my movie? Big deal'

fields.headline: 'The critics don't like my movie? Big deal'
fields.standfirst: Scott Hicks won seven Oscar nominations and a Hollywood career with his film Shine. But that didn't stop the sniping at his latest effort. He talks to Stephen Moss
fields.trailText: Scott Hicks won seven Oscar nominations and a Hollywood career with his film Shine. But that didn't stop the sniping at his latest effort. He talks to Stephen Moss
fields.body:
There are three types of movie director: the embarrassing ones who send you to sleep; the controlled ones who trot out the same speech to anyone who questions them; and the interesting ones who actually think before they talk.

Fortunately, Scott Hicks falls into the last camp: he is warm, engaging, open and honest. How on earth does he survive in Hollywood?

Hicks visited London last month to talk about his new movie, Snow Falling on Cedars (pictured), based on David Guterson's best-selling novel. He was planning to buy a few first editions and pay a visit to explorer Sir Wilfred Thesiger, one of his heroes. Hicks is a director with a hinterland - and a large and exotic one at that.

Hicks is the Australian documentary film-maker who sprang to international prominence in 1995 with Shine, which told the story of pianist David Helfgott. It was nominated for seven Oscars, with Geoffrey Rush winning best actor. Hicks is still in touch with Helfgott and his wife, Gillian, and they met up again recently in Australia. "They realise that the film transformed their lives," says Hicks, "and I'm aware that they allowed me to do the film and that it's transformed my life."

Transformed, indeed. Hicks spent a decade developing Shine. He had seen Helfgott at a concert in Adelaide - rocking, talking incessantly to himself but "transporting the room", and immediately wanted to know more. "It took 10 years to get the movie made, but it was simply an idea that would never let go. I was making documentaries to earn a living, but in between them my passion was to make that movie."

Raising the money - all $4m of it - was tricky, but the movie was an instant hit at the Sundance film festival, eventually grossed more than $100m and made Hicks a hot property in Hollywood. "Suddenly I was bombarded with scripts and ideas. I said I'd read this wonderful book, Snow Falling on Cedars, and started to have discussions with Universal, who had optioned it. Ron Bass was slated to write it, but he's a very busy writer and it took more than a year before the screenplay came in. During that year I got hundreds of offers but nothing quite measured up to this. Finally, about a week after the Oscars in 1997 - which was the end of that glorious ride with Shine - in came an offer from Universal to direct."

Hicks is 46, long-haired, a Holly wood outsider who chose not to relocate to the US after Shine's success . (He lives in Adelaide with his wife and two children.) Moving from that carefully nurtured, small-budget movie to the world of big studios and megabucks could have been a nightmare. So? "I took a decision very early on that I was not going to let the size of the juggernaut intimidate me. It was there to help me make a better film.

"One of the first choices I made was the producers - Kathy Kennedy and Frank Marshall. I wanted producers who not only had an extraordinary track record but who would allow me to make the film I wanted to make, knew how to communicate with the studio and would keep people out of my way. I knew I was making an unusual film for a big- studio picture."

Snow Falling on Cedars is unusual because it tells a complicated, multi-layered story largely through flashbacks. The setting is a courtroom where a Japanese-American man is on trial for murder, but there is no attempt - in book or film - at a plot-driven courtroom drama. The film aims to capture the poetry of Guterson's novel and let the story unfold through the interconnecting memories of the people who come to the witness stand. "It's more tone poem than thriller," wrote one American critic. It's a fair point: the 127-minute span feels long; the film, shot over 70 days on islands off America's north-western coast, is too self-consciously beautiful; the soaring cellos that underscore the movie's emotional high spots too plangent. There is bags of atmosphere but a lack of narrative tension; the relaxed story-telling of a book is difficult - in this case, perhaps, dangerous - to reproduce in a film.

Hicks answers these charges fluently and with no hint of rancour. He is so articulate and reasonable - "What you see is what you get, for good or ill; that's what I wanted to make" - that I feel guilty for not liking the movie more. "This book has a readership that is extremely possessive about it," he says, "and I felt that it was important to try and cleave as close as possible to the feeling of the novel. The atmosphere, which is so densely detailed and descriptive, seemed important to me, and an enormous amount of effort went into trying to create that feeling for the film.

"To me, the novel is a kind of discourse on memory and I thought this is something cinema is really well equipped to do. I felt there was a way to deal with these three or four different stories that are happening simultaneously by working them through people's memories. It's not a courtroom drama: there is a trial, yes, but the courtroom is, in a sense, a springboard into people's memories. In court, you get into the witness box and you're asked to remember.

"It seemed important it was not just one point of view. I felt there were passages in the film that demanded to be told from the point of view of the participants, particularly the Japanese-American scenes. I reject the notion that you can only tell a story by following one individual's journey."

But isn't it just a little slow? "It depends on the willingness of an audience to allow themselves to be enveloped in a world. As a film-maker, if you draw the audience in, allow them to be enveloped in another world where they forget they are in the cinema, then you've succeeded.

"The response I've got from people who really love the film is that it is like being in a trance, and you will find out everything you need to know by the end. If you're impatient and you go, 'OK give it up - what's the plot, what's the story?', then you're challenging the movie and you probably won't get it."

The movie didn't, I suggest, please many US critics. "We had a mixture from the absolute rave to the reverse. It's a shame they can't see films with real audiences so they could see the emotional response ordinary people have for this film. It's working in Kansas, in regional towns in Illinois.

"If the critics in New York find it doesn't meet certain intellectual criteria for them, well, big deal. It's ironic that, in a world where critics have been bemoaning Hollywood's lack of content and attacking the obsession with trivial, blow-'em-up movies, in the past year you've had this rich array [of thoughtful films] and some of those same critics have attacked them."

fields.headline: Rooms with a view
fields.standfirst: The housing crisis is not just an urban phenomenon
fields.trailText:
There are plenty of delightful places to live in rural Britain, as anyone 
knows who has flicked the pages of Country Life magazine. But it is a bitter 
irony of modern rural life that many of those born and brought up in the 
countryside can least afford to live there.
fields.body:
There are plenty of delightful places to live in rural Britain, as anyone knows who has flicked the pages of Country Life magazine. But it is a bitter irony of modern rural life that many of those born and brought up in the countryside can least afford to live there.

Far from being a distinctively urban phenomenon, homelessness is a widespread and spreading scourge in the countryside. And although the extent and the causes of it vary hugely from region to region, there are factors common to all:

  • A surge of demand by city-dwellers for a permanent or 'weekend' home in the country has driven up prices and rents.
  • A desperate lack of development land in the more sought-after areas has further boosted the value of existing properties.
  • Incomes from rural employment, especially but not exclusively agriculture, are well below the national average.
  • The continuing system of 'tied' dwellings, in which accommodation is part of a low-wage employment package, means that when the job goes or the worker retires, he or she is without a home or the means to acquire one.

    Quantifying the problem is as difficult as defining it. To some people, the countryside means remoteness, even wildness. To others, it is embodied in village greens and quaint cottages. The campaigning group Action With Communities in Rural England takes the view that all non-urban areas are by definition rural. By that definition, there are 11m people living today in rural England and, shockingly, an estimated 25% of them live below the official poverty line.

    The Countryside Alliance, noted more for its defence of bloodsports than its support of the rural poor, estimates that rural house prices are now 10-15% higher than the national average. (That again disguises huge regional disparities, but it is indisputably true that a character-cottage in a commuter village is worth a good deal more than a suburban house of equivalent size in the city).

    The issue of rural housing is bedevilled by conflicting interests. The demand for new affordable homes is often most bitterly resisted by newcomers to an area who feel that 'their' peace and tranquillity is threatened. (The same sort of people regularly incur the scorn of country folk by complaining that farming is smelly, or noisy, or both).

    With local authorities no longer building homes, much of the miserably inadequate new stock is being provided by housing associations and, of course, by private builders happy to make a buck from the craze for country dwelling. Both are regularly thwarted by Green Belt regulations and other planning requirements.

    The CPRE (the Campaign for the Protection of Rural England) strongly supports the planning laws, and believes they are under threat, especially in the crowded south-east, where the government wants 1.1m new homes by 2016. That target, says CPRE assistant director Tony Burton, implies a nightmare future of sprawl and congestion, in a region already at bursting point. "Building over one million homes would shatter the Green Belt, intrude on land protected for its landscape or wildlife value, and lose valuable farmland," he says.

    Many campaigners, for the homeless as well as for the countryside, are outraged that little is being done to regenerate the 560 square kilometres - the government's own figure, recorded in last year's Land Use Database - of decayed urban land. Those 'brownfield' areas could sprout up to three-quarters of a million new homes, and leave huge swathes of countrside free to sprout more natural crops.

    Countryside Alliance
    Economic and Social Research Council (on demographic change in Britain)
    Shelter (on the need for social housing)
    Shelter (on homelessness in Britain)
    The National Housing Federation
    The Joseph Rowntree Foundation
    The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions

fields.headline: Portillo transforms Tories' economic outlook
fields.standfirst: 'The critical point is that Michael has made a decision' - Conservative central office
fields.trailText: New shadow chancellor Michael Portillo began a buccaneering first day in the office by renouncing the Tories' opposition to the minimum wage and an independent Bank of England.
fields.body:
New shadow chancellor Michael Portillo began a buccaneering first day in the office by renouncing the Tories' opposition to the minimum wage and an independent Bank of England.

Within minutes of returning to the Commons despatch box, Mr Portillo overhauled Conservative economic policy and startled many Tory MPs in the chamber by promising to "respect the independence of the Bank of England and legislate to enhance that independence and create more accountability of the bank to parliament."

He also pledged that "the next Conservative government will not repeal the national minimum wage", which the Tories were implacably opposed to when Labour piloted the legislation through parliament in 1998.

A Conservative party spokesman said that the decisions were Mr Portillo's own work, following his surprise promotion in William Hague's reshuffle this week.

"The critical point is that Michael has come in and taken a look at these two issues and he has seen there was a clear direction in which our policy was moving and made a decision," he said.

Labour MPs who had earlier heckled Mr Portillo's return to frontline politics waved their Commons order papers in delight at the news.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, welcomed Mr Portillo's "conversion" of the Tory party to Labour policy and wished him well in trying to get his party to adopt "a sensible economic policy".

Mr Portillo's surprising shift amounts to a substantial overhaul of the party's economic policy. Since Labour came to power, two key Conservative lines of attack centred chancellor Gordon Brown's decision to hand over interest rate powers to the Bank and imposing the "burden" of the minimum wage on businesses.

In a later statement, Mr Portillo confirmed the Conservatives would also seek to "enhance" the Bank's independence, while increasing its accountability to parliament.

"Our aim will be to reassure markets that monetary decisions will not be taken for political reasons; and also to establish more clearly the independence of the committee's members," the shadow chancellor announced.

"Their appointments will be for longer. The committee will be made more accountable to parliament. Committee appointments will be confirmed by parliament. A parliamentary committee will have oversight of the MPC's work."

Mr Portillo added that the Tories had little to fear from the minimum wage "at the modest level at which it has been set by the government."

"The minimum wage has caused less damage to employment than we feared. We remain concerned at the compliance costs for business, and will seek to improve its administration."

Tory Treasury spokesman Oliver Letwin caught the reforming mood in the party, disclosing that changes to the working families tax credit were also being considered.

Liberal Democrat economics spokesman Matthew Taylor claimed Mr Portillo's announcement was an "extraordinary admission" that the Conservatives were out of step with mainstream Britain.

Mr Taylor said: "The Conservatives no longer know what they believe in. They are flailing about to find some way back from political oblivion.

"Michael Portillo has ripped up William Hague's economic strategy and replaced it with his alternative Conservative manifesto. The battle for the Conservative leadership has already begun."

TUC general secretary John Monks said: "The Conservative party has clearly caught up with the public's mood as the minimum wage is extremely popular."

Transport and General Workers Union general secretary Bill Morris called on the government to increase the £3.60 an hour level of the minimum wage.

"It is particularly sad that now the Tories have accepted the arguments for a national minimum wage, the government seems happy to let it wither on the vine," he said.

webTitle: The Leicester Eight, The Ivory Coast 22 and The Islington Hundred

fields.headline: The Leicester Eight, The Ivory Coast 22 and The Islington Hundred
fields.trailText: JUST THE TICKET (FOR PEOPLE WHO LIKE MISCONDUCT ENQUIRIES)
fields.body:
JUST THE TICKET (FOR PEOPLE WHO LIKE MISCONDUCT ENQUIRIES)

Leicester City started the week by getting themselves knocked out of the FA Cup. They then suffered three days of pain as they were harangued for being boring (in the sort of articles you read for about two paragraphs before drifting off into a daydream about paint drying). So you'd think that winning a place in the Worthington Cup final would represent a happy end to a difficult week for the club. Well it did, but the relief didn't last long.

This morning, eight Leicester players and officials were charged with misconduct as part of the FA's fun investigation into the distribution of tickets for last year's Worthington Cup final, where there was a bit of bother between Leicester and Spurs fans in a supposedly segregated section. Steve Guppy, Neil Lennon, Graham Fenton, Arnar Gunnlaugsson and Stuart Campbell have all been notified that a rollicking is imminent, and join their team-mates Tony Cottee and Andy Impey who have already been charged.

The Foxes' chief scout Jim Melrose, academy director David Nish and physio Ian Andrews will also be up before the beak at Filbert Street on March 15. But the Fiver doesn't think that will be an end to it. "We must stress that it is an on-going investigation," FA spokesman Steve Double added. "There are still some matters that we want to clear up to our satisfaction." And the Leicester players are, according to a club spokesman, "extremely angry", "taking independent legal advice" and "will be protesting their innocence most strongly at the inquiry".

At least there's been some good news for Leicester - the 25 players who were previously charged with failing to assist the FA in their inquiry have been let off the hook. However, these charges were withdrawn after "further co-operation and information" - possibly, maybe and perhaps the catalyst for the charges - so this is very much what you could call a 'swings and roundabouts' situation.

* The Football League have clamped down on the allocation of tickets for this year's Worthington Cup final. Players were previously entitled to 75 tickets each and club directors were allowed 100. But now only 25 tickets will be given per person.

NOT IN THE ARMY NOW

Rather than demanding the resignation of the national coach, allowing fans to burn effigies of star players, or watching the media ridicule the manager with a clever turnip photo-montage, the Ivory Coast's military government responded to their team's exit from the African Nations Cup by taking the modest precautionary step of stripping their players of passports and phones and sending them to army camp.

It's the sort of strategic team-building exercise that Kelvin Koogan can only wish he dreamt up. But in this instance, international outrage ensued. Inter Milan complained to Fifa, while Celtic were reported to be "trying to contact Ivory Coast football association" about the safety of their defender Olivier Tebily with the help of a spokesperson's immaculate Glaswegian West-African French. It must have worked a treat because, according to Le Jour newspaper, the Ivory Coast 22 were freed last night to chortle at each other's passport photos, chat on their mobiles, and scarper back to their European clubs before the wrath of their nation's fans descended on them.

The fans duly got down to business. Even though they notched up a respectable win, draw and defeat and unluckily dropped out of the "group of death" on goal difference, supporters' chief Francois Amichia complained that "the Ivory Coast has a high place in African sports, and it is not right to go out in the first round". It couldn't happen here though, eh?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'll certainly be okay for the European Championships with England. I can't believe people would think anything different." - Michael Owen tries his hand at incredulity.

£100M WELL SPENT

If you were Arsenal and you had £100m to spend, what would you do? Well, obviously, you'd buy two-and-a-half David Beckhams. But just imagine that option wasn't available, wouldn't you want to build a "hotel and casino, conference suite, shopping mall, night club and restaurant" complex? Of course you would. After all, if it's good enough for Chelsea...

According to a draft planning brief drawn up by Islington council, the Gunners planned new home - half-a-mile away from Highbury in Drayton Park - will be a Chelsea Village style "associated development". Or, as an irate local resident put it, "a major entertainment seven-days-a-week complex". But while 100 such residents turned up to complain about the plans at a meeting of the Islington Stadium Communities Alliance last night (typical bloody Islington), the council are fully behind the plans.

As far as the Fiver is concerned, the more gimmicky football-related complexes that get built the better. Particularly if they include such delights as the Paul Merson casino, Hotel Oleg Luzhny, or even the Patrick Vieira conference facilities ("for when words speak louder than actions"). But we do have one small worry; will there be any room for the pitch?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Sunderland have made a £3m double bid to sign Bologna defenders Massimo Paganin and Nicola Boselli.

Spurs have denied reports that Ipswich striker David Johnson is heading to White Hart Lane for £5m.

Manchester City are interested in Lee Dixon, despite the fact the full-back has been offered a new one-year contract at Arsenal.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Emile Heskey has pledged to see out his contract at Leicester City. The England international signed an extension to his current deal earlier in the season to keep him at Filbert Street until the summer of 2001. "Do I intend to honour that contract?" he said today, "Yes. I signed my contract; I'm here and that's what I intend to do."

Denis Smith has become manager of Oxford United for the second time. Smith previously held the post for five years before leaving in December 1997.

Graham Barber, Paul Durkin and Graham Poll have been invited to attend Uefa's advanced course for international referees. Uriah Rennie will be attending a subsequent course for international newcomers.

Former Everton and Wales goalkeeper Neville Southall has had his week-to-week contract cancelled by Torquay only five days after he made his 700th league appearance at Chester. Southall has been combining his commitments at Plainmoor with a part-time coaching job at Huddersfield.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.25am)

Kuwait. Peru. United Arab Emirates. Three things which make this programme pull up a chair and say, "Yes, I'll spend some quality time here."

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.50am)

Hairy drama and hairy men. Presented by James Richardson.

Channel 5: European Club Football (12.50am)

Celtic and Bayern Munich. All very friendly.

Argentinian Football (2.30am)

Independiente v Racing Club. Again? How many times do they play each other?

Footy Shorts (4am)

This week: Christian Dailly, post-bouffant.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.15am)

Sepp Blatter sings, jokes and tap-dances his way through another star-studded variety show. It's as though Sammy Davis Jr. never died.

Spanish Football (8pm, 1am SS2)

Sun, sand and sangria! Not for the players, obviously. Nor, in all probability, for you.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm)

McCaff still can't get a corporate sponsor. But the old lady next door has promised him 10p every time he interrupts a caller to shout "Hey, big man!" at Alan McInally.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm and 11.30pm SS1)

Jason McAteer on his favourite lines from King Lear.

British Eurosport: Football (6pm)

Some of the African Nations Cup.

Football (10.30pm)

Some more of it.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)

In no way a rest home for people who failed to hold down a regular part in Brookside.

NOT IN THE ARMY NOW Rather than demanding the resignation of the national coach, allowing fans to burn effigies of star players, or watching the media ridicule the manager with a clever turnip photo-montage, the Ivory Coast's military government responded to their team's exit from the African Nations Cup by taking the modest precautionary step of stripping their players of passports and phones and sending them to army camp. It's the sort of strategic team-building exercise that Kelvin Koogan can only wish he dreamt up. But in this instance, international outrage ensued. Inter Milan complained to Fifa, while Celtic were reported to be "trying to contact Ivory Coast football association" about the safety of their defender Olivier Tebily with the help of a spokesperson's immaculate Glaswegian West-African French. It must have worked a treat because, according to Le Jour newspaper, the Ivory Coast 22 were freed last night to chortle at each other's passport photos, chat on their mobiles, and scarper back to their European clubs before the wrath of their nation's fans descended on them. The fans duly got down to business. Even though they notched up a respectable win, draw and defeat and unluckily dropped out of the "group of death" on goal difference, supporters' chief Francois Amichia complained that "the Ivory Coast has a high place in African sports, and it is not right to go out in the first round". It couldn't happen here though, eh? QUOTE OF THE DAY "I'll certainly be okay for the European Championships with England. I can't believe people would think anything different." - Michael Owen tries his hand at incredulity. £100M WELL SPENT If you were Arsenal and you had £100m to spend, what would you do? Well, obviously, you'd buy two-and-a-half David Beckhams. But just imagine that option wasn't available, wouldn't you want to build a "hotel and casino, conference suite, shopping mall, night club and restaurant" complex? Of course you would. After all, if it's good enough for Chelsea... According to a draft planning brief drawn up by Islington council, the Gunners planned new home - half-a-mile away from Highbury in Drayton Park - will be a Chelsea Village style "associated development". Or, as an irate local resident put it, "a major entertainment seven-days-a-week complex". But while 100 such residents turned up to complain about the plans at a meeting of the Islington Stadium Communities Alliance last night (typical bloody Islington), the council are fully behind the plans. As far as the Fiver is concerned, the more gimmicky football-related complexes that get built the better. Particularly if they include such delights as the Paul Merson casino, Hotel Oleg Luzhny, or even the Patrick Vieira conference facilities ("for when words speak louder than actions"). But we do have one small worry; will there be any room for the pitch? THE RUMOUR MILL Sunderland have made a £3m double bid to sign Bologna defenders Massimo Paganin and Nicola Boselli. Spurs have denied reports that Ipswich striker David Johnson is heading to White Hart Lane for £5m. Manchester City are interested in Lee Dixon, despite the fact the full-back has been offered a new one-year contract at Arsenal. NEWS IN BRIEF Emile Heskey has pledged to see out his contract at Leicester City. The England international signed an extension to his current deal earlier in the season to keep him at Filbert Street until the summer of 2001. "Do I intend to honour that contract?" he said today, "Yes. I signed my contract; I'm here and that's what I intend to do." Denis Smith has become manager of Oxford United for the second time. Smith previously held the post for five years before leaving in December 1997. Graham Barber, Paul Durkin and Graham Poll have been invited to attend Uefa's advanced course for international referees. Uriah Rennie will be attending a subsequent course for international newcomers. Former Everton and Wales goalkeeper Neville Southall has had his week-to-week contract cancelled by Torquay only five days after he made his 700th league appearance at Chester. Southall has been combining his commitments at Plainmoor with a part-time coaching job at Huddersfield. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: World Football (2.25am) Kuwait. Peru. United Arab Emirates. Three things which make this programme pull up a chair and say, "Yes, I'll spend some quality time here." Channel 4: Football Italia (2.50am) Hairy drama and hairy men. Presented by James Richardson. Channel 5: European Club Football (12.50am) Celtic and Bayern Munich. All very friendly. Argentinian Football (2.30am) Independiente v Racing Club. Again? How many times do they play each other? Footy Shorts (4am) This week: Christian Dailly, post-bouffant. Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.15am) Sepp Blatter sings, jokes and tap-dances his way through another star-studded variety show. It's as though Sammy Davis Jr. never died. Spanish Football (8pm, 1am SS2) Sun, sand and sangria! Not for the players, obviously. Nor, in all probability, for you. You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm) McCaff still can't get a corporate sponsor. But the old lady next door has promised him 10p every time he interrupts a caller to shout "Hey, big man!" at Alan McInally. Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm and 11.30pm SS1) Jason McAteer on his favourite lines from King Lear. British Eurosport: Football (6pm) Some of the African Nations Cup. Football (10.30pm) Some more of it. Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm) In no way a rest home for people who failed to hold down a regular part in Brookside.

fields.headline: How much can I pay for . . .
fields.trailText: A ladies' tool kit
fields.body:
A ladies' tool kit

Oh, how very sweet and thoughtful. Connolly, the shop that does the posh driving equipment - you know, gloves and maps and all that lovely butch stuff - have also put together a "Ladies' Tool Kit".

Looking forward to my very own extra-light screwdriver and a wide range of pretty little drill bits, I was slightly disappointed to find that Connolly's idea of the type of tools a lady might need while driving include moisturiser, shampoo (isn't this forbidden in the highway driving code?) and perfume. But, never one to be down for long, I cheered up when I realised it was all by Jo Malone, in lovely soft leather. And only £2,000! I must call Daddy straight away. Tel: 0171-235 3883.

Bibi van der Zee

fields.headline: Driven to action
fields.standfirst: The days of outrageous vehicle prices are numbered. But if you can't wait for the government to break the car firms' stranglehold,  Sally Kinnes  shows how to beat the rip-offs and save yourself thousands of pounds
fields.trailText: The days of outrageous vehicle prices are numbered. But if you can't wait for the government to break the car firms' stranglehold, Sally Kinnes shows how to beat the rip-offs and save yourself thousands of pounds
fields.body:
Want to buy a new car? Don't, at least not until April, or whenever the government decides what to do about the much publicised rip-off of British car retailing.

"We're telling people to wait," says Phil Evans, senior policy adviser at the Consumers' Association (CA). "Most people are expecting manufacturers will bring their prices down."

They have certainly been charging over the odds for long enough. If you manufactured highly desirable products, controlled who sold them, set the price they were sold at and refused to supply them to any retailer who tried to discount your price, you would be in court before you cashed your first cheque.

Unless, of course, the products were cars. Throughout Europe, they have block exemption from the usual rules of competition, and the manufacturers, who have most to gain from the system, say a jolly good thing too. Almost everyone else says rubbish.

Car retailing in Britain is a rip-off. The CA has been saying so for years, and now it seems the competition commission agrees. Last Monday, the commission delivered its report on the industry to the government, though it must have needed a pantechnicon to get it there. It is one of the longest and most complex reports it has ever produced.

The report is unlikely to be published for another three months, but it is widely believed to condemn the current practice by which manufacturers control price and supply through the franchised dealer network - and help keep prices much higher than they are in Europe.

"Manufacturers can't actually fix prices," says Andrew McIlwraith, editor of the CA's Which? Car guide. "But they control the wholesale price and set the list price, or recommended retail price. That gives the dealers no room for manoeuvre."

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), which has huge political clout, is vigorously opposed to any change. It blames the strong pound for high prices, and says the dealer network is essential for expert servicing. The CA disagrees. "There is a need for service support, but why should that have anything to do with sales," says McIlwraith. "And if the fluctuation in exchange rates made any difference, you would expect prices to go up as well as down. They don't."

It's now up to the department of trade and industry to decide whether or not to act on the competition commission's report. "If the government fails the consumer on this, it will be the end of its claim to be the friend of Mondeo man," says Evans, adding that the European block exemption comes up for renewal in 2002. "We want to see the government campaign to end it".

In the meantime, there are a number of things the DTI could do. "It could give dealers room to negotiate with the manufacturers on prices, let them negotiate their own finance packages, and say that any discount given to fleet buyers [currently about 40%] should be given to the retailers as well," says Evans.

If you are desperate to change your car before April, you could buy second-hand. "Prices are the cheapest they have been for a long time, and will probably start to go up again," says Evans. But if you have your heart set on a new one, there are a growing number of ways to get around the dealer network. Here are some of the best.

Nearly new/preregistered

If you want to save 20-30% on what is effectively a brand new car, ask your dealer about "nearly new" or preregistered cars. This loophole is created by the way the industry massages sales figures. "To maintain the fiction that the industry is doing all right, a manufacturer registers a car to itself or its dealers," says Evans. "A manufacturer may claim to have sold 50,000 cars when 40,000 are sitting on an airfield somewhere. Mitsubishi estimates there are 500,000 preregistered cars in the UK."

Make sure you aren't charged the full list price - you can recognise a preregistered car by the simple fact that it will already have licence plates.

P&O Stena

Cars are certainly cheaper in Europe, but if you try to import them yourself, you can drown in the paperwork. This week, P&O Stena announced a scheme whereby it does the hard work and delivers your import, ready to drive, to your front door. P&O says customers will also save 8-18%.

"People ask what the downside is, and that could be a long wait - up to 14 weeks or more," says Chris Laming of P&O. "But there is huge public interest." In the first 24 hours, the company had 1,500 enquiries and 100 firm orders. The makes sold will be BMW, Jaguar, Land Rover (all models), Lexus (all models), Mercedes, Peugeot, Renault, Toyota and VW; and don't worry, like those sold online (see below) they're all right-hand drives. Buyers will pay a £10 registration fee and a 10%-20% deposit. Telephone 0870 600 0613.

Internet

As if manufacturers didn't have enough to worry about, there is now a net threat. Totalise (www.totalise. net), an internet service provider (ISP), is importing cars through its e-commerce wing, Eurekar, and says it has done £1.5m of business in the past two months.

"We offer a safe and easy way to import cars," says its sales manager, Charles Tyrer. "Customers pay into something similar to a client account, so even if we went bust they would get their money back. They pay in sterling, but the exchange rate on the day they order is guaranteed."

Prices are 20-40% below the UK cost and a special promotion, offering an amazing £14,600 saving on Range Rovers, is claimed as the biggest saving of any vehicle importer. Cars are delivered to your door Green Flag-inspected and with road tax and a three-year warranty. A hefty deposit is required (15-30%), but it is reduced to £250 if you sign up to the company's finance package.

Because many people are still nervous of European imports, Totalise Eurekar has also just launched a service offering cars it has bought in bulk from UK dealers. Waiting time is seven days; savings are 10%.

From February 16, www.one swoop.com's site will offer a similar service, and in the spring, Richard Branson joins the fun (www.virgin. com/cars/). Last November, Vauxhall became the first motor manufacturer to sell a range of its cars over the net, offering savings of around £1,000 (www.vauxhall.co.uk).

If you want to ensure your online retailer is doing things right, the CA's site at www.which.net/campaigns/ gives chapter and verse. The CA is also planning its own European import scheme.
