fields.headline: Jörg Haider's coalition declaration
fields.standfirst: The official English text of "Responsibility for Austria - A Future in the Heart of Europe" a declaration signed by conservative leader Wolfgang Schuessel and far-right Freedom party leader Jörg Haider
fields.trailText: The Federal government reaffirms its unswerving adherence to the spiritual and moral values which are the common heritage of the peoples of Europe and the true source of individual freedom, political liberty and the rule of law, principles which form the basis of all genuine democracy.
fields.body:
The Federal government reaffirms its unswerving adherence to the spiritual and moral values which are the common heritage of the peoples of Europe and the true source of individual freedom, political liberty and the rule of law, principles which form the basis of all genuine democracy.

The Federal government stands for respect, tolerance and understanding for all human beings irrespective of their origin, religion or "weltanschauung" [outlook on the world]. It condemns and actively combats any form of discrimination, intolerance and demagoguery in all areas. It strives for a society imbued with the spirit of humanism and tolerance towards the members of all social groups.

The Federal government works for an Austria in which xenophobia, anti-Semitism and racism have no place. It will take vigorous steps to counter every way of thinking which seeks to denigrate human beings, will actively combat the dissemination of such ideas and is committed to full respect for the rights and fundamental freedoms of people of any nationality - irrespective of the reason for their stay in Austria. It acknowledges its special responsibility as regards the respectful treatment of ethnic and religious minorities.

The Federal government supports the Charter of European Political Parties for a Non-Racist Society and commits itself to work for the exemplary realisation of its fundamental principles in Austria.

The Federal government is committed to the protection and promotion of human rights as well as to their unconditional implementation at national and international level. This also makes an important contribution to the prevention of wars and domestic conflicts which result in violations of the rights of people, who may find themselves displaced or even forced to leave their home country.

The Federal government is committed to the principles of pluralistic democracy and the rule of law common to all members of the European Union, which are also anchored in the Austrian constitution and form the precondition for membership in the Council of Europe. The rights and freedoms enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights, which are constitutionally guaranteed in Austria, are a clear expression of this commitment.

The Federal government is committed to the European peace project. Co-operation between the coalition parties is based on a commitment to Austria's membership in the European Union. The Federal government is bound by those principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, and the rule of law, which under Article 6 of the Treaty of the European Union are common to all member states of the European Union. Austria's future, too, lies in the deepening of integration and the enlargement of the Union. Austria's history and geopolitical situation represent a special responsibility to further the process of integration and to anchor the European idea even more firmly in everyday life. The Transatlantic Partnership will have a special significance in order to assure peace and stability during the 21st century.

The European Union as a community of values corresponds to a definite concept for the future development of European integration. This includes, in particular, work on the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Austria supports further work towards combating all forms of discrimination according to Article 13 of the EU Treaty.

A living culture of democracy and the rule of law demands a relationship between state and citizens that creates new areas of freedom and responsibility for the individual. In a modern efficient state there are functions which can best be carried out by the individual or by non-state actors.

The Federal government, however, is committed with all emphasis to the maintenance in solidarity of the state welfare services for every citizen who needs state help and support. This applies especially to those people who are unable to take advantage of the opportunities induced by modernisation which are increasingly dominating our lives.

The principle of solidarity also means that consideration must be shown towards the needs and expectations of future generations in order to ensure fair chances for all members of society and their plans for the future.

The Federal government desires to strengthen Austria's position as a performance and competition orientated economic location. That is the basis for securing existing employment, creating new jobs and ensuring prosperity in our country. Austria's accession to the European Union and an assured participation in the European Monetary Union were and remain important preconditions for the future of the economy and employment in Austria.

Austria's social partnership has proved itself as an important instrument for the location of industry and jobs in Austria, and has contributed thereby to the maintenance of social peace. The Federal government is committed to comprehensive co-operation with the social partners, but at the same time recommends the necessary readiness to reform the social partnership, for example in respect of the social security structures including the election of representatives of the insured, and strengthening the service character of the social partnership institutions.

The Federal government is aware that the Austrian people must energetically continue to build on their great achievements of the past and develop Austria's strengths still further.

Austria accepts her responsibility arising out of the tragic history of the 20th century and the horrendous crimes of the National Socialist regime. Our country is facing up to the light and dark sides of its past and to the deeds of all Austrians, good and evil, as its responsibility. Nationalism, dictatorship and intolerance brought war, xenophobia, bondage, racism and mass murder. The singularity of the crimes of the Holocaust which are without precedent in history are an exhortation to permanent alertness against all forms of dictatorship and totalitarianism.

The European Union's project for a broad, democratic and prosperous Europe, to which the Federal government is unconditionally committed, is the best guarantee against a repetition of this darkest chapter of Austrian history.

The Federal government is committed to a self-critical scrutiny of the National Socialist past. It will ensure unreserved clarification, exposure of the structures of injustice, and the transmission of this knowledge to coming generations as a warning for the future. As regards the question of forced labour under the National Socialist regime, the Federal government will endeavour to arrive at objective solutions in the light of the intermediate report by the Austrian commission of historians, while having regard to the primary responsibility of the companies concerned.

The government parties are committed to a new form of government and co-operation. They desire to solve problems, deal with challenges and make consistent use of opportunities, because they are committed to Austria's future in Europe. Austria, as a stable and reliable country, will make her contribution in partnership for a peaceful and secure life together in Europe and the world.

webTitle: Catwalk cutback Campbell shuns stress of 'the shows'

fields.headline: Catwalk cutback Campbell shuns stress of 'the shows'
fields.trailText: For 14 years she has graced the catwalks of the world, her name one of the most sought after in Milan, Paris, New York and London. But now, it seems, it has all become too much.
fields.body:
For 14 years she has graced the catwalks of the world, her name one of the most sought after in Milan, Paris, New York and London. But now, it seems, it has all become too much.

Naomi Campbell (pictured right on the catwalk for Fendi in Milan) has decided that she will no longer do "the shows", the gruelling schedule that can require a model to appear in three couture shows a day during a city's fashion week.

Speaking in Australia yesterday at the launch of her new fragrance, Campbell, the model from Streatham, south London, said she was not planning to appear in shows in London or New York this year.

"I'm definitely not doing New York and definitely not doing London. Milan - I'll wait to see what happens," she said.

"I find it really stressful, doing 16 shows and then having to do fittings and dress rehearsals. I'm not saying 'poor me', I just find it very stressful and I want to chill out a bit more, so maybe it's about doing less."

Campbell, 29, said she had held back from the latest couture shows in Paris and was reassessing her workload. "I'm not quite sure if I'm going to continue doing the shows all over the world: I think I'll just pick one out of each country."

Dubbed the "black Bardot" by the haute couture world, exposed recently for its racism, she is the world's most famous black model. She reputedly earns £1m a year and has a reputation for being one of the most difficult models in the business.

The model's lawyers were last night due to represent her in a Canadian court. She has been accused by her assistant of assault. Georgina Galanis claimed that Campbell hit her over the head with a mobile telephone. The model has always denied the charges and promised to fight them with her "bare hands and teeth".

In London yesterday, Campbell's agent, Carole White, said it was true her client would be scaling down her catwalk appearances. "Because she has launched her own brand fragrance - which is why she is in Australia - that has stopped her from doing New York and she's not going to be back in London in time," she said. "She is just not physically able to do it. She is launching in Japan on February 14.

"She won't be doing as many shows again. A model would normally do 16 to 20 shows and she's not going to be doing that again.

"She still models. We are still taking a lot of editorial bookings. If she was available for the shows she would only be doing a selected few. It's a lot of pressure and she doesn't really need it, to do 16 shows back-to-back."

Ms White added: "She can cross the Atlantic three times a week. It's very stressful and it's a lot worse than being a pop star on tour. It's a very heavy schedule.

"She will be in New York for a couple of days, then when she comes back to London she has to fly to Paris then fly to Milan. Then she might have a day off. When she comes back from Australia she goes straight back to Dublin to do a charity show, then she goes to Berlin."

webTitle: Brown left with cake on his face

fields.headline: Brown left with cake on his face
fields.standfirst: National Farmers' Union embarrassed by security lapse that allowed woman to smear chocolate eclair over agriculture minister and flee
fields.trailText: Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, was left with cake on his face yesterday after being attacked by a protester while on stage at a national conference.
fields.body:
Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, was left with cake on his face yesterday after being attacked by a protester while on stage at a national conference.

A woman wielding a chocolate eclair managed to evade security at the National Farmers' Union conference in London and smear it on his face.

The incident happened during a heated confrontation between Mr Brown and delegates.

The protester, Birgit Cunningham, managed to slip away unhindered from the Hilton hotel conference room, which was packed with hundreds of delegates.

She later said she had "just flipped" and wanted to apologise to Mr Brown, but the incident caused severe embarrassment to the National Farmers' Union, whose security arrangements were so easily evaded.

Mr Brown made light of the attack, which happened five days after the Liberal Democrat councillor Andy Pennington was murdered and the MP Nigel Jones injured by a man wielding a sword at the MP's surgery in Cheltenham. Mr Brown said the assault was a silly stunt.

"It was not a samurai sword. It was a chocolate eclair. Although I am not a particularly brave person, I am not frightened of chocolate eclairs."

He dismissed suggestions he needed tighter security. "I bowl around meeting farmers without security all the time. Nothing like this has ever happened. People do get angry and they do shout at me. I do try and talk to them because I understand why people are angry and upset."

Ms Cunningham, 34, an events organiser who has previously helped green campaigners organise anti-GM protests , said: "I stole a media badge. I listened to the speakers and one farmer sounded really desperate. He had lost his whole beef business because of the crisis. I was looking round at all the farmers and they were shaking their heads in despair.

"Then Nick Brown came up and it was clear he was not going to offer more money to help out. He was saying that farmers must learn to diversify and upgrade."

Ms Cunningham, from Kensington, west London, said she "just flipped" and grabbed a £1.40 eclair from her handbag which she had intended to give to a friend. "It just all became an emotional thing. I was in a total trance."

She fled down the back stairs without anyone catching her. "I'm a bit taken aback by what I did. I feel very sorry for Nick Brown and think he is doing the best he can under the circumstances. I would love to chat with him and show him I'm sorry."

But within minutes of the incident, Ms Cunningham had phoned a picture library which had pictures of her posing with strawberries to promote organic food.

Last summer she helped to urge celebrities including Sting, Sadie Frost, Jude Law, Simon and Yasmin LeBon to voice support for an organic picnic in Greenwich, south-east London.

Zac Goldsmith, editor of Ecologist magazine, said he did not see the incident as "particularly objectionable". He said the magazine was considering working with Ms Cunningham to organise a conference on "the real farm crisis" later this year".

William Hague, the opposition leader, later received rapturous applause as he attacked the government for creating "two nations town and countryside". He said: "The rural way of life is under attack from urban values and Islington pressure groups and a metropolitan elite who know nothing about the countryside and care little for the people who live in it."

webTitle: Actor Frost denies being drunk while in Berlin cell

fields.headline: Actor Frost denies being drunk while in Berlin cell
fields.trailText: German police reacted quickly yesterday to rebut claims by the British actor Sadie Frost that she was held in a Berlin police cell for eight hours, issuing a statement saying she had been placed in a "drying-out cell" for her own safety.
fields.body:
German police reacted quickly yesterday to rebut claims by the British actor Sadie Frost that she was held in a Berlin police cell for eight hours, issuing a statement saying she had been placed in a "drying-out cell" for her own safety.

Frost, who appears in the current release Rancid Aluminium, has made an official complaint, alleging that police held her in a cell without food, water or toilet facilities after she was freed from a lift in an apartment block.

Berlin police said Frost was indeed placed in a cell in the early hours and held, but only for four hours, and the cell was a "drying-out cell" where she was placed for her own safety. Their statement said it had become clear Frost was "under the influence of alcohol".

But a spokesman for Frost denied that she had been drunk. He said: "She had been out to a concert with friends, so any claim she was drunk is incorrect."

Frost's ordeal began when she became trapped in a lift in an apartment block where her husband, the actor Jude Law, was staying while filming in Germany. Police and fire crews released her after 30 minutes, then asked to see her passport and identity papers.

Frost was unable to produce her documents and says she told police that they were upstairs in her husband's flat. They allegedly refused to believe her and arrested her instead. She claims she was held in a cell with no food, water or toilet facilities before finally being released without charge.

Frost's spokesman added that, on releasing her from the lift, the police had refused to escort her to the flat to retrieve her papers. "Instead, they handcuffed her, bundled her into a car and held her for eight hours before releasing her without charge."

The police statement gave a slightly different version of events. It read: "Owing to her condition, the woman was unable to make any comprehensible statements as to where she was staying in Berlin or where she wanted to go. She was not known to the residents of the flats. No written indications of a place of residence in Berlin could be found on her person.

"The officers then decided that, for her own safety, the woman should be taken to the nearest drying-out cell at 74 Charlottenburger Chaussee. The doctor on duty there concluded at about 4.20am that the woman's physical condition did not necessitate immediate medical treatment. The doctor also diagnosed substantial influence of alcohol.

"At around 8.10am it was possible to release the woman from police custody."

The statement added that anyone detained in a Berlin police cell could call officers by pressing a button at any time.

The German authorities said that an investigation would be launched into the circumstances surrounding Frost's complaint. The spokesman for Frost said the matter was being dealt with in conjunction with the British consulate.

"Sadie is very shaken by the whole affair, and she feels this was a violation of her," he said. "It's nothing personal against Germans or Germany and she will be going back there again, but next time she will make sure she has her passport and mobile phone on her the whole time."

webTitle: Julia Roberts looks south of the border

fields.headline: Julia Roberts looks south of the border
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts 's interest in the action-comedy The Mexican looks set to rescue a film which days before looked to be dying a slow death in development limbo. The picture had initially been attached to director David (Fight Club) Fincher and actor Brad Pitt , but both recently bailed out of the project. Insiders predict that Roberts's enthusiasm is likely to woo Pitt back on board.
fields.body:
Julia Roberts 's interest in the action-comedy The Mexican looks set to rescue a film which days before looked to be dying a slow death in development limbo. The picture had initially been attached to director David (Fight Club) Fincher and actor Brad Pitt , but both recently bailed out of the project. Insiders predict that Roberts's enthusiasm is likely to woo Pitt back on board.

The Mexican of the title refers to an ancient, cursed pistol that a goofy American criminal sets out to steal. Pitt would play the lead role, and Roberts his nagging girlfriend. Gore Verbinski (who helmed The Mousetrap) is now earmarked to direct, but the film's budget remains set at a slender $10m which would mean Pitt and Roberts agreeing to a substantial cut in their standard asking price.

The Mexican is not the only script in the Roberts in-tray. The actress is also expected to take over from a pregnant Catherine Zeta-Jones in Oliver Stone's Beyond Borders, opposite Kevin Costner.

webTitle: DiCaprio or Law? The spiderweb thickens

fields.headline: DiCaprio or Law? The spiderweb thickens
fields.trailText: The role of student-superhero Peter Parker in the forthcoming Spiderman project looks to have been finally narrowed down to a shortlist of three.
fields.body:
The role of student-superhero Peter Parker in the forthcoming Spiderman project looks to have been finally narrowed down to a shortlist of three.

According to Entertainment Weekly, an unnamed source at Columbia studios has revealed that the leading candidates are Jude Law, Leonardo DiCaprio and Freddie Prinze Jr. DiCaprio's representative - the splendidly named Ken Sunshine - would neither deny nor confirm the rumour, but a spokesman for Law admitted to the magazine that Columbia had already approached the actor. "There have been overtures about it," the spokesman says. "Jude has been a Spiderman fanatic since he was a kid."

The news is just the latest twist in a behind-the-scenes drama that is likely to be more absorbing than anything that eventually makes it onto the screen. Columbia's adaptation of the classic Marvel comic book yarn has been plagued by problems from the start. Hasty script rewrites have been commisioned to appease dissatisfied Marvel executives. Meanwhile the director's hat has been passed variously between James Cameron, David Fincher and Jan de Bont before settling firmly and finally on the head of Sam Raimi two weeks ago. Movie fans and comic-book afficionados have been following the developments with a nerdy relish, on a website (www.spidermanhype.com) dedicated to documenting every twist in the Spiderman tale.

 Columbia has confirmed that the picture will begin shooting in November or December with a view to an American release in the autumn of 2001.

fields.headline: Sadie Frost's German jail ordeal
fields.trailText: Sadie Frost suffered a comedy of misadventures on a recent trip to Germany when the actress found herself imprisoned twice in one night: first in a faulty lift and later in a local jail.
fields.body:
Sadie Frost suffered a comedy of misadventures on a recent trip to Germany when the actress found herself imprisoned twice in one night: first in a faulty lift and later in a local jail.

The lift had broken down as Frost was on her way to the fourth floor apartment rented by long-term partner Jude Law. Fire crew and local police eventually forced open the doors, but it was a case of out of the frying pan, into the fire for Frost who was carted off to prison when she failed to produce any ID.

"They put me in a armlock, handcuffed me and manhandled me into the back of a police van," Empire online quotes her as saying. During her night in jail, Frost was apparently refused food or drink and forced to urinate on the stone floor of her cell. The actress is expected to file a law suit against the German authorities.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.standfirst: Stigmata killed off in El Salvador • New Line signs up Happiness director • Ed Furlong to play 11th century knight
fields.trailText: Stigmata killed off in El Salvador • New Line signs up Happiness director • Ed Furlong to play 11th century knight
fields.body:
Stigmata may have been a box-office hit in the US, but in El Salvador the Exorcist-style horror film has become a picture non-grata. Government officials last night slapped an immediate ban on the movie by British director Rupert Wainwright, which had opened in the city of San Salvador last Friday.

Wainwright's film concerns a Pittsburgh stigmatist ( Patricia Arquette ) on the run from a corrupt Vatican establishment and has outraged the authorities in this predominantly Catholic country. Last night Morena Serpas, director of El Salvador's office of Public Performances, damned the movie as "an attack on public order".

In brief

New Line Cinema has secured the domestic distribution rights to the eagerly anticipated new film from Happiness director Todd Solondz. The project is as yet untitled and swathed in secrecy, although Variety reports New Line spokesman Michael De Luca describing it as "Todd's most commercial venture yet." The picture will again be produced by Solondz's Happiness collaborator Christine Vachon and is due to begin shooting in the summer.

The amount of money spent producing pictures in Britain rocketed 35% during 1999 to a record $922m. Of this figure, some $641m is a result of foreign investment - principally American studios electing to shoot in the UK with a British cast and crew. "The UK has always demonstrated it had the best talent in front of the camera and behind it," film minister Janet Anderson told the Daily Express. "We're now recognised internationally as a centre of excellence for film-making."

Casting couch

$#149; Ed Furlong yesterday signed up to the lead role in The Knights of the Quest, an 11th century epic to be directed by Italian director Pupi Avanti. The pallid star of T2, Pecker and American History X will play a lowly errand boy who sets off to recover a missing relic. Principal photography begins next month across a globe-hopping set of locations: Italy, Tunisia, France and Scotland.

webTitle: China bans use of 'state secrets' on internet

fields.headline: China bans use of 'state secrets' on internet
fields.trailText: Beijing has imposed tough new controls on the country's estimated 9m internet users, banning them from publishing "state secrets" on the Web. The catch is that no one in China can be entirely sure what is or is not a secret.
fields.body:
Beijing has imposed tough new controls on the country's estimated 9m internet users, banning them from publishing "state secrets" on the Web. The catch is that no one in China can be entirely sure what is or is not a secret.

Human rights observers said it was the most swingeing clampdown that the world had known on the free use of cyberspace. The new regulations, announced in the Communist party newspaper last week, say that "all organisations and individuals are forbidden from releasing, discussing or transferring state secret information on bulletin boards, chat rooms or in internet newsgroups".

Interpreting the new rules could prove a very difficult task in a political culture where the limits of secrecy are never defined. The term can cover economic statistics and political news as well as military information. With the press still controlled largely by the Communist party, it is often hard to determine what has been published officially, the only definite criterion for what is not a "state secret".

Any electronic links between domestic and foreign websites are also covered by the ban, "whether direct or indirect" - raising fears that the use of the internet to connect political groups with the outside world will also be suppressed. China has already blocked access to some foreign websites, including the BBC Online service, but users are continually finding mirror sites that can evade the restrictions.

Observers expressed alarm at the scale of the Chinese clampdown. Andrew Puddephatt, director of the freedom of expression campaign Article 19 in Britain, said that up to now the internet had been allowed to exist in most countries relatively free of state interference.

"Any attempt by any government to impose censorship of the kind commonly applied to newspapers and television networks around the world must be regarded as a very dangerous precedent," he said.

Beijing leaders, from President Jiang Zemin downwards, became anxious last year when sensitive and supposedly secret information surfaced on several Chinese websites. The launch of China's first unmanned spacecraft last November was revealed on a domestic website two days before it actually took place. The unauthorised report even gave details of the spacecraft's planned return to earth in Inner Mongolia.

Other embarrassing breaches of security included sites that published details about China's naval ship-building programme and information about new aircraft construction. Most of these lapses appear to originate from computer fanatics who have no political motive, but want to show how well informed they are.

An engineer at a space centre is said to have used a picture of a secret workshop as an illustration on his own website. A technician at the Shanghai Jiangnan shipyard ended up in court after bragging that his yard was making China's first aircraft carrier.

The regime's fears about the growth of internet culture in China extends to religious groups organising themselves through cyberspace. Mr Jiang suspects that the banned Falun Gong cult used the internet to mobilise thousands of its members for a silent demonstration last April in Beijing.

Mr Jiang is also well aware that President Clinton and other United States leaders, including the secretary of state Madeleine Albright, have hailed the internet as a way of "opening up" China to foreign ideas.

The authorities' concern is heightened by the rapid surge in China's internet use, which grew more than four fold last year. The number of individual online users increased from from 2.1m in December 1998 to 8.9m last December, and is forecast to double this year to 20m.

A recent survey shows that about half of all users surf the Net from their homes. Previously, most users went online from internet cafes or at work where monitoring is easier. Half of all users live in Beijing but access is spreading, and the first internet cafe has just opened in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital.

The clampdown will create a new breed of locally created censors. Every website or large organisation with computer links to the internet must now employ its own monitors, dubbed "secrecy checkers", to make sure nothing that the government defines as a secret is published.

The new regulations, like all other internal Chinese legislation, do not apply in Hong Kong. But Beijing is concerned that "secret" information transmitted from China is then "re-broadcast" back to the mainland, where it may even be picked byofficial newspapers.

The new regulations also prohibit China's domestic websites from hiring reporters to generate their own news content.

"I don't think news will be completely banned from the websites," said an independent website manager from Shanghai who was quoted last week by the Shanghai Daily. "What the government really wants is to curb unauthorised news."

Users are in the dark as to what penalties Beijing will apply to those who break the new restrictions. Offending websites are likely to be closed down.

In recent months the Chinese government has closed down several newspapers as a punishment for printing "sensational stories" and "articles with political errors". Some journalists have also been sent to prison for publishing "state secrets".

The catch is that no one in China can be entirely sure what is or is not a secret. Human rights observers said it was the most swingeing clampdown that the world had known on the free use of cyberspace. The new regulations, announced in the Communist party newspaper last week, say that "all organisations and individuals are forbidden from releasing, discussing or transferring state secret information on bulletin boards, chat rooms or in internet newsgroups". The term can cover economic statistics and political news as well as military information. With the press still controlled largely by the Communist party, it is often hard to determine what has been published officially, the only definite criterion for what is not a "state secret". Any electronic links between domestic and foreign websites are also covered by the ban, "whether direct or indirect" - raising fears that the use of the internet to connect political groups with the outside world will also be suppressed. China has already blocked access to some foreign websites, including the BBC Online service, but users are continually finding mirror sites that can evade the restrictions. fields.headline: Superman 'walks' in TV commercial
fields.standfirst: US disability groups protest that advertisement suggested paralysed actor Christopher Reeve had somehow been cured
fields.trailText: A dramatic commercial left some paralysed people believing Christopher Reeve could walk again and wanting to know where they could find the same help, the leader of an advocacy group said.
fields.body:
A dramatic commercial left some paralysed people believing Christopher Reeve could walk again and wanting to know where they could find the same help, the leader of an advocacy group said.

"We've received a number of phone calls from persons who are paralysed or their parents or relatives, saying, 'What research institute did Mr. Reeve go to in order to receive his cure?'" said Thomas Countee Jr, the executive director of the US National Spinal Cord Injury Association.

In the computer-engineered advertisement for Nuveen Investments, aired during the National Football League game on Sunday, the Superman actor is among those assembled in an auditorium of the future to honour research that cured spinal cord injury. Reeve was paralysed in a horse riding accident in 1995.

In the commercial, he gets up from a chair, then walks haltingly to the stage and stands with other beneficiaries of the research.

Chris Allen of Nuveen said the point of the television advertisement was "to inspire a dialogue on money, to have a new dialogue and get away from buying bigger boats and bigger cars and think about the impact that money can have on the future."

But Mr Countee said the commercial may have inspired too much hope in people who are paralysed.

"When you go out with an advertisement like that, you tread a very, very narrow line between trying to be creative - and being misleading," Mr Countee said from his association headquarters in Silver Spring, Maryland.

Reeve, 47, acknowledged on Monday that he has often been criticised for his unceasing optimism that he will one day walk again.

But he insisted that the scene in the television commercial is "something that can actually happen".

The commercial was aired at a cost of $2m (£1.2m) during the most expensive advertising time on American television.

When he first saw the finished commercial, Reeve said he was overcome. "You get swept away by the emotion of the piece," he said. "There was a lot of reaching for the Kleenex afterwards - I was elated. I was deeply moved."

The actor gave television interviews to explain his participation in the advert, and also issued a statement via Nuveen Investments. "Most scientists agree that with enough money and talent focused on spinal cord repair, the goal of walking within the foreseeable future is a very real possibility."

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Still standing
fields.body:
Still standing

Business Opportunities Digest, a London-based magazine, appears to live up to its name, spotting business opportunities few of its rivals would dare to exploit. In this case it was at the expense of Neil Hussey of Staffordshire, who cancelled his subscription in 1998.

Unfortunately, he neglected to cancel the standing order on his bank account. Last July, he found £59.50 had been deducted from his account and copies of the magazine began arriving again. He returned them with explanatory letters, but despite three further letters to the company, including one sent recorded delivery, he has had no reply.

Callers to Business Opportunity's phone line are greeted by a recorded message inviting them to write or fax. Consumer does both and has heard nothing since, so Hussey would be well advised to get in touch with his local trading standards authority. The moral of the tale is always cancel direct debits and standing orders through your bank when terminating any such contracts.

C&W: calls still queueing

Last summer Susan Thomas of London sent out 16,000 brochures for a conference and asked interested parties to ring a C&W phone number. Anyone who did would have been met with a blank tone; her line had been unexpectedly cut off. Over the next three-and-a-half months she spent hours trying to get through to the infamous fault line, was stood up by three engineers and received none of the promised call-backs.

The only things that did turn up were two bills for non-existent calls. The two engineers who remembered to arrive declared the problem was impossible to fix. Then one day the phone began working without any site visit or roadworks. But it was too late to save the conference. An audience of 200 was projected, but only 56 turned up, all of whom had registered before the phone went dead or after a last-minute mailshot with an alternative BT number. Thomas reckons the lost line cost her £30,000. C&W has offered her £35.

Slough of despond

The bizarre side effects of rail privatisation - which obliged one reader to spend four weeks and 10 phone calls trying to book a ticket - were recounted last week. This week, Bernard Duffy of Windsor describes the torturous process of travelling on our fragmented rail routes; and his year-long battle against the train giants shows how paltry protection is for the consumer.

Duffy has commuted from Windsor to London for the past seven years by one of two routes - to Waterloo or to Paddington. Usually he takes the faster route to Paddington from Slough and has a £2,000 annual season ticket. The ticket covers Slough and London transport zones 1-6, but is also "valid for travel by any reasonable route." And so, when Duffy wanted to go to Feltham, midway between Windsor and central London, he did what he has always done - take the Waterloo line from Windsor, a journey of seven stops.

The Slough route would have meant going to Paddington, crossing London via the tube and travelling eight stops from Waterloo. But this carried no weight with the Thames Trains conductor who declared his ticket invalid because he had not travelled from Slough. Duffy was fined £10 and contacted the independent penalty fares appeals service. Alas, the manager said his plea - that the conditions of carriage allowed for travel by the shortest route - was too difficult to understand and beyond her remit.

She waived his penalty fare but told him he should never break the rules again. Next stop, the office of the rail regulator, which oversees train operators. The office sympathised but passed him on to the association of train operating companies (ATOC). "Given that Thames Trains is a member, this hardly constitutes an independent system to protect passenger's rights," says Duffy. "Without even asking for my arguments, they ruled against me. When I protested, I was invited to set out my arguments, then it ruled against me again."

Undaunted, Duffy went to court to seek a ruling that his ticket was valid. Just before the hearing, Thames Trains and ATOC suddenly decided he was in the right. Duffy won a declaration to that effect and was awarded £770 in costs. "There were times when I wondered if I was mad to continue but for evil to triumph, it is enough that good men do nothing," says Duffy. "The conduct of the train companies was disgraceful and the rail regulator has proved itself a toothless tiger."

fields.headline: A century before lunch
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who was the last batsman to score a century before lunch on the first day of a Test match? How many balls did it take, and were there any famous bowlers on the opposing side?
fields.body:
Who was the last batsman to score a century before lunch on the first day of a Test match? How many balls did it take, and were there any famous bowlers on the opposing side?

It was Majid Khan, for Pakistan against New Zealand at Karachi in 1976-77. He reached his hundred in 113 minutes from 74 balls before lunch on the first day, against a bowling attack spearheaded by Richard Hadlee and Richard Collinge and also including Lance Cairns and slow left-armer David O'Sullivan. It was only the fourth time anyone had made a hundred before lunch on the first day of a Test, and the others were all Australians playing against England - Victor Trumper (Old Trafford 1902), Charlie Macartney (Headingley 1926) and Don Bradman (Headingley 1930 - he ended the first day 309 not out).

Did Shropshire once defeat Yorkshire in the Gillette Cup? asks Steven Icke

It was in 1984, by which time the Gillette Cup was called the NatWest Trophy, that Shropshire beat Yorkshire by 37 runs at Telford. Yorkshire also lost to Durham (not then a first-class county) by five wickets at Harrogate in 1973. Other Minor Counties to defeat first-class opposition in the Gillette/NatWest are: Lincolnshire, who beat Glamorgan by six wickets at Swansea in 1974; Hertfordshire, who beat Essex by 33 runs at Hitchin in 1976; Durham (again), who beat Derbyshire by seven wickets at Derby in 1985; Buckinghamshire, who beat Somerset by seven runs at High Wycombe in 1987; Cheshire, who beat Northants by one wicket at Chester in 1988; and Hertfordshire, who beat Derbyshire 2-1 in a "bowlout" after their match at Bishop's Stortford was abandoned in 1991. In 1998, Scotland beat Worcestershire by four runs at Edinburgh.

I am putting together a family history website. One ancestor, a Walter Baptist Money (1848-1924), is described as "Captain of Cambridge XI and played for the Gentlemen of England". I seem to remember seeing a "Money" in a drawing with WG Grace. Do you have any more information? asks Adrian Money

The "Who's Who of Cricketers" (1993) describes the Rev. WB Money like this: "Middle-order right-hand batsman, slow left-hand underarm lob bowler. Kent (1867, one match), Cambridge University (1868-71, Blue all four years), Surrey (1869, two matches). His first-class debut was for Gentlemen of Kent in 1866, when he had the unusual distinction of bowling unchanged through the first innings, taking 5-35 ... After entering the Church in 1871, he gave up serious cricket. A noted rackets player, he represented Cambridge." You could ask the library at Lord's Cricket Ground (telephone 0171 289 1611) whether they can trace the drawing you remember.

What is the highest total England have scored batting last to win a Test match? asks S Fitzmaurice

It was 332, at Melbourne in 1928-29. Herbert Sutcliffe made 135 as England defied a rain-affected pitch to win by three wickets on the seventh day (all Tests in Australia in those days were played to a finish). The only other time England have made more than 300 to win a Test was at Christchurch in 1996-97, when they made 307-6 to beat New Zealand.

Can you give me the names of Middlesex's 1947 Championship-winning side (I realise they obviously used more than 11 players, but they must have had a regular line-up)? asks Brian Binns

Middlesex's regular players that year, in rough batting order, were Syd Brown (who played in all 26 Championship matches), Jack Robertson (22), Bill Edrich (20), Denis Compton (17), George Mann (21), skipper Walter Robins (18), Alex Thompson (20), wicketkeeper Leslie Compton (26), Jim Sims (24), Laurie Gray (26) and Jack Young (25).

Who got Don Bradman out in his last Test innings? asks David Slater

It was Eric Hollies, the Warwickshire legspinner, who bamboozled The Don second ball at The Oval in 1948. Bradman, who needed to score 4 to ensure that his final Test average was 100, was out for 0 and was stuck with an average of 99.94.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the gossip from all the papers, and some websites too
fields.trailText: The Sun Tottenham will offer Ipswich £5m for David Johnson. Ipswich are ready to do business after their £2.5m signing of Marcus Stewart.
fields.body:
The Sun Tottenham will offer Ipswich £5m for David Johnson. Ipswich are ready to do business after their £2.5m signing of Marcus Stewart.

Daily Mail Chelsea have fallen behind in the race for Ruud van Nistelrooy. Roma have offered PSV £17.5m for the Dutch striker.

Daily Star Sunderland have made a £3m double bid for Bologna defenders Massimo Paganin and Nicola Boselli.

This Is London Lee Dixon is a target for Manchester City. Joe Royle was hoping to land the full-back on a free transfer at the end of the season, but Arsene Wenger has offered Dixon another year's contract so a fee would have to be involved.

Arsenal are planning to move into a £100m leisure complex half a mile from Highbury. The new development will include a hotel, casino, conference facilities, a shopping mall, night clubs and restaurants.

The Mirror Watford want Reading midfielder Darren Caskey. Graham Taylor is prepared to spend £750,000 on the ex-Spurs player, but faces competition from Southampton and Ipswich.

Charlton want Crystal Palace's Hayden Mullins. The £2m-rated midfielder may go for as little as £500,000 as desperate Palace are forced to clear their debts.

The Express QPR are in talks over plans to move into a £60m stadium at Wormwood Scrubs. They would share the 60,000-seater with UK Athletics.

fields.headline: Bringing back Beowulf
fields.trailText: The British Library is publishing a double CD-rom containing colour digital images of the Beowulf manuscript together with related commentaries and transcripts.
fields.body:
Buried in the British Library's new building at Euston is a small fragile looking manuscript. Protected by glass and low lighting, its meaning is obscured by an ancient language. Yet it is about to become available to scholars around the world in unprecedented detail. It is the only surviving copy of the 11th century Old English epic poem - Beowulf.

The British Library is publishing a double CD-rom containing colour digital images of the manuscript together with related commentaries and transcripts. The poem evokes a dark landscape inhabited by mythical monsters engaged in epic battles.

This edition is aimed at academics familiar with the language. A multimedia version with a translation is planned schools and general readers. Those wanting help with their Old English have a choice between Seamus Heaney's Whitbread prize winning version or net translations including that from the US scholar John Breeden.

This area of medieval scholarship has been illuminated by technology from space exploration. Professor Kevin Kiernan, the editor of the electronic edition, was inspired by work at Nasa to use advanced image enhancement techniques in unraveling some of the mysteries of the manuscript.

Although it survived for centuries, it was damaged in a fire in 1731. Handling by scholars led to further deterioration as the edges crumbled away.

The detective work to reconstruct some of the missing text involved Kiernan studying not only the first complete edition of the poem published in 1845 but also the contributions of other 19th century medieval specialists. Kiernan followed through with an increasing sophisticated series of experiments using digital cameras, ultraviolet fluorescence, and fibre-optic backlighting with staff at the BL led by Andrew Prescott, curator of western manuscripts. Each page was filmed in colour using a digital camera and illuminated by a cold fibre optic light source to minimise damage.

Kiernan decided to use Netscape as the front end of the project because it makes it platform-independent and ready to put out on the net. The Java plug-in has a built in magnification tool, the facility to view pages side by side and a sophisticated search.

When running the disks it is advisable to use a system well above the recommended minimum spec because the large files are unwieldy with slower systems. The only thing missing is a series of links to related sites. Not even the British Library's own site is mentioned.

Professor Kevin Kiernan, the editor of the electronic edition, was inspired by work at Nasa to use advanced image enhancement techniques in unraveling some of the mysteries of the manuscript. Although it survived for centuries, it was damaged in a fire in 1731. Handling by scholars led to further deterioration as the edges crumbled away. The detective work to reconstruct some of the missing text involved Kiernan studying not only the first complete edition of the poem published in 1845 but also the contributions of other 19th century medieval specialists. Kiernan followed through with an increasing sophisticated series of experiments using digital cameras, ultraviolet fluorescence, and fibre-optic backlighting with staff at the BL led by Andrew Prescott, curator of western manuscripts. Each page was filmed in colour using a digital camera and illuminated by a cold fibre optic light source to minimise damage. Kiernan decided to use Netscape as the front end of the project because it makes it platform-independent and ready to put out on the net. The Java plug-in has a built in magnification tool, the facility to view pages side by side and a sophisticated search. When running the disks it is advisable to use a system well above the recommended minimum spec because the large files are unwieldy with slower systems. The only thing missing is a series of links to related sites. Not even the British Library's own site is mentioned.

webTitle: Michael Portillo, grave with new added earnest

fields.headline: Michael Portillo, grave with new added earnest
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: It should have been a triumphant prime minister's question time for Tony Blair. Last week, rightly or wrongly, it appeared that he had bottled out of the session. Instead, Tories were allowed to filibuster the day away.
fields.body:
It should have been a triumphant prime minister's question time for Tony Blair. Last week, rightly or wrongly, it appeared that he had bottled out of the session. Instead, Tories were allowed to filibuster the day away.

But now it's the opposition that looks silly. William Hague has replaced John Redwood with Archie Norman, a management consultant turned grocer who has all the charisma of a barcode scanner.

Mr Hague reminds me of that chap Graham Taylor who used to manage England. Once, when England were a goal down, he pulled off their leading goalscorer, Gary Lineker. England lost, and the Sun depicted Taylor as a turnip. Mr Hague would look similarly fetching with a few green stalks sticking out of his head.

(John Redwood is not a good speaker either, but at least he works hard and has a grasp of the subject. He is not a space alien, but a nerd, a school swot, the kind of chap who gets too interested in his subject. I used to expect him to appear in the chamber wearing short pants with a sliderule down his socks.)

Mr Hague has also promoted Michael Portillo to shadow chancellor. Portillo is famous for having prematurely installed phone lines ready for his secret leadership bid in 1995. If you went round now, you would probably find a satellite station up on his roof.

Mr Blair appears to be delighted by this turn of events, and repeated Mr Portillo's stated view that the Hague leadership was "unassailable" several times throughout the day.

So question time should have been easy. But it wasn't. For a start, the traditional opening lickspittle question, the one in which a Labour MP tries to polish the Blair boots with his hair, had fallen to Piara Khabra, the MP for Southall. As well as being fawning, obsequious and as greasy as artificial lard, Mr Khabra managed to be incomprehensible and incoherent. Even the politer Tories, usually considerate to ethnic minority MPs, began baying.

Then Mr Hague attacked Mr Blair over asylum seekers: "It's always a case of 'the cheque is in the post'. You are all talk and no delivery."

Throughout this Mr Portillo sat silent and still, looking grave.

In his crossness, Mr Blair began to wave his hand around, doing what might have been an impression of the late Sir Donald Wolfit in King Lear. The Tories went into camp mode. "Whoooo!" they cried.

Mr Portillo did not budge and his hands were clasped in front of him, gravely.

Dennis Canavan, banned by Millbank from standing for the Scottish parliament, asked why the people of Falkirk West had given him "the biggest poll and the biggest majority in Scotland".

You or I might think this showed that the people of Falkirk know whom they want better than the pod people of Millbank. But you would be wrong. The government had created the parliament, said Mr Blair, in his snippiest drama queen mode. "That is why I believe that the people of Falkirk will return a Labour MP, a loyal Labour MP, at the next election." No hint of an expression crossed Mr Portillo's grave face.

Finally came help. Ann Winterton asked an aggressive question about Sinn Fein. "Be under no mistake!" rapped Mr Blair, bafflingly.

"People are in favour of what we have done," he went on. He was floundering. He needed a kick start, and it came, thank heavens, from Michael Fabricant. "What have you done?" he sneered.

It was perfect. Galvanised by his anger, the prime minister launched into a long, heartfelt list of his achievements in Northern Ireland. It was impressive and commanding. Once again, Micky Fabb had saved the day for Labour.

No expression crossed Mr Portillo's face, which remained grave, with, perhaps, an added touch of earnest.

webTitle: In the land of the free, the legal eagle is king

fields.headline: In the land of the free, the legal eagle is king
fields.trailText: There are 2m guns in civilian hands in the United States. That works out at 200 per lawyer. Wade through the foaming websites of the anti-semites, weekend militiamen and Republicans, and it becomes clear that many among America's well-armed citizenry have performed the same calculation. Because if there is any hope of the ceasefire that they fear, it will come out of the barrel of a law suit.
fields.body:
There are 2m guns in civilian hands in the United States. That works out at 200 per lawyer. Wade through the foaming websites of the anti-semites, weekend militiamen and Republicans, and it becomes clear that many among America's well-armed citizenry have performed the same calculation. Because if there is any hope of the ceasefire that they fear, it will come out of the barrel of a law suit.

First, the score. Gunshot deaths in the US are way down - to only 88 a day. Around 87,000 lucky Americans were treated for bullet wounds last year; 32,436 unlucky ones died, including a dozen policemen by their own weapons. In one typical case, a young man, Steven Fox, described feeling pieces of his brain fly from his skull after a mugger shot him. He is permanently paralysed.

But, hey, that's business for you. And what a business it is. Guns, ammo and accessories are a $6bn-a-year honey pot for several corporations: Browning, Smith & Wesson, Colt and others.

Britain loves stories of gun lust in the US. It is an opportunity for snooty comparisons with America's crude and lawless society. This drives Elisa Barnes crazy.

Barnes is the lawyer who recently brought a groundbreaking law suit against handgun manufacturers, which were found negligent in the shooting of Fox. "You [European] guys are so smug. Glock, Browning, Beretta have these refined European owners. Smith & Wesson is the number one seller of killer guns - and it's owned by Tomkins plc, of England."

Armed crime is traditionally viewed as a social problem, but Barnes thought it was too convenient for gun makers to blame the criminal alone. Through investigation and statistical analysis she concluded that sales to criminals are a much-valued - if unpublicised - market segment sought out and provisioned by these upstanding manufacturers.

Her calculations are compelling. Gun companies dumped several million weapons into outlets in states with few curbs on purchases, super-saturating the legal market so that excess would flow up the "Iron Pipeline" to meet black market demand in New York and other big cities.

Like the company that sells cigarette rolling papers in quantities far outstripping sales of legal tobacco, gun manufacturers have a nod-and-wink understanding of where their products end up. Their market models cannot account for half the gun sales in loose-law states such as Georgia.

Nor can industry executives fail to have noticed the requests - more than 800,000 of them - to manufacturers from the Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agency to trace guns captured by police after use in crimes .

The Fox case jury found a dozen gun makers guilty of negligent distribution. The shooter's gun was never found. Unable to determine which company made the gun that fired the bullet into Fox's head, the jury ordered all the makers of .25 calibre weapons in the case to pony up $5m for Fox's care and pain.

Fox's victory burst the dam. Several hundred lawyers - including the Costanza group, the combine of firms that mangled the tobacco industry - filed suits to make sure the gun industry feels our pain. New Orleans is the first of dozens of cities in court demanding that gun purveyors pay the cost of gathering the wounded off the streets, and the cost of arming the municipal police force in self-defence. The legal profession may finally accomplish what a cowering Congress dare not consider: shutting down firearms sales at source.

The civil rights group NAACP has weighed in with a massive class-action suit on behalf of thousands of the wounded and dead, based on yet another theory: product liability. I spoke to one of their counsel, Mike Hausfeld, just after he returned from beating Hitler in a US courtroom. Fifty years after the war, Hausfeld's firm brought a suit against Mercedes-Benz, Siemens, BASF and others who used slave labour from concentration and prison camps under the Nazi regime. The defendants have agreed to create a $1.2bn compensation fund.

Hausfeld concedes that the companies were acting under orders of the Reich, but points out: "Contemporary industrial empires were made from those profits. In 1938 Henry Ford received a medal from the Führer, and his German plants continued to provide Ford income through 1942. Those profits belong to the victims."

I started with guns, but my real topic is America, Home of the Brave Lawsuit. The open courthouse is the best of US democracy, where Davids may sling their rocks at corporate Goliaths. That is sufficient reason for the powers-that-be to malign the US system of civil justice with frightful images of O J Simpson and Louise Woodward where - they imply - juries ran amok.

Corporate Europe has good reason to fear US law. Consider other Hausfeld cases. His firm took part in securing $1bn from Hoffman LaRoche and other pharmaceuticals giants to compensate victims of their worldwide conspiracy to fix the price of vitamins.

The action, brought in the US, has so far benefited American victims only. European governments can collect fines, but victims of the cartel are effectively out of luck under European Union and British law, even under the supposedly tough new rules.

Hausfeld was also one of the legion of lawyers who whacked Exxon for $5bn in punitive damages for the Exxon Valdez spill. While the Wall Street Journal excoriated the courts for vacuuming Exxon's deep pockets, the $5bn hit seems to have focused the oil shipper's attention. Grudg ingly, Exxon-Mobil now spends billions on double-hulled tankers, escort vessels and new safety equipment when operating in the lawyer-infested waters of Alaska.

By contrast, the French are still picking dead birds out of the TotalFina oil slick. I can't help thinking that disaster, whatever its technical cause, was a product of the Civil Liability Convention (which Britain joined after the Valdez disaster) - limiting shippers' responsibility for spill damage in European waters to roughly $127m. At that price, as far as shippers are concerned, an oil spill is a bargain compared with the cost of prevention.

That brings us to Hausfeld's suit against Monsanto, filed last month. Europe's Greens flatter themselves that they forced the company to retreat from its aggressive promotion of genetically modified grains. But it is difficult to imagine Monsanto's chief executive, Robert Shapiro, frightened by a salvo of well-drafted leaflets. Rumblings of a lawsuit, however, had to disturb his repose, and added to the pressure to seek a haven through merger.

After all, every US chemical company executive is schooled in the story of how half the asbestos industry was forced into bankruptcy court to settle several hundred thousand lawsuits that found companies culpable because they claimed the mineral was harmless.

Alan Simpson, a British Labour MP, has drafted a law that would make GM food and seed sellers liable to legal action for any medical or environmental damage they may cause, more in line with US law. Simpson suspects that Monsanto, AstraZeneca and their ilk would be less cavalier about seeds with tweaked DNA if the companies knew they would reap what they sow.

Where will America's lawsuit-crazed lawyers strike next? General Augusto Pinochet has shopped at Harrods in London, but has never been to Macy's in New York. In fact, since his coup in 1973, the general has not set foot in the US. Of course not, says Hausfeld, "We'd sue him." The Observer

webTitle: Fund handouts erode trust of parents

fields.headline: Fund handouts erode trust of parents
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Rats and Mice have gnawed away at the trust in fair play that was once rock solid among parents and schools in Labour-run Leeds.
fields.body:
Rats and Mice have gnawed away at the trust in fair play that was once rock solid among parents and schools in Labour-run Leeds.

Rats and Mice are acronyms which stand for two funds for councillors to spend in their wards. One school's goody-bag from Rats (the larger fund, so-called because the smaller is Members' Involvement in Community Expenditure) reached £45,000 in a year, while others got peanuts or nothing because their councillors preferred tree-planting or care homes.

"The result removes the allocation of funding to the greatest need and undermines equitable capital funding for schools," said the damning Ofsted report.

Worse, according to the Liberal Democrat education spokesman, councillor Brian Cleasby, is an unofficial pattern of "political spending" which saw a primary school in his ward wait 14 years for new paint, while one on his Labour counterparts' patch was spruced up twice.

"Worse still," he said, "is the political control and meddling in management which have driven some senior staff out and stopped others applying for jobs."

But Labour yesterday emphasised Ofsted's use of "auspicious" to describe council leader Brian Walker's "strong commitment to maximum delegation of authority to officers and greater transparency" and the appointment, after four rudderless years, of a permanent education director, Keith Burton. He said: "I have never worked anywhere before where I have had so many delegated powers.

"We accept the criticisms of our weaknesses in the report. We are revamping our education action plan.

webTitle: School head jailed for sex abuse

fields.headline: School head jailed for sex abuse
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The former head of a Roman Catholic prep school in Lancashire was jailed for three years yesterday for sexually abusing pupils.
fields.body:
The former head of a Roman Catholic prep school in Lancashire was jailed for three years yesterday for sexually abusing pupils.

Judge Brian Duckworth told Rory O'Brien, 57, of Kemple End, Hurst Green: "You have been presented to this court as a man of sterling character, a man spoken about by everybody who has given evidence as someone who has been a charismatic, caring, magnificent schoolmaster.

"Now your career lies in ruins, your character is destroyed, your life is shattered."

O'Brien, the former headteacher of St Mary's Hall, the school attached to Stonyhurst Catholic college near Hurst Green, had denied six charges of indecent assault dating back to the early 70s.

The father of five was found guilty in Preston crown court of three charges relating to two boys assaulted in the 90s and two charges relating to a boy abused in the 70s.

He was cleared of a further charge relating to a fourth pupil who claimed he had been abused in the 70s.

O'Brien's name will be added to the sex offenders' register.

Judge Duckworth said: "The touching of young boys in the way in which you have touched them is horrible and revolting behaviour at which any right thinking people, particularly parents, would be disgusted."

All three former pupils, one in his 30s and two still teenagers, told the court how O'Brien came to their dormitories at night and shone a torch in their face to wake them up, before taking them to his study.

fields.headline: Churches give sex education guidelines
fields.trailText: The Church of England and the Roman Catholic Church yesterday issued a seven-point statement outlining the form they want the government's promised guidelines on sex education to take.
fields.body:
The Church of England and the Roman Catholic Church yesterday issued a seven-point statement outlining the form they want the government's promised guidelines on sex education to take.

But the two churches could not agree on some details. They disapproved of "self-gratification" but there was a divergence of opinion on exactly what it entailed.

"It means using sex to exercise power over someone," said Canon John Hall, an Anglican, one of those involved in drafting the suggested guidelines. "It's not talking about masturbation. The Church of England doesn't take a view on that."

But Bishop Vincent Nichols, an auxiliary Roman Catholic bishop in north London, took a wider view of what the churches were trying to discourage.

"I suppose it means solitary sex, or sex where there's no real communication between the two people," he said.

The two churches are responsible for 7,000 schools and about a quarter of all school pupils in England.

The guidelines are to be introduced after the planned repeal of section 28, which restricts what teachers can teach children about homosexuality. The Catholic hierarchy and the influential evangelical wing of the Church of England opposes its repeal.

But the draft guidelines do not mention homosexuality at all.

"Pupils should be taught from an early age to understand human sexuality _ They should be given accurate information. This will enable them to understand difference and help to remove prejudice."

Human sexuality "finds its perfect expression within loving life-long marriage. Any other physical sexual expression falls short to some degree of that ideal. It follows that human sexuality is not fulfilled in self-gratification or in promiscuous or casual relationships."

fields.headline: Peter Levi
fields.standfirst: Poetry scholar and man of many other parts, his passionate reviews revealed a writer who never stopped being star-struck about literature
fields.trailText: Peter Levi, who has died aged 68, was a restless impulsive man who played many parts: Jesuit priest, poet, archaeologist, scholar, biographer, critic, prolific reviewer, gadfly, man about Oxford - and professor of poetry. fields.body:
Peter Levi, who has died aged 68, was a restless impulsive man who played many parts: Jesuit priest, poet, archaeologist, scholar, biographer, critic, prolific reviewer, gadfly, man about Oxford - and professor of poetry. While there was no one in the literary world quite like him, with his resolute adherence to elegising in poetry, his whirlwind name-dropping in his criticism, his dandyish insouciance, he also hammed up a familiar traditional role: that of the English upper-middle-class eccentric.

Something about Levi never quite belonged. He was a character in Oxford, a good friend of other writers and dons such as Iris Murdoch, John Wain and Lord David Cecil, but I had a comic encounter with him in 1983 which rather punctured any romantic myth I might have entertained about his swashbuckling Oxford life. I had edited a small press anthology and Levi was the only contributor who wondered who I might be and invited me to lunch. My abiding memory is of returning to his room at St Catherine's to hunt out a book and finding another occupant there. He shared the room and they had mixed their days up. This incident rather epitomised his marginal position in the scholarly world, where his books were often criticised for their haste and inaccuracy.

He rarely turned a commission down, it seemed, and he didn't disdain popular works: I first saw him when I worked for a firm of Oxford book packagers; Levi was writing the Atlas of the Greek World, the second volume in a series of coffee table books. He would swan in from time to time and generally leave the editors tearing their hair over the gaps he'd left them to fill in. He was briefly notorious in 1988 for claiming a Shakespeare discovery, a trap that seems to lie in wait for Oxonian eccentrics. The episode was short-lived, probably merely a stunt to sell his Shakespeare biography, but it harmed his reputation; the work in question was obviously by a minor poet, one William Skipwith, as it transpired.

As a reviewer and poetry critic his impulsiveness could be much more productive. He read very widely and books like The Noise Made By Poems were inspiring in their confident ranging over European poetry. His mode of reviewing was entirely his own and he continued to write them in longhand throughout this career. When his first piece for me at Poetry Review in 1986 went missing in the post, he offered to write it again, and he did: "I liked it better second time round," he said. "At the end of June I was falling over myself in the annual attempt to become a more serious critic, but now it is 'August for the people and their favourite islands'. "

Levi was born in Ruislip, Middlesex. His father was a Jewish merchant who had converted to Catholicism, and Catholicism was at the centre of Levi's life until 1977. He was educated by the Christian Brothers and ordained as a Jesuit priest in 1964. His education was interrupted by polio while at school and a serious car crash while at Oxford. He said that the two long periods of recuperation encouraged his magpie reading habits: "dilettantism was thrust upon me". After graduation he taught at Campion Hall, Oxford, and undertook pastoral work. In 1977 he married Cyril Connnolly's widow, Deirdre (Connolly had died in 1974), and left the Jesuits. Levi had been in love with Deirdre for many years and had wrestled with his destiny before making the break with the priesthood.

Levi was Oxford professor of poetry from 1984-89, and for a while I thought he might become Poet Laureate when John Betjeman died. They had a few things in common, though Levi might have been thought to lack the common touch Betjeman had. But he once appeared on Russell Harty's chat show and totally disarmed everyone with his twinkling faux-naivety. Harty was interested in the big turning point in Levi's life, his abandonment of the Jesuit order for marriage and literary life. Something about the way he answered Harty's question on what prompted the change - "It was love" - suggested a man who'd been asleep until that point and had been woken into life.

He wrote more than 60 books (Amazon list 34 as still available), fiction as well as biography, poems and travel writing. He travelled with Bruce Chatwin and Patrick Leigh Fermor and there is a wonderful photograph, taken by Chatwin, of a turbaned Levi riding in Afghanistan. He had a particular affection for Greece, its literature past and present as well as its archaeology.

The face a man presents to the world can tell you a lot. In his photographs Levi usually sports gothic-arch furrowed eyebrows, a gesture at once challenging, querulous and defensive. I admired his lack of the usual English intellectual reserve.

His reviews were always passionate and blended life and art in an often intoxicating cocktail: writing of Eliot he said: "It is even stranger and more thrilling that at Marburg... he missed by a mere couple of years meeting the star philosophy pupil, Boris Pasternak"; "thrilling", "star" - this kind of thing could easily be dismissed by more rigorous critics as high table chunter. But Levi gave the impression that he really was star-struck about literature and at his best he conveyed this to his readers. His own assessment of "the most useful and pleasurable work I've done" was Marco the Prince: Serbian heroic poems that he translated with his friend Anne Pennington.

He is survived by his wife Deirdre and by two step-daughters and two step-sons.

Peter Chad Tigar Levi, writer, born May 16 1931; died February 1 2000

webTitle: Boycott of Austria may recoil on EU

fields.headline: Boycott of Austria may recoil on EU
fields.standfirst:
Commission officials voice fears as member states vow to isolate new government including far-right party

The Austrian far right in power: special report
Freedom Party
People's party
fields.trailText: Vital areas of European Union business could face grave problems if member governments go beyond their threat of bilateral action to isolate an Austrian government that includes Jörg Haider's far right Freedom party.
fields.body:
Vital areas of European Union business could face grave problems if member governments go beyond their threat of bilateral action to isolate an Austrian government that includes Jörg Haider's far right Freedom party.

With Mr Haider claiming the finance ministry for a party colleague yesterday, the sense of crisis in Brussels deepened as the European commission stared into the unknown. Portugal, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, cancelled a visit by its foreign minister, Jaime Gama, to Vienna next week, blurring the boundaries between bilateral and multilateral action -which is supposed to be unaffected.

"Where exactly does bilateral end and multilateral start," asked one perplexed official. "We just don't know what is going to happen."

Austria's 14 EU partners have said they will freeze their bilateral relations with Vienna and downgrade diplomatic contacts if Mr Haider's party and the conservative People's party form a ruling coalition. A new government including the Freedom party is expected to be approved by Austria's president, Thomas Klestil, today after the two sides pledge to respect democratic values.

Portugal's prime minister, Antonio Guterres, said that not even the risk that the action of the 14 could hurt the EU's workings would deter Austria's partners.

"It is a question of principles and values," Mr Guterres insisted. "This is much more important than any tactical question about how this or that [EU] dossier may be affected in the coming months."

In public, commission officials talk of an "unprecedented and complex situation". But privately, their language is harsher, and there is dismay that the 14 moved to isolate Austria without first consulting Romano Prodi, the commission president.

"Its schizophrenic", said one senior source. "They've created a situation where they say they're not going to shake hands with a cousin or a brother, but insist that they can't cancel family meetings."

Tony Blair agreed to support the unprecedented move after talking to Mr Guterres last weekend, but the foreign office was unhappy about the potential for problems in the EU. Sweden and Denmark shared these doubts, but it would have been politically difficult to oppose a step being pushed hard by France and Germany.

On Tuesday, the commission said it "shared the concerns" of the 14, but indicated that for the moment it would be business as usual with Austria.

Under questioning by journalists, Jonathan Faull, the chief spokesman, said that the commission office in Vienna would remain open. Ironically, so will the Vienna-based headquarters of the European Monitoring Centre on Racism and Xenophobia.

But it may not turn out to be as simple as maintaining a division of labour between the commission and governments.

Key areas of EU business are still handled between member governments, whose foreign ministers, finance ministers and prime ministers come together to make decisions in the council of ministers. Much of the work that is approved in these meetings is normally prepared and brokered in contacts beforehand.

"The grease that makes the cogs turn in formal council meetings is applied in bilateral meetings outside," said one veteran Brussels hand. "That could be a problem for Austria and the rest of us too."

A strict ban on bilateral contacts would certainly make it difficult for Austria to take the initiative on issues it is concerned about - which could in turn further damage plummeting popular support for membership of the union.

And the 14 also run the risk of looking ridiculous, with a smiling Mr Blair, say, posing with the Austrian chancellor for an "EU family portrait" at a summit but refusing to meet him in London. "What precisely bilateral means is something we will have to see in the days to come," admitted a gloomy Mr Faull. "Council work will be much harder."

Diplomats insisted that there should be no risk to the year-long intergovernmental conference designed to reform the EU's decision-making procedures to cope with the change and strain imposed by the prospect of 12 more countries joining the union in the next few years.

No EU member is contemplating anything as radical as expelling Austria, but the French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, said yesterday that the EU could suspend Austria's voting rights under article 7 of the Amsterdam treaty if a rightwing government repeatedly violated the union's democratic principles.
