fields.headline: The British way of death
fields.trailText: Dr Moira Baird (Letters, February 2) is correct that a code of conduct obliges nurses to report "to an appropriate authority" any circumstances which could jeopardise care of patients. I am an experienced practice nurse. Due to the unprofessional behaviour of a GP, towards myself and many patients, I reported a serious incident to the GMC and the health authority.
fields.body:
Dr Moira Baird (Letters, February 2) is correct that a code of conduct obliges nurses to report "to an appropriate authority" any circumstances which could jeopardise care of patients. I am an experienced practice nurse. Due to the unprofessional behaviour of a GP, towards myself and many patients, I reported a serious incident to the GMC and the health authority.

The complaint to the GMC was rejected because the "information you provided did not raise sufficient concern". I was expected to find and organise the witnesses because the GMC "have no powers of investigation". None of the patients involved were aware of any wrongdoing.

Many nurses have reported serious matters to the GMC, with little effect except on their own health and stress levels. I am sure the Shipman public inquiry will show that a number of health professionals tried to voice their concerns. I was able to leave the single-GP surgery; most patients are not so fortunate, especially the elderly.

Name and address supplied

In my group practice of 6,000 patients we have a small number of sudden unexpected deaths at home each year. Unless there is a very obvious cause, eg a history of repeated heart attacks, we would feel unable to issue a death certificate and would refer the case to the coroner for a post-mortem examination. A new worrying trend is that, in such circumstances, we now routinely receive a call from the coroner's officer trying to persuade us to issue a certificate. We have no doubt this is a cost-cutting exercise to reduce the number of post-mortems, but are concerned that suspicious deaths could be easily overlooked.

Dr Robin Gleek
Tarporley, Cheshire
rgleek@aol.com


Stuart Horner is right (Death made too easy, February 1). My 29-year-old brother was found dead in unexplained circumstances and we, his family, were told by the coroner that the cause of death was "unascertainable". Only the intervention of our solicitor forced the authorities to carry out an autopsy which led to the "unascertainable" cause of death being discovered and the instigation of a police investigation. We are a working-class family and my brother was found dead in a hostel. I wonder if that had anything to do with our experiences?

Russell Burrows
London


My husband died suddenly at 39. I asked for a post-mortem; I was told there was "no need"; no underlying cause of death was entered on his death certificate; his death was not reported. Only two and a half years later, did I discover there were two different causes of death on record: one in the mortality statistics, and one in the cremation forms. This latter "cause" had no evidence whatever to support it, and the hospital concerned has since acknowledged that. One aspect that has upset me in particular is the laissez faire attitude, the hallmark perhaps of self-regulation. Greater accountability and monitoring of all those involved in such procedures is essential.

Liz Stevenson
Edinburgh


I have been a medical referee to a crematorium for 12 years. About £32m is spent each year on fees to doctors for completing forms or post-mortems. This money would be much better spent on a system of medical examiners covering a wide area. This team could audit all death certificates, recording the doctor involved and the cause and the location of death, and undertake audits of case notes etc, both on the basis of suspicion and randomly. This team could also advise coroners and health authorities and pull together the present disorganised arrangements.

Dr Gordon Pledger
Morpeth, Northumberland

fields.headline: Suspense in Ulster
fields.trailText: Brendan O'Leary's plea that Blair and Mandelson should not suspend the Northern Ireland assembly (Comment, February 2) is wrong about the letter of the Good Friday agreement and profoundly misreads the current political crisis. The GFA did not establish joint authority and there is nothing in the agreement which denies the secretary of state the right of dissolution. Each government is responsible for action within its jurisdiction and the executive and assembly are, like it or not, firmly within UK jurisdiction.
fields.body:
Brendan O'Leary's plea that Blair and Mandelson should not suspend the Northern Ireland assembly (Comment, February 2) is wrong about the letter of the Good Friday agreement and profoundly misreads the current political crisis. The GFA did not establish joint authority and there is nothing in the agreement which denies the secretary of state the right of dissolution. Each government is responsible for action within its jurisdiction and the executive and assembly are, like it or not, firmly within UK jurisdiction.

Even if O'Leary's reading of the agreement were correct, David Trimble will resign by the end of the week if Mandelson does not suspend. If Trimble goes as first minister he will not be re-elected, given the balance of forces within unionism in the assembly. To hang on to May 22 will mean the destruction of the only sort of unionist leadership which can make the new dispensation work. Suspension may also fail, given the obduracy of the present chief of staff of the IRA but to hang on guarantees failure.

Prof Henry Patterson
University of Ulster
henry@13ravenhill.freeserve.co.uk


Three questions: 1. If weapons are handed in, how many more remain hidden? 2. What would prevent the acquisition of replacements? 3. Why, therefore, is the demand for decommissioning allowed to threaten the peace process when it is that very process which allows the only hope that weapons won't be used?

Paul Houghton
Towcester

fields.headline: Mr Bush looks beatable
fields.standfirst:
New Hampshire boosts the Democrats

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush, Republican dauphin and US presidential pacesetter, called it a "bump in the road". But his stinging, 18-point defeat by John McCain in New Hampshire's primary looks, the morning after, more like a head-on collision with electoral reality
fields.body:
George W Bush, Republican dauphin and US presidential pacesetter, called it a "bump in the road". But his stinging, 18-point defeat by John McCain in New Hampshire's primary looks, the morning after, more like a head-on collision with electoral reality. The closer the Texas governor got to voters, the less they liked what they saw. Big bucks - his war-chest is four times the size of Mr McCain's - and GOP establishment backing cut little Granite state ice. His parading of his father, ejected from the White House in 1992, was less a legitimisation of his succession than a reminder of past failure. And his Big Idea, Reagan-style tax cuts, fell as flat as the pancakes at the election-eve tossing contest he attended in Manchester. After months basking in the supposed inevitability of his nomination, the shine is off Mr Bush. He has a fight on his hands. An obstacle course of primaries climaxing on March 7, in California and New York, will test his mettle and his nerve. If young "Dubya" is more than merely the privileged scion of a rich, patrician family, we should know by then.

Mr McCain's was an upset victory in the old style, an upstart usurpation achieved by relentless stumping; he is estimated to have spoken personally to 60,000 New Hampshire voters. His Vietnam record undoubtedly served him well, as did his cultivated outsider-underdog image - a triumph of repackaging for this long-serving senator from Arizona. But a reality check is necessary in his case, too. He trails Mr Bush by 20 points in South Carolina, venue for the next key Republican primary, and nationally. His personalised approach will have less impact in the bigger states. Unlike the pattern of New Hampshire, there will be no independent switch-voters to boost his cause. And after weak showings by conservatives like Steve Forbes, rightwing defections are less likely to hurt Mr Bush. Backed by all but four of the nation's GOP governors, he will use his financial and organisational edge to crush Mr McCain's rebellion if he can.

For the Democrats, this Republican battle-royal is all good news. Al Gore, a winner in Iowa and New Hampshire, has emerged from his tussles with Bill Bradley a tougher, energised, and more persuasive candidate. While Mr Bradley is by no means out of the race, the odds against him are lengthening. But what is now clear to both men is that Mr Bush is beatable. The great prize beckons. King George's coronation is far from assured.

fields.headline: Sex and the single limb
fields.trailText: As head of the NHS sex-change programme, the furore of healthy limb amputation seems to me a case of deja vu (Healthy limbs cut off at patients' request, February 1). In 1966, at the University of California, I studied physicians' attitudes toward sex-change surgery. The majority preferred that desperate patients commit suicide rather than undergo genital surgery. Amputating healthy sexual organs was characterised as surgical mutilation and psychiatric collusion with delusion.
fields.body:
As head of the NHS sex-change programme, the furore of healthy limb amputation seems to me a case of deja vu (Healthy limbs cut off at patients' request, February 1). In 1966, at the University of California, I studied physicians' attitudes toward sex-change surgery. The majority preferred that desperate patients commit suicide rather than undergo genital surgery. Amputating healthy sexual organs was characterised as surgical mutilation and psychiatric collusion with delusion.

Only after years of futile attempts by psychiatrists to make transsexuals accept their birth sex was surgical treatment begun. The rationale for the 1966 programme at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in the US was "if we cannot change the mind to fit the body, then we must change the body to fit the mind". When I endorsed the first sex-change operation at the University of California, in 1969, I was warned of possible criminal prosecution for mayhem. This is the common law offence of damaging the limb of one of the king's fighting men to render him a less effective soldier. Healthy limb amputation may not be comparable to sex change. Half of the world lives as men and half as women. There is no large population content to be missing a leg. There is as yet no substantial body of psychiatric treatment results from attempts to cure this disorder of body image to match the well-documented futility of curing transsexualism.

We are in an early stage of treating this newly recognised disorder. Mental health specialists and surgeons must publish their clinical experiences. Then we can determine whether that learned with transsexuals is applicable.

Prof Richard Green
Charing Cross Medical School

fields.headline: At the eleventh hour
fields.standfirst:
The peace process is sick, but not yet dead

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Once again Northern Ireland is the land of the irresistible force and the immovable object. On one side are the unionists, lodging a demand that is fair and legitimate. Standing against them are republicans, who cannot for fair and legitimate reasons meet that demand.
fields.body:
Once again Northern Ireland is the land of the irresistible force and the immovable object. On one side are the unionists, lodging a demand that is fair and legitimate. Standing against them are republicans, who cannot for fair and legitimate reasons meet that demand. The deadlock continues: the unionists want the IRA to give up its guns, but the IRA refuses. For David Trimble and his men, the logic is impeccable. The republicans have taken, taken, taken from the peace process - now it is time to give. Their prisoners have been released, their politicians elevated to ministerial rank in the new devolved government of Northern Ireland and, most recently, their demands met, with London's acceptance of Chris Patten's reforms of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. They have won much, say the Unionists. Now they must pay the price - in guns and bullets.

What is more, runs this indictment, republicans clearly understood they would have to yield arms by now. Never mind that the actual text of the Good Friday Agreement speaks of May 2000 as the final deadline, it was clear during the gruelling negotiations chaired by the former US senator George Mitchell last autumn that something would have to give before then. Indeed, David Trimble staked everything on his belief that decommissioning was around the corner, even offering his resignation to a sceptical Ulster unionist council if the IRA failed to deliver. It was that promise which persuaded the council to shelve its doubts: if it had not, today's Northern Ireland executive would never have materialised.

All that amounts to a moral weight on republicanism to budge. The nationalist press in Ireland is clear on this matter. The Irish Times demands an end to "the fascist stance" which allows republicans to keep both political and paramilitary options open. The same paper reports that 86% of people in the Republic want decommissioning right now. The pressure is intense indeed: even republicanism's friends now demand at least symbolic movement. And yet symbolism is precisely the problem, just as it has always been. The IRA can countenance disarmament on its own timetable, the one so carefully crocheted together in the Good Friday agreement. The moment that timeline shifts, away from the terms brokered by Mr Mitchell and to ones of unionism's choosing, then disarmament becomes a different kind of action: one that symbolises surrender. That is why Mr Trimble's February deadline, no matter how politically essential, was also so fateful: for it turned a deal, which is acceptable, into a demand, which is not.

So what now? It would be tempting to send for senator George, but that would be a mistake. His patience is surely exhausted and besides, Northern Ireland has to get used to solving its own problems. A gesture from the IRA, a bullet or two, would certainly save everyone a lot of trouble. But the most realistic hope might be not to suspend or park the peace process, but to keep the engine running - to keep the executive in place, if only symbolically. To do otherwise, would be to undo too much valuable work. If the new machinery can be kept in place until May, the arms problem may well find a solution. For that is the true deadline: if the IRA do not disarm by then, they will be utterly discredited and alone. So we urge the politicians of London, Dublin and Belfast to redouble their search in the time that remains for a creative compromise which can hold them, in limbo if necessary, until May. Let the Good Friday agreement run its course. After 30 years, a few months more cannot be too long to wait.

webTitle: Italian officials are accused of stealing Kosovo aid

fields.headline: Italian officials are accused of stealing Kosovo aid
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Italy is reeling from claims that its aid mission to help Kosovan refugees was hijacked by corrupt officials who colluded with the Albanian mafia after years of siphoning funds from other disaster relief efforts.
fields.body:
Italy is reeling from claims that its aid mission to help Kosovan refugees was hijacked by corrupt officials who colluded with the Albanian mafia after years of siphoning funds from other disaster relief efforts.

The head of the mission and three other officials have been arrested on suspicion of systematic embezzlement, false accounting and bribery - igniting fury that up to £40m of private donations to help those fleeing last year's war in Kosovo may have been misappropriated.

The accused are alleged to be a tight-knit group within the civil defence who pulled off similar scams after a 1997 earthquake in the centre of Italy and 1998 floods in the south.

The investigation into the Albanian mission is the most serious of three inquiries into aid to Albania which have uncovered mounting evidence of systematic corruption.

The government-sponsored Rainbow Mission to Albania was a source of national pride after it quickly set up 10 camps to accommodate 25,000 Kosovans who fled Serb ethnic cleansers and Nato bombing.

But prosecutors believe that the camp in Vlore, a near-lawless coastal town, was turned into a money-making machine for those who ran it.

They are accused of diverting humanitarian aid supplies to the black market, accepting bribes from contractors, paying excessively high prices for services, billing for non-existent vehicles and falsifying the accounts to try to cover their tracks.

Gangsters were allegedly allowed to drive off with entire kitchens, use the medical facilities and loot equipment.

The four officials - including Luciano Tenaglia, the camp's manager, and Massimo Simonelli, the field director of the mission to Albania - deny serious wrongdoing.

Mr Simonelli admits falsifying accounts, but denies personally accepting any money.

Last June and July they helped Rhami Isufi, an Albanian businessman, to steal bathroom fittings, thousands of kilos of pasta and other supplies, said Michele Emiliano, a prosecutor in Bari, south Italy.

Camp volunteers claim they heard officials discuss the possibility of making large gains, and hoping that the government would extend the mission to Kosovo after the war.

Prosecutors have concentrated on Vlore, which accommodated 5,200 refugees before being handed over to the Albanian government last April - but have not ruled out investigating the other camps.

Pressure to launch an inquiry started last September after Italian television aired a cook's amateur video footage showing dozens of Albanians looting the Vlore camp while officials stood by.

"The generosity of Italians has been betrayed. Our country is shamed. The government allowed our contributions to be managed by the Albanian mafia," said Enrico La Loggia, a senator of the opposition Forza Italia party.

Members of the public who responded to the government's plea last year for donations to help refugees are incandescent.

After months of insisting all was well, Massimo D'Alema, the prime minister, has admitted he underestimated the accusations.

The minister in charge of civil defence, Franco Barberi, has been demoted.

Mr D'Alema has attempted to deflect criticism. He met a class of primary school children who demanded the return of their £100 donation.

Disbelief turned to fury when investigators said the officials were a well-established team that had worked together on earthquake and flood relief efforts.

They were "steadily engaged in illegal activities", said Daniela Rinaldi, a Bari judge.

The scandal is blamed on the government's desire to court popularity by being seen to set up and control its own aid effort, rather than passing on the donations to non-governmental agencies that had worked in Albania before.

"There is no doubt that the Rainbow Mission was a political decision, not an operational one," said Gianfranco Schiavone, of the Italian Consortium for Solidarity.

Two other investigations have compounded the disillusionment with aid efforts in Albania.

Some 914 containers of goods donated from Italy and other European countries never left Bari port. Mismanagement, possibly criminal, is blamed for the fiasco.

webTitle: MP drops bombshell on Knesset besieged by nuclear row

fields.headline: MP drops bombshell on Knesset besieged by nuclear row
fields.standfirst:
Arab member forces historic debate on Israel's nuclear policy

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: One of the last taboos of modern Israel was shattered yesterday when its nuclear weapons programme was debated for the first time in the country's parliament.
fields.body:
One of the last taboos of modern Israel was shattered yesterday when its nuclear weapons programme was debated for the first time in the country's parliament.

Amid noisy protests, Israel was said to have stockpiled up to 300 bombs, developed with the help of the South African apartheid regime, and it planned to adapt submarines recently bought from Germany to carry nuclear missiles.

The historic debate was initiated by Issam Mahoul, an Arab member of the Knesset from the leftwing Hadash group.

The government reluctantly allowed the debate to proceed after he threatened to appeal to the supreme court.

Repeatedly referring to Mordechai Vanunu, the Israeli nuclear technician who was jailed for 18 years in 1986 for revealing Israeli nuclear secrets, Mr Mahoul accused successive governments of "fraud, lies and deceit", in which the media and academia had collaborated, "to brainwash and drug the public".

According to experts' estimates, he said, Israel's stock of nuclear weapons had increased to what he called "the insane amount of 200-300".

He alleged that the purpose of the German-built submarines was "to cruise deep in the sea and constitute a 'second strike' force in the event that Israel is attacked with nuclear weapons".

He added: "That means, that not only do the hundreds of nuclear bombs that Israel possesses not pose [as] a defence, they actually caused the military establishment to fear a nuclear early strike, which escalates the spiral of the non-conventional arms race further and further, at the cost of billions of dollars."

The nuclear reactor at Dimona in the Negev desert had produced a huge amount of nuclear waste which, if leaked, would contaminate Israel for centuries, Mr Mahoul said.

He referred to reports that Israel had exported nuclear waste to Mauritania, in north-west Africa.

He attacked the cloak of secrecy surrounding what he described as nuclear missile sites near Kfar Zechariah on the outskirts of Jerusalem, and near Yodfat in the Galilee.

He also said Israel was producing "biological warfare" material at an institute in Nes Tsiona.

Mr Mahoul, who was supported by a member of the liberal Meretz party, as well as by his Knesset faction, described the government's official policy of "nuclear ambiguity" as "nothing but self-delusion".

He said: "The entire world now knows that Israel has a huge stockpile of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons, and that it serves as the cornerstone for the nuclear arms race in the Middle East."

"I hope that today's debate will symbolise the breaking of the wall of silence and the beginning of an intensive debate in the Knesset and among the public on this subject," Mr Mahoul said.

Haim Ramon, the member of the Israeli cabinet in charge of the prime minister's office, said that he could not respond in detail to Mr Mahoul's allegations. "To do so would aid the enemy," he said. But he accused Mr Mahoul of hurting Israel's interests. "Do you want us to tell Iran and Iraq exactly what we have and what we don't have? It's unheard of," he said.

At the start of the debate, about two dozen rightwing Knesset members walked out in protest, according to the Associated Press news agency, which added that five Arab members were expelled for heckling.

Though Shimon Peres, the father of Israel's nuclear programme has admitted that the Dimona reactor was built as a deterrent, Israel maintains an official policy of studied nuclear ambiguity, saying only that it will not be the first to "introduce" nuclear weapons in the Middle East.

webTitle: Two die in attack on UN bus

fields.headline: Two die in attack on UN bus
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Two people were killed and several injured yesterday when an anti-tank rocket was fired at a United Nations bus carrying Serbs in Kosovo, the Nato-led peacekeeping force said.
fields.body:
Two people were killed and several injured yesterday when an anti-tank rocket was fired at a United Nations bus carrying Serbs in Kosovo, the Nato-led peacekeeping force said.

"A UNHCR bus was hit by an anti-tank rocket. Two people were confirmed dead; five are injured," K-For said in a statement.

"K-For troops were escorting the bus at the time of the attack," the statement said.

The bus, a weekly shuttle transporting Serbs between Mitrovice and Durakovac, was attacked near the village of Cubrelj.

Mitrovice, 25 miles north of the capital of Kosovo, Pristina, contains one of several enclaves where most of Kosovo's remaining Serb population now lives in fear of attack by the province's Albanian majority.

The statement said that K-For medical teams were last night attending casualties at the scene of the attack and that an evacuation was in progress.

webTitle: Tactical victory kickstarts Vietnam vet's bandwagon and leaves Bush in slow lane

fields.headline: Tactical victory kickstarts Vietnam vet's bandwagon and leaves Bush in slow lane
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: John McCain's compelling victory in Tuesday's New Hampshire Republican presidential primary sent shockwaves through American politics yesterday, as the Arizona senator promised to take his "great national crusade" against big money politics all the way to the White House in November.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Concord, New Hampshire
fields.body:
John McCain's compelling victory in Tuesday's New Hampshire Republican presidential primary sent shockwaves through American politics yesterday, as the Arizona senator promised to take his "great national crusade" against big money politics all the way to the White House in November.

Mr McCain trounced the party frontrunner, Texas governor George W Bush, in New Hampshire, the traditional first primary of the election year, and left the remaining conservative runners scrambling for survival in what is now to all intents and purposes a two-horse Republican race.

The scale of Mr McCain's win astonished even his own pollsters and posed serious questions about Mr Bush's strategy and chances. Mr McCain took 49% of the Republican vote, followed by Mr Bush on 31%. Steve Forbes finished third on 13%, followed by Alan Keyes on 6% and Gary Bauer on 1%.

"Thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you," a beaming Mr McCain told cheering supporters at his Nashua headquarters, with his wife Cindy at his side. "The wonderful New Hampshire campaign has come to an end but a great national crusade has just begun."

In the Democratic contest, vice-president Al Gore dug out a narrow but significant victory, defeating former senator Bill Bradley by 52% to 47%. Mr Gore has won both early contests, in Iowa and New Hampshire, but Mr Bradley did well enough this week to pre-empt expected calls from Democratic party elders for him to abandon his presidential bid before the March 7 "Super Tuesday" primaries.

Most of the political attention yesterday focused on the aftermath of the McCain-Bush contest, with both men wasting no time in hurrying to campaign in South Carolina, the site of their next head-to-head battle in the February 19 Republican primary.

Mr McCain won in New Hampshire because he focused his effort in a single state. While Mr Bush spent the last few months building a richly financed campaign around the United States, Mr McCain worked New Hampshire, spending 73 campaign days there against Mr Bush's 37.

New Hampshire was tailor-made for the iconoclastic, voter-friendly former Vietnam war prisoner. Unusually among primary states, New Hampshire allows independent voters to participate in either of the party contests, and these voters flocked to Mr McCain's cause. The Arizona senator won a 3-1 victory over Mr Bush among independents.

But Mr McCain also won in practically every other category of voters too, including a particularly important 44%-36% win over Mr Bush among registered Republicans, an outcome that stunned the Texas governor and the party hierarchy almost as much as the overall result itself.

In defeat, Mr Bush was quick to contrast his own "50-state strategy" with Mr McCain's state-by-state approach. "He ran a really good race and a strong race," Mr Bush said in his concession speech. "He spent more time in this great state than any of the other candidates and it paid off.

"The road to the Republican nomination and the White House is a long road. Mine will go through all 50 states and I intend it to end at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue [the White House]."

New Hampshire voters provided a disappointing night for the three conservative contenders, especially Mr Bauer, who is expected to drop out soon. Mr Forbes, though, is likely to continue, thus limiting Mr Bush's hopes of rallying the whole of the conservative vote against Mr McCain's progressive challenge.

The Republicans now embark on a frenetic schedule of campaigning and fundraising. Mr Bush has so far amassed $69m in funds, compared with Mr McCain's $14m, enabling the Texas governor to spend heavily on the crucial television advertising that now becomes a much more important campaign weapon than the up-close-and-personal tactics of New Hampshire.

webTitle: Another twist of the knife in Clinton

fields.headline: Another twist of the knife in Clinton
fields.standfirst:
Victorious McCain launches his Republican crusade in the town with the name of a man he has made his target

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Victorious McCain launches his Republican crusade in the town with the name of a man he has made his target
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Clinton, South Carolina
fields.body:
Eight years ago, Governor Bill Clinton emerged from the New Hampshire primaries as "the man from a town called Hope". Yesterday, Senator John McCain inverted the spin, presenting himself as the great Republican hope from a town called Clinton.

John McCain's choice of this small South Carolinan town as the venue for his campaign launch in this state was no accident. His aides were telling anyone who would listen that the president and all his misdeeds were the chief target of the campaign, as the Arizona senator emerged from the New Hampshire primary looking like a genuine presidential contender.

"Last night was the end of a primary in New Hampshire, but it was the beginning of a greater crusade across America," Mr McCain told a crowd of about 800 supporters in Clinton's presbyterian college.

He said the win had given him "a megaphone to talk to all Americans", but he used that megaphone yesterday chiefly to heap contempt on the Clinton-Gore administration, making no direct mentions of his Republican opponent, almost as if the primaries were already over.

Mr McCain's win in New Hampshire was the consequence of a low budget form of "retail politics", travelling by bus to a total of 114 town hall meetings to deliver his message in person.

Bush aides pointed out that Mr McCain is unlikely to be able to repeat that feat in South Carolina, and Mr Bush, conceding defeat in New Hampshire, warned that he had the resources to fight "a 50-state race".

The McCain strategy depends on New Hampshire having a snowball effect on the senator's poll ratings and his fundraising capacities. His press team claimed yesterday that following his victory speech, the campaign raised $14,000 dollars on its website.

Asked what the New Hampshire results meant for Mr Bush, Mike Murphy, Mr McCain's senior strategist, grinned to journalists and said: "Iceberg", leaving no doubt that the Texas governor was supposed to be the Titanic.

Only hours after clinching his 18% win over Governor George W Bush, Senator McCain landed in South Carolina in the dead of night, determined to whip up the maximum possible momentum for his run in the conservative southern state, the bulk of whose Republicans have hitherto voiced their support for Mr Bush as their presidential nominee.

Wooing military veterans

Before New Hampshire, Mr Bush held a lead of up to 20% in the South Carolina opinion polls. But local political observers said that lead could narrow significantly once the enormity of Mr McCain's win sunk in.

Mr McCain's supporters will be able to make rapid inroads into the traditional Republican support base because of South Carolina's unusual demographics. Over 400,000 of the state's 3m population are military veterans, who are drawn to South Carolina because of its cluster of military bases and the subsidised medical facilities they offer. They represent 13% of the electorate, and an even higher proportion of Republican voters.

Mr McCain's early tactics in South Carolina have been to focus discontent on Washington and the present Democratic administration. The jabs against Mr Bush have been more subtle, playing up Mr McCain's record with the veterans as a Vietnam hero and former prisoner of war in silent contrast to Mr Bush's success in avoiding the con flict altogether by joining the Air National Guard.

At Mr McCain's breakfast stop in the town of Spartanburg, the welcoming crowd was a sea of baseball hats marked with the colours of various military units. The senator was in his element. He immediately picked out Ballard Brown, whose cap identified him as a former crewman on board the Intrepid aircraft carrier.

"Hi, I'm an Intrepid man myself, did you know that," the candidate shouted through a scrum of grey hair and old medals. "I know that, and that's why I'm voting for you," Mr Brown shouted back.

Mr Brown has long been a McCain sup porter but he said that since the New Hampshire result, his Republican friends were no longer treating him like a maverick.

"I think the dark horse just turned a little whiter," he said. He added that Mr McCain's reformist message would gain more political traction among South Car olina veterans than Mr Bush's promise to cut more taxes.

The Texas governor's radio advertisements started weeks ago, suggesting that Mr McCain was keeping back more money for Washington and the "special interests" by being stingy with taxes

Like many New Hampshire Republicans, Mr Brown was not buying that line yesterday. "Even if they said they were going to give me back a million dollars, I don't care if there's a tax cut," he said. "I want them to look after social security and foreign debt first. That's what Senator McCain is going to do for me."

fields.headline: Shipman's women
fields.standfirst: What did 15 of the victims of Britain's biggest serial killer have in common? They were elderly. They were vulnerable. They were women. And that, argues  Joan Smith, made them expendable
fields.trailText: What did 15 of the victims of Britain's biggest serial killer have in common? They were elderly. They were vulnerable. They were women. And that, argues  Joan Smith, made them expendable
fields.body:
Was it the mother's fault, smothering him with affection and never allowing him to become a man? Or maybe she was cold and unresponsive, eventually abandoning him through death or divorce. Then there was the wife, docile and withdrawn, feeding his fantasies of control by doing exactly what she was told. Or perhaps she was noisy and domineering, undermining his authority at every turn. One thing we can say for certain is that the moment a serial killer is convicted, a familiar game is about to begin: cherchez la femme.

Nor am I talking about the tragic list of female victims. In the case of Dr Harold Shipman, convicted on Monday of killing 15 women patients with lethal doses of diamorphine, the spotlight has shifted, swiftly and predictably, to his wife and mother. "The mummy's boy addicted to murder" was how the Daily Mail characterised Shipman, describing how, as an adolescent, he watched his beloved mother receive morphine injections as she died of cancer. "Was it a child's rage that led him to kill women who enjoyed the longevity that she was denied?" the paper demanded.

Variants on this theory appealed to Oliver James, one of the media shrinks most frequently consulted by anxious journalists, and Dr Richard Badcock of Rampton special hospital. As for Shipman's wife Primrose, Dr Badcock told the Daily Telegraph that, because of Shipman's need for control, she might have had no life of her own. But the Mail was surprised by her strength of character, speculating that her husband's attitudes had rubbed off on her, giving her the strength to confront curious onlookers. It also asked, rhetorically: "How can any wife stand by such a monster?"

Moves to strip Shipman of his pension, while they may provide some comfort to the relatives of his victims, will in effect punish his wife for his crimes. This is not an argument about whether or not Primrose Shipman is a pleasant person, but evidence of a disturbing phenomenon that surfaces when serial killers, especially men who murder women, are apprehended. Their closest female relatives are placed under intense and often hostile scrutiny, while their victims quickly become types, stripped of their individuality.

In this case, we are told, Shipman was obsessed with elderly women. It may yet turn out, even allowing for journalistic hyperbole, that he killed more than 100 of them. Twelve of the 15 victims whose final minutes were described at his trial were over 60, three were 81. This common factor is assumed to hold the key to the killings and, with a little digging into his background, reporters quickly came up with Shipman's mother Vera, dead at the unusually early age of 43.

But what if the obvious inference is wrong, as it has been in other cases? Serial killers face a number of practical problems, including access to victims and how to cover their tracks. What if Shipman selected his victims with a different thought in mind - that he did not want to be found out? It now transpires that the elevated death rate among his elderly patients had become noticeable enough to prompt an ineffectual police inquiry three months before his actual arrest. So what would people in Hyde have said if, instead of older women dying, his victims had been 25- and 30-year-olds?

In a culture obsessed by youth, older women are far less visible, if not expendable. It was not the police but the daughter of Shipman's last victim, Kathleen Grundy, whose efforts finally brought the GP to justice. The first three victims in the court case died over a two-year period and their respective ages were 81, 67 and 77. If the women had been 41, 27 and 37, it would almost certainly have been a different story. This age group is more likely to visit a GP at his surgery and less inclined to share the traditional deference to doctors that apparently led Shipman's victims not to query his treatment.

Not taking into account this vital factor, ease of access, has been disastrous in previous operations to track down serial killers. During the Yorkshire Ripper inquiry in the late 70s, West Yorkshire police convinced themselves they were looking for a man who hated prostitutes, a decision based on the fact that the middle group of victims worked in the sex industry. In fact, an analysis of the victims suggests Peter Sutcliffe turned to prostitutes, whom he could lure to a secluded place, after his assaults on women in residential neighbourhoods were disturbed. The police overlooked an early victim, a schoolgirl who provided an excellent photofit of Sutcliffe, and relied on forensic evidence from the murder of a prostitute in Preston which he did not commit.

Even more dramatically, police in the US in the 1960s relied on an offender profile that suggested the Boston Strangler was a man with a pathological hatred of his mother, based on the fact that his initial victims were elderly. When a man called Albert DeSalvo confessed to the killings in prison, detectives at first refused to believe him because he had a warm relationship with his mother. He hated his violent father, DeSalvo explained, and his choice of elderly women was dictated by his assessment that they were physically weaker and would put up less of a fight. Later, as he grew more confident, he moved on to younger victims.

I could ask a facetious question here: do serial killers have fathers? But there is a deeper problem. Pop psychology makes dramatic headlines, as it has already done in the Shipman case, but it also deflects discussion away from the real, gut-wrenching horror at the heart of these events. The most significant thing about the victims in the Harold Shipman case - as with Peter Sutcliffe, Albert DeSalvo, Ted Bundy, John Christie, Neville Heath and Jack the Ripper - is this. Their confirmed victims are all women.

Forget the supposed obsessions with prostitutes, mothers or the elderly; what we have in each instance is a man who systematically set out to destroy women. Of course there are serial killers who target men or children, and their motives are often distorted by the press to create lurid headlines. But serial killing emerged as a crime committed by men against women and what we can say for certain about the motive of a Shipman or a Sutcliffe is that it is misogyny in its purest, most lethal form.

If we lived in a society that valued, supported and nurtured women, whatever their age and appearance, this would seem bizarre. But we don't. Murder and violent pornography are at the far end of a scale, with sexual harassment and the demonisation of awkward women - single mothers, lesbians and so on - somewhere in the middle. In the circumstances, looking for an individual woman and a single event to explain Shipman's behaviour is perverse, a means of detaching him from the wider culture we all inhabit. And it is just possible that if we valued certain kinds of women more highly, in this case the elderly, men like Shipman might not get away with murder for quite so long.

fields.headline: Sweet on sugar daddies
fields.standfirst: So Cosmo creator Helen Gurley Brown was once a mistress. Oh, lucky girl.  Katharine Whitehorn considers the pleasure of being kept
fields.trailText: So Cosmo creator Helen Gurley Brown was once a mistress. Oh, lucky girl.  Katharine Whitehorn considers the pleasure of being kept
fields.body:
The news that Helen Gurley Brown, creator of Cosmopolitan as we know it, was once a Kept Woman will hardly astound anyone for what it reveals about her morals - not anyone who has ever read American Cosmo, anyway. But it is intriguing nonetheless. HGB, she reveals in her autobiography, was 24 when she met her 43-year-old sugar daddy; she was applying for her 15th secretarial job and was told she'd got it after a session on a Moroccan leather couch in his office.

After that they switched to a motel, while all she did in office hours was eat peanuts and read novels; it broke up after three months when he left for Europe with his wife. She then applied to an ad agency for her 16th job and was promoted to copy-writing, this being in the days when only by showing you were a lousy secretary were you allowed to do anything else. The rest is history.

How did the sugar daddy pay her, I wonder? Leave the cheque on the mantelpiece in the Edwardian fashion? Give her $50 for the powder room, like Holly Golightly in Breakfast At Tiffany's? Or did he simply award her a ridiculously large salary? Putting your mistress on the payroll is fairly standard practice, after all, in some quarters: when it was revealed that a number of Democratic congressmen had done just that, Mrs Walter Mondale, asked how she felt about it, memorably said: "The Democrats do it to their secretaries, the Republicans do it to the country."

But being a mistress has its drawbacks. As a kept woman, you are disliked not only by the sugar daddies' short-changed wives but by working women generally. Workmates deeply resent any girl who is thought to be making her way to the top of the firm via the top of the desk, and successful, good-looking women are always furious at any suggestion that they have used their charm to get where they are. When the National Union of Journalists ran Fleet Street, there were stern rules about doing two years in the provinces before coming to London; these were designed to see that bed-worthy secretaries never got jobs above trained journalists. Or at any rate, that any girl journalist who was that way inclined would have to start by sleeping with provincial editors.

I doubt if in journalism it is quite so crude - more often, I suspect, blokes kid themselves the desirable girls are really bright. But it seems still to be common enough in showbiz and in modelling - witness the recent scandals about oily agency men exploiting teenage hopefuls.

But of course being kept didn't have to involve getting even a nominal job. Old-time mistresses arguably had a far better time of it; they were provided with a house, perhaps, a carriage, champagne. Many a hardworking girl, slogging home on the bus with a take-away and a packet of aspirins, might wistfully think how nice it would be to inhabit a cosily furnished love-nest, with a man to pay the bills and turn up with a bunch of flowers, and no real work to do before bedtime. (Time was, of course, when that was what wives expected, which was why the women's movement sometimes said marriage was just prostitution with better job security; but wives don't get far with such demands these days.) Just having to sleep with the boss on top of an already hard-working schedule seems, by comparison, not much of a deal.

But the climate isn't right for a serious demimonde of pampered, witty, amusing mistresses, throwing parties à la Traviata, holding salons of philosophers and poets like Aspasia in the Athens of Pericles. The degree to which you get a recognised class of mistress - well maintained by their protectors, supplied with red or white camellias according to the time of the month, all bills paid and a glittering social life - relates to the extent to which legal wives are corseted in respectability and made to stay at home being virtuous and dull. You don't get a mistress class as such when the girls men marry are the same as the ones they sleep with. An old-fashioned friend of bon vivant Cyril Ray once asked him where young men go these days for, you know, harrumph. Ray said he thought they mostly made private arrangements, to which the old boy said: "What! Fellas sleeping with other fellas' sisters?"

Mistresses exist and always will. But few nowadays will ever aspire to the sort of lavish treatment that Edward VII afforded Lillie Langtry. "I've spent enough money on you to buy a battleship!" he once grumbled. "And you've spent enough in me to float one," she demurely replied. I doubt if even the entire staff of Cosmo could match that.

webTitle: Briton gets life for weapons drop in India

fields.headline: Briton gets life for weapons drop in India
fields.trailText: Peter Bleach, a former arms dealer and British army intelligence officer, was sentenced yesterday to life imprisonment by a Calcutta court for conspiring to commit offences against the state of India.
fields.body:
Peter Bleach, a former arms dealer and British army intelligence officer, was sentenced yesterday to life imprisonment by a Calcutta court for conspiring to commit offences against the state of India.

Bleach, 48, was arrested four years ago after a plane in which he was travelling dropped a cache of Bulgarian weapons over West Bengal. The arms were allegedly destined for a Hindu cult, Ananda Marga.

"Because of the serious threat to the security of the nation, [the accused] deserve exemplary punishment," the judge said. The prosecution told the court that Bleach and the five Latvian crew of the Russian-made Antonov should remain in prison for the rest of their lives.

Bleach lodged an appeal. "It is a conviction based on false evidence," he told reporters before leaving the court.

He says documents showing he alerted the British ministry of defence about the planned operation were not considered by the court and that parts of a key document - a record of a meeting with special branch officers at his home in Howdale, North Yorkshire - were removed.

Security sources insist that Bleach was told to pull out of the operation. He denies this and says that, if he had, his life and the lives of his family would have been threatened.

webTitle: Offshore turbines offer green leap forward

fields.headline: Offshore turbines offer green leap forward
fields.trailText: A European consortium plans to exploit Britain's status as the windiest country in Europe by installing two powerful wind turbines off the Northumberland coast this year.
fields.body:
A European consortium plans to exploit Britain's status as the windiest country in Europe by installing two powerful wind turbines off the Northumberland coast this year.

The consortium, Blyth Offshore Wind Ltd, said yesterday they would be the largest offshore turbines in the world when they start generating electricity in August. The combined four megawatt capacity would provide power for 3,000 homes.

The project, Britain's first to harness the force of North Sea gales, was unveiled a day after the government set electricity suppliers a target of generating 10% of power from renewable sources by 2010 as part of its campaign to reduce greenhouse gases.

The two turbines will be built by a Danish wind energy company, Vestas, half a mile off Blyth in sea 25 feet deep, close to an existing wind farm at Blyth harbour; the consortium hoped they would be the forerunners of much bigger projects in deeper waters further offshore.

The consortium - Border Wind, PowerGen Renewables, Nuon UK, a unit of a Dutch firm, and Shell Renewables, part of the huge oil group - said that in theory Britain had sufficient wind to generate three times as much electricity as it consumed.

The £4m project, funded partly by the European com mission, is dwarfed by a £6bn potential for offshore farms identified by the department of trade and industry.

It is also tiny by comparison with plans to instal 750 megawatts of renewable energy in Denmark by the end of 2004, and an Irish project to build 200 megawatts of wind power six miles offshore in Dublin bay.

David Still, managing director of Border Wind, said the UK lagged behind other European countries such as Denmark and the Netherlands in renewable energy but now had the chance to catch up.

Offshore wind power, electricity from onshore wind farms, and bio-mass (burning organic waste) are seen as the three elements that can help industry reach the 10% target set by Helen Liddell, the energy minister, on Tuesday.

Mr Still said that the Blyth project could lead to far bigger schemes, costing as much as £200m, that would be more efficient and thus bring down the cost of wind electricity.

Mrs Liddell said this week she was "not ready to see consumers pay through the nose" for achieving the 10% target. The utilities bill foresees electricity customers receiving a 10% cut in bills so, Mrs Liddell said, they could be asked by suppliers to pay an extra £1.35 on the average quarterly bill to fund green power.

Renewables account for 2.6% of Britain's electricity, and are being promoted by ministers to help meet their target set at the Kyoto world conference of reducing greenhouse gases by 12.5% by 2010, though the government has volunteered a 20% cut.

Mrs Liddell said: "It's time to make the next generation of technologies lean and mean as well as clean and green." Echoing her, the consortium promised that offshore farms would provide jobs and exports.

The government has exempted renewables from the controversial climate change levy on industry and commerce due to be introduced this year in exchange for a cut in employers' national insurance contributions. Mrs Liddell angered some renewable energy producers this week by scrapping another scheme to fund such energy through a statutory charge on electricity bills.

webTitle: CPS pays up for witness bungle

fields.headline: CPS pays up for witness bungle
fields.trailText: The crown prosecution service yesterday apologised for a mistake that led to five people flying thousands of miles to act as witnesses in a trial which was abandoned before Christmas.
fields.body:
The crown prosecution service yesterday apologised for a mistake that led to five people flying thousands of miles to act as witnesses in a trial which was abandoned before Christmas.

Three witnesses flew from Dubai and two came from Chicago for a hearing which they were told was due to start at Uxbridge magistrates court in Middlesex on Tuesday morning.

When they arrived the court was virtually empty and they were surprised to hear prosecutor Tom Levin announce that the case had been abandoned in December.

The CPS is obliged to cover the cost of the flights, hotel rooms in London for two nights, legitimate travel and eating expenses for the stay and loss of earnings. The overall bill is likely to cost taxpayers £10,000.

The case involved Iameel-ur-Reham Hashmee, a businessman living in Bristol, who was charged last June with assault and disorderly behaviour after a flight on Emirates airlines from Dubai to Heathrow.

Mr Hashmee, 49, was accused of manhandling a flight attendant in a row over a ruby pendant he wanted to buy from the duty free list.

Mr Hashmee pleaded not guilty to the charges on November 30 last year. Two weeks later the CPS sent him a letter saying the case against him had been discontinued. The witnesses, however, were not informed.

According to the CPS, there was a breakdown in communication between their officers and the police, which meant the witnesses were not sent letters telling them not to turn up.

"Somewhere along the line there has been an error," a CPS spokeswoman said. "We are responsible for paying witness expenses. They will not be out of pocket because of this."

fields.headline: Convalescent homes to make comeback
fields.trailText: Convalescent homes are to re-emerge under government plans for a new "intermediate" tier of care to enable elderly patients to be moved out of costly hospital beds but looked after until they are ready to go home.
fields.body:
Convalescent homes are to re-emerge under government plans for a new "intermediate" tier of care to enable elderly patients to be moved out of costly hospital beds but looked after until they are ready to go home.

The plans were yesterday outlined by Alan Milburn, the health secretary, who promised to "build a bridge between home and hospital" in ways that would free acute care beds for more patients needing treatment.

As well as a new generation of convalescent homes, ministers expect to oversee the opening of low-dependency wards in hospitals, run by consultant nurses, and the provision of more intensive domiciliary care to allow some elderly patients to go home sooner than is now possible.

Mr Milburn said: "This new set of intermediate care services needs to be specifically designed around the needs of older patients for a period of rehabilitation and their recovery."

When in opposition, Labour mooted the idea of investing heavily in rehabilitation services to take pressure off hospitals.

The initiative has been spurred by the findings of the department of health inquiry into bed use and availability.

Two-thirds of hospital beds are occupied by patients older than 65, and half the rapid increase in emergency admissions in the past five years has been accounted for by people over 75 - one in two of whom has been admitted on grounds of "symptoms, signs and ill-defined conditions".

In an address at the King's Fund health policy centre in London, Mr Milburn said the ageing population and rising incidence of chronic disease meant that the nature of NHS care was changing from dealing with life's incidents, such as heart attacks and bone fractures, to dealing with life's experiences: getting older and becoming frailer.

The beds inquiry report, to be published this month, would show no simple link between the number of acute beds in a hospital, the management of emergencies and waiting times for non-urgent surgery.

While it was evident that more critical care beds were needed for the gravely ill, and that there would have to be an overall increase in bed numbers in the whole system, the inquiry report would urge wholesale modernisation of the care process.

Too many elderly people faced a false choice between hospital and home, the minister said.

"The beds inquiry will show that they are effectively trapped when they should be free to get back on their own feet after a period of hospitalisation," he said

The plans to bring back convalescent beds, which used to be commonplace but went out of fashion in the 1960s, envisage both a new role for some existing cottage hospitals and the building of some new units, probably with private finance.

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, welcomed the initiative but asked why existing nursing homes could not be used.

The same point was made by the Independent Healthcare Association, which said specialist rehabilitation services stood ready and waiting in the private and voluntary sectors.

Mr Milburn said nursing homes were associated with dependency and were places people tended to go into, never to come out.

"That might be right for a lot of elderly people, but it's not right for all elderly people," he said. "What I want to foster is not a dependency culture, it's an independency culture."

Julia Neuberger, chief executive of the King's Fund, said: "It is essential that the facilities announced today are staffed by people who are skilled in supporting older people and that their primary purpose is to help patients to regain their independence."

fields.headline: Millionaire refuge revealed in Hale
fields.trailText: There is a leisurely flow of Shogun jeeps through Hale village, stopping to park while their owners buy tuna steaks, have a manicure, or nip into the interior designer's.
fields.body:
There is a leisurely flow of Shogun jeeps through Hale village, stopping to park while their owners buy tuna steaks, have a manicure, or nip into the interior designer's.

Hale is one of a string of postcodes across Manchester's southern commuter belt that has been identified by a credit reference agency, Experian, as the wealthiest area of Britain outside the south-east of England.

More than one in 20 householders is a millionaire in the 11-mile strip of affluence running from Altrincham through Hale, Wilmslow, Alderley Edge and Prestbury.

The district has long been known as the home of many of Manchester's football and soap stars. Roy Keene has a large detached Victorian house in Hale, Teddy Sherringham is living down the road in Bowdon close to Mr and Mrs Beckham, and Robbie Williams has a home in Alderley Edge.

Now a new wave of arriviste businessmen and women is buying up properties.

Desirable residencies, say the estate agents, are 30 minutes from the heart of Manchester, 10 minutes from the airport, and in the catchment area of some of the north-west's highest achieving schools.

Shopkeepers in the high street at Hale, surrounded by vast detached laurel-hedged residences, have noticed a marked increase in trade.

Jonathan Kennedy, of Reed Rains estate agents, said yesterday that he had had an incredibly good year and had sold several properties at prices well over £2m.

"You can get almost any property you like in this area. We have Victorian, Edwardian, 1930s and post-war houses - all very large. Tailor-built properties are also very popular -developers are knocking down a lot of the older properties."

Fishmonger Paul Bradbury said of his clientele: "There is still a steady market for cod, and I am selling a lot more swordfish and sea bass than I used to." Outside the shop his advertising board has been changed to read: Monkfish tails at £5.50/lb. Venison sausage: £3.50/lb.

Affluence has even trickled down to the charity shops, leaving them brimming with designer cast-offs - some with the labels still inside.

Christine Mapp, sales assistant in Help the Aged, said: "A lady came in at the weekend with more than 20 designer items, after having had them all dry cleaned. It happens all the time."

Gordon Frankland, who owns Hale's bookshop, said, however, that in his experience many of the wealthier residents did not spend much time in the village.

"I get occasional customers buying £200 worth of hardbacks, but I think that many of the richer folk prefer Manchester's bigger shopping centres.

"I'm not complaining, of course. I've seen my house price go up in recent years."

Jayne Hall, manager of Iceland, disagreed. "Teddy Sherringham is in here all the time," she said.

"You often see Posh and Becks knocking around - they use the shop as regularly as other people in the area. We just leave them alone."

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText:
Claim over condom rejected
Fur hat was error, says countess
Great balls of lightning: a lucky find
Lockerbie charges denied
Web site offers free home sales
fields.body:
Claim over condom rejected
A woman who blamed the birth of her third child on a split condom yesterday lost her £120,000 damages action against Britain's biggest sheath manufacturer, writes Clare Dyer.

In the first damages claim in the UK over the failure of a contraceptive device, Mr Justice Ian Kennedy ruled that Marian Richardson, 36, had not established that the Durex "Jeans" condom was defective.

She sought £120,000 compensation from LRC Products (formerly the London Rubber Company) for the cost of bringing up her daughter Kara, the pain of the pregnancy and delivery, and the financial loss suffered as a result of the birth four years ago.

Mrs Richardson, of Carlton Colville, near Lowestoft, Suffolk, said the pregnancy had led to the temporary breakdown of her relationship with her boyfriend - now her husband - and the shelving of the health consultancy and beauty business they had planned to open.

The judge ruled that for Mrs Richardson to have succeeded in her action she had to have satisfied the court that the condom failed because its latex skin had been damaged by ozone before it left the factory.

Fur hat was error, says countess
Sophie, Countess of Wessex, has admitted making "an error of judgment" by wearing a fox fur hat.

The former Miss Rhys-Jones, who married Prince Edward last June, bought the hat in St Moritz and was photographed in it at the Swiss ski resort.

Buckingham Palace said yesterday that it had been an impulse purchase to counter the cold. "She had no intention of upsetting anyone," a palace spokesman said.

The countess, 35, who has a job as a public relations executive, was criticised by animal rights campaigners. The RSPCA said: "We believe that people should look for alternatives that are just as fashionable but do not cause the suffering of animals."

Asked about the hat when she arrived at her London office yesterday, the bare-headed countess said: "I think it was an error of judgment on my part."

Great balls of lightning: a lucky find
Ball lightning is the last great mystery of meteorology. Every now and then - in thundery weather - witnesses report an eerie sight: a blazing ball of light, floating gently above the surface, either to explode or evaporate after a few seconds, writes Tim Radford Such phenomena have been reported in the aisle of an Ilyushin-18 jetliner, emerging from the pilot's cabin of a Pan Am flight and disappearing into the rear lavatory. Some scientists have claimed ball lightning as an optical illusion, others have pronounced it a knot of long-lived electromagnetic plasma.

But two New Zealand scientists report in Nature today a more down-to-earth explanation for something that has been puzzling physicists for hundreds of years. They say ball lightning is made of fluffy little tangles of silicon that burn and emit light.

Many soils are a natural mix of quartz and carbon. John Abrahamson and James Dinniss, of Canterbury university in Christchurch, argue that all it would take to make ball lightning would be a lucky blast of lightning which would kick a network of invisible particles of silicon or silica into the air, where they would react with oxygen to release heat and light.

They tested their theory in the laboratory by firing charges of electricity into a tiny layer of silica-based soil, and indeed watched them oxidise. They worked out mathematical models of how a ball of invisible dust would increase in temperature to about 1,000C or even 2,000C, to shine with the light of a dim bulb before fading or exploding in less than 30 seconds. But there was one disappointment. "We did not observe any luminous ball," they report. "At the higher power levels, the soil sample was always completely blown away."

Lockerbie charges denied
The two Libyans accused of the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie in December 1988 which killed 270 people yesterday entered their first formal not guilty plea to the charges against them.

Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, 47, and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, 43, face charges of conspiracy, murder and a breach of the aviation security act.

The two men were not present at the pre-trial hearing at Edinburgh high court. Instead, the first formal pleas were entered by lawyers acting for them.

At the same hearing the trial judge, Lord Sutherland, told Ray Martin QC, for the BBC, that he would not hear his earlier application to allow the trial to be televised. He said the application was an administrative rather than judicial matter. The BBC said it would decide this week whether to seek a legal review.

Yesterday's hearing in Edinburgh was a continuation of the hearings begun before Christmas in the converted gymnasium at Camp Zeist, the Netherlands, which will act as a Scottish court under Scots law for the duration of the trial. In those proceedings the crown had sought permission for prosecution witnesses to disguise their appearance.

The crown said it wanted to protect the safety of key witnesses, including security officials from the former East German Stasi. Yesterday the crown modified its request following indications from Lord Sutherland that he would not be prepared to agree to measures such as wearing masks. Colin Boyd QC, solicitor general for Scotland, said former Stasi members had indicated reluctance to come to court if their identities were revealed. These witnesses will now be able to grow beards and change their hairstyles.

Web site offers free home sales
A property web site is launched today which threatens to put traditional estate agents out of business. It costs nothing to advertise your home on the HomeFreeHome site, compared with the usual estate agent's fee of 1%-2%.

Colchester businessmen Matthew and Simon Jackson have invested £80,000 in the site and hope to display tens of thousands of properties.

Matthew Jackson said the site would be "an ideal advertising and contacts medium for all trades associated with house buying. We'll make our money from businesses that will benefit from that extra spending power."

The web site will allow sellers to upload property details and photos. Registered buyers will be notified by email whenever a property fitting their criteria is logged on.

The RSPCA said: "We believe that people should look for alternatives that are just as fashionable but do not cause the suffering of animals." Asked about the hat when she arrived at her London office yesterday, the bare-headed countess said: "I think it was an error of judgment on my part." Great balls of lightning: a lucky find Ball lightning is the last great mystery of meteorology. Every now and then - in thundery weather - witnesses report an eerie sight: a blazing ball of light, floating gently above the surface, either to explode or evaporate after a few seconds, writes Tim Radford Such phenomena have been reported in the aisle of an Ilyushin-18 jetliner, emerging from the pilot's cabin of a Pan Am flight and disappearing into the rear lavatory. Some scientists have claimed ball lightning as an optical illusion, others have pronounced it a knot of long-lived electromagnetic plasma. But two New Zealand scientists report in Nature today a more down-to-earth explanation for something that has been puzzling physicists for hundreds of years. They say ball lightning is made of fluffy little tangles of silicon that burn and emit light. Many soils are a natural mix of quartz and carbon. John Abrahamson and James Dinniss, of Canterbury university in Christchurch, argue that all it would take to make ball lightning would be a lucky blast of lightning which would kick a network of invisible particles of silicon or silica into the air, where they would react with oxygen to release heat and light. They tested their theory in the laboratory by firing charges of electricity into a tiny layer of silica-based soil, and indeed watched them oxidise. They worked out mathematical models of how a ball of invisible dust would increase in temperature to about 1,000C or even 2,000C, to shine with the light of a dim bulb before fading or exploding in less than 30 seconds. But there was one disappointment. "We did not observe any luminous ball," they report. "At the higher power levels, the soil sample was always completely blown away." Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, 47, and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, 43, face charges of conspiracy, murder and a breach of the aviation security act. The two men were not present at the pre-trial hearing at Edinburgh high court. Instead, the first formal pleas were entered by lawyers acting for them. At the same hearing the trial judge, Lord Sutherland, told Ray Martin QC, for the BBC, that he would not hear his earlier application to allow the trial to be televised. He said the application was an administrative rather than judicial matter. The BBC said it would decide this week whether to seek a legal review. Yesterday's hearing in Edinburgh was a continuation of the hearings begun before Christmas in the converted gymnasium at Camp Zeist, the Netherlands, which will act as a Scottish court under Scots law for the duration of the trial. In those proceedings the crown had sought permission for prosecution witnesses to disguise their appearance. The crown said it wanted to protect the safety of key witnesses, including security officials from the former East German Stasi. Yesterday the crown modified its request following indications from Lord Sutherland that he would not be prepared to agree to measures such as wearing masks. Colin Boyd QC, solicitor general for Scotland, said former Stasi members had indicated reluctance to come to court if their identities were revealed. These witnesses will now be able to grow beards and change their hairstyles. Web site offers free home sales A property web site is launched today which threatens to put traditional estate agents out of business. It costs nothing to advertise your home on the HomeFreeHome site, compared with the usual estate agent's fee of 1%-2%. Colchester businessmen Matthew and Simon Jackson have invested £80,000 in the site and hope to display tens of thousands of properties. Matthew Jackson said the site would be "an ideal advertising and contacts medium for all trades associated with house buying. We'll make our money from businesses that will benefit from that extra spending power." The web site will allow sellers to upload property details and photos. Registered buyers will be notified by email whenever a property fitting their criteria is logged on.

fields.headline: Tagged bees answer navigation puzzle
fields.trailText: Bees fitted with radar transponders have helped to answer one of evolution's great mysteries: how a worker learns aerial navigation. Each bee flies a little bit farther each time it leaves the hive until it gets the hang of it.
fields.body:
Bees fitted with radar transponders have helped to answer one of evolution's great mysteries: how a worker learns aerial navigation. Each bee flies a little bit farther each time it leaves the hive until it gets the hang of it.

The answer was simple, but solving it was not. Researchers at Illinois university at Urbana-Champaign, a radar team from Greenwich university and scientists at the Institute of Arable Crop Research at Rothamsted, Hertfordshire, fitted beginner bees with radar reflectors weighing no more than a bee's normal cargo of pollen and watched them venture out.

The worker bee starts adult life in the hive caring for grubs and sweeping out rubbish. At three weeks it is sent foraging.

"Imagine living in a dark castle for about half your adult life and then having to venture into a world of sunshine to find food to bring home," said Beth Capaldi, of Illinois university, who reports in Nature today. "It would probably take time for you to adjust. That's how it is for bees." A bee learns to navigate from the position of the sun and landscape features. Each bee in the experiment was fitted with a tag that re-emitted a unique harmonic of a radio frequency, so it could be tracked for up to 700 metres.

The study found that each time a bee went out on a training flight it flew faster, farther and higher, gaining confidence.

webTitle: Loyalist gang jailed for gun attack on bar

fields.headline: Loyalist gang jailed for gun attack on bar
fields.standfirst:
Mothers express outrage that Good Friday agreement could grant early release for killers of Protestant and Catholic friends
Northern Ireland: special report
Northern Ireland Office
Sinn Fein
Social Democratic and Labour Party
Ulster Unionist Party
fields.trailText: A gang of loyalist terrorists was jailed for life yesterday for the murder of two life-long friends - one a Protestant and the other a Catholic - in a gun attack on a Northern Ireland bar.
fields.body:
A gang of loyalist terrorists was jailed for life yesterday for the murder of two life-long friends - one a Protestant and the other a Catholic - in a gun attack on a Northern Ireland bar.

Stephen McClean and Noel McCready smirked and sniggered in the dock of Belfast crown court as they were found guilty of what the judge described as one of Northern Ireland's "most heinous offences".

A third man, Ryan Robley, who had already pleaded guilty to the killings, was also jailed for life.

The victims' mothers expressed outrage outside the court when it became clear that the killers, believed to be members of the Loyalist Volunteer Force, could be free by the summer under the terms of the Good Friday agreement.

Philip Allen, a 34-year-old Protestant, and Damian Trainor, 25, a Catholic, who had known each other since childhood, died when Mc Clean and McCready opened fire indiscriminately in the Railway Bar, Poyntzpass, a Co Armagh village, in March 1998. As they burst into the bar, one of the gunmen shouted: "Get down, you bastards."

Mr Allen, a lorry driver who had announced his engagement shortly before the shootings, and Mr Trainor, a mechanic who was due to be his best man, died in hospital shortly after. Two other men were injured in the attack.

The killings united nationalists and unionists who were horrified by the murder of two peaceful friends, from either side of Northern Ireland's sectarian divide, as they enjoyed a drink. Their deaths helped to spur Northern Ireland's political leaders to sign the Good Friday agreement a month after the shootings.

Mr Justice Kerr condemned the "mindless bigotry" of the killers who had selected the bar in the mistaken belief that it was frequented only by Catholics.

In his 70-page judgment, the judge said that the masked intruders, who were both carrying hand guns, had ordered all the customers to lie down.

"When the gunmen had the occupants in a position of complete vulnerability, they opened fire," he said. "It is clear they intended to kill as many people as possible, irrespective of the age or gender."

The judge added that the two victims typified the spirit of Poyntzpass where Catholics and Protestants lived in harmony. "That they could have been victims of this cowardly attack is made all the more poignant by the fact that the killers who perpetuated it were motivated by mindless bigotry," he said.

The victims' mothers reacted furiously when it became clear that their sons' murderers could be free by July. Ann Trainor was close to tears when she said that supporters of the Good Friday agreement "didn't know what they were signing up for".

"There's a lot of evil in [the killers]," Mrs Trainor said.

Ethel Allen was also opposed to the early release of the killers. But she said: "At least they will be labelled guilty for the rest of their lives for the murder of my loving son."

In separate interviews for last night's Belfast Telegraph, the two mothers spoke movingly of how they have struggled to cope with the loss of their sons.

Mrs Allen said that for the first year after her son's death she tried to convince herself that he was still alive.

"By day I told myself that he was at work and at night I told myself he was with [his fiancée] Carol or Damian," she said.

McClean, 30, and McCready, 33, from Banbridge, Co Down, were also each given two 20-year sentences for the attempted murders of Stephen Williamson and Clarence Fraser, who were wounded in the shooting.

The judge also imposed a 15-year term on the pair for possession of a firearm.

All sentences are to run concurrently.

The guilty plea by Robley, 30, also from Banbridge, was taken into account and he was given 14 years for the attempted murders and 10 for the firearms charge. A fourth man, David Keyes, 23, was also charged with the murders after showing police the two guns used in the attack. Within two weeks of the shootings he was murdered in the LVF wing at the Maze prison.
