webTitle: Met pays damages for raid on actors

fields.headline: Met pays damages for raid on actors
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police is to pay £55,000 in damages to 11 Kurdish refugees after armed officers stormed their rehearsal of a Harold Pinter play believing the amateur actors were armed with real guns.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police is to pay £55,000 in damages to 11 Kurdish refugees after armed officers stormed their rehearsal of a Harold Pinter play believing the amateur actors were armed with real guns.

The out-of-court settlement was agreed yesterday as a district judge at central London county court criticised the "extraordinary state of affairs" which led to the arrest and five-hour detention of the theatre group, which included a boy aged 12.

The group was rehearsing Mountain Language, a play inspired by the plight of the Kurds which includes violent scenes of torture.

The men, who all have home office status as refugees after fleeing torture and oppression in Turkey, brought a civil action against the police for assault, trespass and false imprisonment.

In what the men's solicitor called "a horror story of life imitating art", dozens of armed police smashed down the doors of the Kurdistan Workers' Association community centre, in Finsbury Park, north London, on the evening of June 19 1996, after a member of the public reported seeing men in combat gear pointing guns at people on the floor.

The group was arrested at gunpoint, handcuffed and held in the back of a police van for more than five hours without explanation. The actors were forbidden to speak in their native language - in scenes similar to the play they had been rehearsing.

Ahmet Yuksel, then 12, was held elsewhere, uncertain of his friends' whereabouts, while police searched the building and discovered that the weapons were props on loan from the Royal National Theatre - a fact made known to local police weeks earlier.

The Metroplitan police, which has not admitted liability, will also pay the legal costs, expected to exceed £45,000. A case brought by a 12th man is still in progress.

Scotland Yard declined to comment yesterday but a spokesman said at the time of the arrests that officers had acted "in good faith".

The New Life Theatre Group had been due to perform Mountain Language in front of Pinter, who wrote the play after witnessing Kurdish persecution in Turkey. The title is a reference to the Turkish-imposed ban on the Kurdish language, which is derided as the "mountain language".

The refugees' solicitor, Sadiq Khan, said: "If it wasn't so serious it would be funny."

webTitle: Column that turns City into showbiz

fields.headline: Column that turns City into showbiz
fields.standfirst: Shares inquiry: Mirror editor hit on wave of popular interest in stock market with the 'matey' style of his City Slickers reporters
fields.trailText: Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, was prescient in his prediction two years ago that the City would one day be as fascinating to his readers as his former stomping ground of showbiz. But it could prove his downfall.
fields.body:
Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, was prescient in his prediction two years ago that the City would one day be as fascinating to his readers as his former stomping ground of showbiz. But it could prove his downfall.

The pair of self-styled City Slickers he hired for the paper in 1998 had an inauspicious start. On their first day, they handed their editor a scoop that was rewarded with the front-page splash. The only problem was that their story, the merger of Asda and Safeway, was not true.

Anil Bhoyrul, 33, and James Hipwell, 34, survived the ignominy to build an unquestionably loyal following with their irreverent view of the sober subject of share dealing - for example, handing out spoof P45s to directors whom they felt should quit in view of their performance.

The Slickers' daily cocktail of gossip, share tips and business news is modelled on the celebrity page previously edited by their editor. Mr Bhoyrul recently told the trade magazine PRWeek: "It is the matey style of reporting - 'our mates told us over a few beers about this'-type thing."

The Slickers' mates in the Square Mile include Alan Sugar, the Spurs boss and founder of Amstrad. Other businessmen who feature regularly are the nightclub entrepreneur Peter Stringfellow, the Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone, and Luke Johnson of Pizza Express.

Mr Sugar alone warranted a couple of dozen mentions in the Slickers column in the past 12 months, and two of his companies were among Slickers' share tips of the year.

The column has ridden the wave of interest in shares among people who not long ago saw the stock market as the preserve of pinstripes. Punters have piled in via the internet - with the interest sustained by a string of get-rich-quick stories.

And the tabloids, especially the Mirror, have rushed to cater for the passion.

"The [City Slickers] have influence because of course the Mirror is read by a lot of people," said Mike Hines, joint managing director of the stockbroking firm Winterflood Securities.

"It's part of the phenomenon that everyone is becoming interested in stocks and shares. It also has the advantage that if you get a few tips right it becomes a self-fulfiling prophecy - because they move the share price by tipping it."

The paper claims that its 10 tips for 1999 showed a 159% gain over the year.

The growth of tipsters in newspapers and online does however have an invidious side. The Slickers claimed recently to have received hundreds of threats on internet bulletin boards that published Mr Bhoyrul's phone number after the pair suggested investors sell a certain stock.

The new battleground for redtops caused the Sun to strike back. Its editor, David Yelland, tried to poach Cathy Newman from the Financial Times for a column he hoped to call "Better than Lex" - a reference to the FT's comment column that doubtless would have meant little to Sun readers.

When the Sun did launch its City page last month with ex-Mail on Sunday reporter Ian King, the Slickers counterattacked with typical brio - nicknaming him Queenie and adding his picture byline to theirs with the suggestion he was in need of on-the-job training at the Mirror.

webTitle: RSC catches fright at flames in smouldering Chekhov

fields.headline: RSC catches fright at flames in smouldering Chekhov
fields.trailText: The show went on at the Royal Shakespeare Company at Stratford-upon-Avon last night, but without the naked flames which introduced a spectacular curtain line to Tuesday's press night performance of Chekhov's bitter-sweet masterpiece, The Seagull.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The show went on at the Royal Shakespeare Company at Stratford-upon-Avon last night, but without the naked flames which introduced a spectacular curtain line to Tuesday's press night performance of Chekhov's bitter-sweet masterpiece, The Seagull.

"Fire!" said Richard Johnson, playing the worldly, decadent Dorn. "Real fire!" he added, in the face of the obvious bafflement of his fellow actors.

By the time the audience realised that this was not a new element in Peter Gill's translation, a stage hand had rushed on and was quenching a blazing linen curtain. The performance was suspended for 10 minutes while the mess was swept up. The cast then resumed their places to a huge round of applause on a stage which had escaped even being scorched.

But yesterday morning the decision was taken to ban both the naked candles and cigarettes on stage. The use of artificial candles and cigarettes was considered, but ruled out in the intimate space of the Swan Theatre. "Everyone felt it would just look too hideous," company spokesman Ian Rowley said.

The candles, in the set designed by Vicky Mortimer for Adrian Noble's new production, were used to light the stage within a stage on which the younger generation in the play performs an achingly pretentious amateur theatrical. The cigarettes were liberally smoked by their urbane and mocking elders, come down from Moscow to show off in their country estate with ultimately tragic consequences.

It appears that a character leaving the stage early in the first act brushed against the linen sheeting draping the amateurs' stage, so that it was left hanging directly above a candle. The sheet smouldered unobserved before bursting into flames 10 minutes later.

Mr Rowley, who was in the audience, said: "By the time the audience realised something was actually amiss, the stage crew, who were brilliant, had already got the fire out."

Last night's performance went ahead without a flicker of alarm. Fire is taken seriously at Stratford, where the original Victorian theatre burned to the ground in 1926. Yesterday an inquiry began involving the RSC, the Warwickshire fire service and Stratford district council.

webTitle: Debunkers fling pie in eye of the beholder

fields.headline: Debunkers fling pie in eye of the beholder
fields.trailText: Birgit Cunningham's encounter with the agriculture minister is the latest in a line of confectionery attacks, the best-known exponent of which is the Biotic Baking Brigade in the United States.
fields.body:
Birgit Cunningham's encounter with the agriculture minister is the latest in a line of confectionery attacks, the best-known exponent of which is the Biotic Baking Brigade in the United States.

The brigade "pied" Bill Gates, the richest man in the world, and followed up by doing the same for Bob Shapiro, the head of Monsanto. Nobel prize-winning economist Milton Friedman got one in the face, as did Karl Lagerfeld, Ronald McDonald, the head of the World Bank, numerous Canadian and Dutch ministers, several US mayors, the heads of oil, chemical and logging companies, rightwing homophobes, lawyers, state governors, and newspaper magnates.

"Under neo-liberal economic policies we can all thow a pie in the face of fascism," according to Agent Apple of the BBB.

The BBB preaches an "autonomous, diffuse and widespread" global pastry uprising against corporate power, ecological destruction and "worthiness, power and the self-important".

It has struck twice in Britain: in 1998 Ricardo Ruggiero, the former head of the World Trade Organisation, was targeted by environmentalists while in Britain for a meeting; a Welsh BBB "cell" last year chucked a chocolate mousse at the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, because of his links with GM food - it missed.

Political pie throwing has a long history. It took off in Europe in 1973 with a Belgian surrealist, Noel Godin, who famously pied Marilyn Monroe. Its roots go back to 19th century music hall, and it was practised by the Marx Brothers and the Dadaist art movement.

Today "entartement" is mainly a US phenomenon. Activists are "pieing" at least two people a month. Most recipients do not press charges, and let it be known they are mildly amused.

"Under neo-liberal economic policies we can all thow a pie in the face of fascism," according to Agent Apple of the BBB. The BBB preaches an "autonomous, diffuse and widespread" global pastry uprising against corporate power, ecological destruction and "worthiness, power and the self-important". It has struck twice in Britain: in 1998 Ricardo Ruggiero, the former head of the World Trade Organisation, was targeted by environmentalists while in Britain for a meeting; a Welsh BBB "cell" last year chucked a chocolate mousse at the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, because of his links with GM food - it missed. Political pie throwing has a long history. It took off in Europe in 1973 with a Belgian surrealist, Noel Godin, who famously pied Marilyn Monroe. Its roots go back to 19th century music hall, and it was practised by the Marx Brothers and the Dadaist art movement. Today "entartement" is mainly a US phenomenon. Activists are "pieing" at least two people a month. Most recipients do not press charges, and let it be known they are mildly amused.

fields.trailText:
Offers to kidney op victim
At least 19 people have offered to donate a kidney to save the victim of an operation mix-up, Graham Reeves, administrators at Morriston Hospital in Swansea said yesterday.
fields.body:
Offers to kidney op victim
At least 19 people have offered to donate a kidney to save the victim of an operation mix-up, Graham Reeves, administrators at Morriston Hospital in Swansea said yesterday.

Mr Reeves, 69, from Burry Port, is critically ill after a healthy kidney was removed and he was left with a diseased one at Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli, west Wales, last week.

Dancer settles claim early
Dancer Kerstin Parkin, who suffered catastrophic brain damage during the birth of her first child, yesterday settled for a "substantial part" of her £8m damages claim. High court judge Mr Justice Buckley gave Ms Parkin an undisclosed interim payment which will be used by her husband Mark to care for her in a specially adapted home. His total claim for money to cover further treatment for his wife was challenged by Bromley Hospitals NHS Trust.

Scotsman chief steps down
The editor of the Scotsman newspaper has stepped down after two years in the post, it was announced yesterday. Alan Ruddock, 40, will be replaced by deputy editor Tim Luckhurst, who will be acting editor, Scotsman Publications publisher Andrew Neil announced.

Gormenghast figures tumble
Viewing figures for the £6m flagship BBC2 drama series Gormenghast have fallen by nearly a half within a fortnight, it emerged yesterday. While 4.2m people watched the first instalment of the surreal gothic fantasy, the audience had plunged to 2.5m by Monday's third episode.

webTitle: Scottish Opera bosses blamed for cash crisis

fields.headline: Scottish Opera bosses blamed for cash crisis
fields.trailText: Scotland's national opera company was brought to within 24 hours of closure by arrogant and irresponsible management, which failed to appreciate the extent of its financial difficulties.
fields.body:
Scotland's national opera company was brought to within 24 hours of closure by arrogant and irresponsible management, which failed to appreciate the extent of its financial difficulties.

A damning report by the Scottish parliament's culture committee yesterday criticised Scottish Opera's former management for its "arrogant" attitude to the crisis, which brought the company to the brink of collapse, with debts of around £2.5m.

The cross-party report singles out one of the government's key advisers on the arts for particular censure. It says Ruth MacKenzie - then general director of Scottish Opera and now a special adviser to the culture secretary, Chris Smith - failed to meet standards required.

Ms MacKenzie and Scottish Opera's former chairman, Sandy Orr, are accused of neither understanding nor accepting responsibility for the crisis.

In a hugely personal attack, the report accuses Ms MacKenzie and Mr Orr of gauchely running the company on the assumption that the taxpayer would bail them out of financial difficulties.

Mary Mulligan, a Labour MSP and the culture committee's convener, said: "Scottish Opera were a disaster in terms of their financial management and the way they responded to a bad situation."

The full extent of the financial crisis only became apparent last year when the company's interim chief executive, Adrian Tricke. went to the Scottish executive with books showing a £2.5m deficit for Scottish Ballet and Scottish Opera.

The Scottish education minister Sam Galbraith made a one-off payment of £2.1m to save the national company from closure, using money that he later admitted had been set aside to reduce class sizes. The government has been forced to bail out Scottish Opera 11 times in the past three decades.

Scottish Opera has now merged with Scottish Ballet and is run by a joint board. Daniel McGhie, chairman of the new board, said lessons would be learned from the committee's report, but he had no plans to cut back on productions.

The report criticises Ms MacKenzie's handling of the finances of a one-off Edinburgh Festival production of Macbeth, which cost £750,000 when the company was already seriously in debt.

"We believe that there was an attitude within Scottish Opera which simply said budgets don't matter," said Mike Russell, the Scottish National Party spokesman on culture.

In her accounting of Macbeth, Ms MacKenzie used a procedure she has insisted is proper, which shifted the cost from one financial year to the other.

The criticism of Ms MacKenzie comes as an embarrassment to the government, which sought her out for a senior advisory position in the culture department.

Ms MacKenzie was unavailable for comment yesterday, but Mr Orr said the committee had failed to understand how arts were funded in Britain. "There is no substance to any of the extraordinary accusations made against us," he said.

The Scottish Arts Council is criticised for failing to properly supervise budgets and for allowing a culture that presumed government bailouts would be forthcoming. A spokesman said it would now review its procedures for monitoring budgets.

webTitle: Ulster direct rule looms as talks fail

fields.headline: Ulster direct rule looms as talks fail
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland peace process will today be plunged into its gravest crisis when the government restores direct rule over the province, barring an 11th-hour change of heart by the IRA on disarmament.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process will today be plunged into its gravest crisis when the government restores direct rule over the province, barring an 11th-hour change of heart by the IRA on disarmament.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, is expected to outline the move in a Commons statement amid signs that a frantic round of diplomacy involving Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, his Irish counterpart, has failed to produce a breakthrough.

The two prime ministers are expected to mount a final effort to rescue the process this morning when they hold emergency talks during Mr Blair's trip to Devon.

Mr Ahern, the taoiseach, is due to report on his talks with the republican movement in Dublin last night where he issued an appeal to Martin Ferris, a member of the IRA army council, to save the process by making a gesture on arms.

The appeal appeared to have been unsuccessful when the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, said after the talks last night that the Unionist demands for immediate decommissioning were "disastrous".

Mr Blair also struck a pessimistic note in the Commons yesterday when he admitted the IRA had still not agreed to disarm, throwing the peace process into a "serious crisis" that could place lives at risk.

"Let us never forget that there are people now today that, if we don't get this peace process sorted out and moving forward again, will not grow up either in normal conditions and some will not be alive at all," Mr Blair told MPs.

The prime minister is expected to make a final decision on restoring direct rule after his meeting with Mr Ahern this morning.

Pulling the plug on Northern Ireland's first power-sharing executive in 26 years would be a drastic step that would deeply anger Sinn Fein. Mr Adams has warned that such a move would provoke the IRA into withdrawing from General John de Chastelain's decommissioning body, ending any prospect of disarmament.

The Sinn Fein president reiterated his warning last night, saying that restoring direct rule would be a disaster. "If there isn't a political process then it is very difficult to know how matters can be resolved," he said.

However, ministers on both sides of the Irish border have reluctantly come round to the view during the past week that suspending the executive is the only way of preserving the position of the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble.

His resignation as first minister is due to be triggered tomorrow if the IRA fails to begin the process of decommissioning weapons. By freezing the executive ministers will be able to hold out the hope that Mr Trimble could resume office at a later date in the unlikely event of a deal.

The deputy leader of the SDLP, Seamus Mallon, last night issued an impassioned plea to the Unionists and Sinn Fein to hold fire.

"Stand back from the brink that you're standing on now. Stand back from the brink that you're having everybody else standing on. Stand back from the brink and the chasm that faces the entire community," Northern Ireland's deputy first minister said.

But the Ulster Unionist party made clear that it would abandon the executive today unless the IRA begins to disarm. Sir Reg Empey, the party's senior negotiator, said that words from the IRA were no longer enough.

webTitle: Blair's plan for more women MPs

fields.headline: Blair's plan for more women MPs
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is considering changing the law to allow political parties to use all-women shortlists to select parliamentary candidates amid Labour concerns that it could lose its newly-increased share of women's votes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is considering changing the law to allow political parties to use all-women shortlists to select parliamentary candidates amid Labour concerns that it could lose its newly-increased share of women's votes.

In a meeting with Labour's national executive, Mr Blair acknowledged that his party, which has 101 women MPs, had to act to ensure it did not slip back.

After admitting for the first time that he had been a "complete doubter" over the all-female shortlists Labour tried to introduced at the last election, Mr Blair acknowledged: "I do think that the results of that were in fact very important for us at that election."

Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, is pressing him to introduce legislation after the next election to permit all-women shortlists.

Labour's last attempt to use the strategy - introduced under John Smith following pressure from women MPs - was stymied after the all-female lists were ruled illegal.

The party chose not to appeal against the judgment, though many legal advisers felt it was open to challenge.

Ms McDonagh is convinced that action is needed if the party is to apprach is goal of a 50:50 balance of men and women MPs.

However, since there will be no chance of such a legal change before the next election - probably less than 18 months away - the party is having to rely on encouragement and coercion to ensure a respectable number of women candidates in the selection process.

This week, Labour constituency secretaries received a letter from Ms McDonagh reminding them that "the party is committed to increasing the number of women MPs".

Women MPs have been pressing the party high command to recognise that Labour risks jeopardising support from women voters if it is not seen to promote policies directed at women and to prove that the influx of women MPs in the last election was more than a one-off gimmick.

webTitle: Loyalty test: Portillo slips up in praise of Hague

fields.headline: Loyalty test: Portillo slips up in praise of Hague
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo yesterday launched his new shadow cabinet career with a series of robustly loyal statements in support of William Hague's policies on taxation, gay sex and the euro - where both men signalled a new onslaught on Labour's "wait and see" stance.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo yesterday launched his new shadow cabinet career with a series of robustly loyal statements in support of William Hague's policies on taxation, gay sex and the euro - where both men signalled a new onslaught on Labour's "wait and see" stance.

The new shadow chancellor is on his best behaviour, but not even he could avoid a Freudian slip. On GMTV he said his leader's position was "absolutely unassailable".

As every Westminster politician knows "unassailable" has been a non-word ever since Margaret Thatcher said it of her chancellor, Nigel Lawson, shortly before he walked out of cabinet in 1989. Labour MPs seized on it with glee.

Mr Hague, who was wrong-footed by mixed party reaction to his latest "definitive" reshuffle, also moved yesterday to iron out potential difficulties between Mr Portillo and Francis Maude, the new shadow foreign secretary, whose treasury post he took. Mr Maude will be in sole charge of European policy, he announced, after Mr Portillo rejected suggestions that he is against UK membership of the single currency under any circumstances. Mr Hague is committed against joining the euro only for five years, as Tony Blair reminded MPs at question time yesterday.

Mr Portillo was unabashed. "The proper position is for us in the next manifesto to be against the euro, so that people know that if they want to save the pound, there is only one way to do it and that is to vote for the Conservative party," he said.

Fielding questions more deftly on Radio 4's Today programme Mr Portillo told its chattering class audience that he is all for sexual tolerance, but that Mr Hague is right to resist repeal of section 28 because "it implies you approve of homosexuality".

Not even "trendy" liberals go that far, Mr Portillo suggested. "My guess is that Tony Blair is deeply regretting that he ever got himself into that mire," he added.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
It's known as taxonomy, finding appropriate names for the thousands of new species still regularly uncovered by modern research. It looked simple enough in 1758 when Carl Linnaeus first drew up the rules which classify us as Homo sapiens and the cowslip as Primula veris . Sadly, Linnaeus not only got a lot wrong but couldn't possibly have foreseen discoveries like the virus. So, as Quentin Reynolds reports for The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4), the system may be due for an overhaul.

Once we get into the euro-referendum it's worth recalling Tommy Tucker, one of the Foreign Office's most talented backroom boys. He stayed firmly in the shadows but penned most of the letters and speeches supporting the Heath government's 1970 moves to get Britain into Europe. In Document (8.0pm, Radio 4) Christopher Cook recalls the IRD's clandestine campaign, and the useful backing it received from MI6.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
The Go-Between (Joseph Losey, 1972) 4pm, Sky Cinema

LP Hartley's novel of doomed love as adapted by Harold Pinter: the strength of the film is less in the drama than the perfect evocation of time, place, and social milieu: pre-Great War, rural Norfolk. Julie Christie and Alan Bates are the class-defying lovers; Edward Fox the horrified upper-class gent and Dominic Guard the hapless boy in the title role.

Keep The Aspidistra Flying (Robert Bierman, 1997) 6am, 2pm Sky Premier

Bierman's adaptation of George Orwell's novel about young poet Gordon Comstock's limp rebellion against the class system and the literary establishment is a quaint period piece. It's a handsomely mounted vision of the 30s, by turn elegant and squalid. Richard E Grant makes a convincingly sullen, sexually frustrated Comstock, Helena Bonham Carter the nice middle-class girl who won't. But all his railing about his Art in the cruel copywriting world seems far away and long ago.

The Quick And The Dead (Sam Raimi, 1995) 10pm, FilmFour

Raimi's homage to Sergio Leone is more fun than it sounds. Sharon Stone's woman-with-no-name is about as Eastwood as a woman can be, complete with poncho and cee-gar, she is a lethal contender in a 16-gun prize shootout in the two-bit town of Redemption. Quick-draw cast includes Gene Hackman's bad guy, Leonardo DiCaprio his son, and Russell Crowe as Stone's lover.

Gothic (Ken Russell, 1986) 3am, Bravo

At a villa on Lake Geneva in 1816, Lord Byron hosts Shelley, his lover Mary Godwin, her half-sister Claire and Byron's biographer, Dr Polidori. Over an increasingly stormy weekend there is much Russelling: passion, laudanum-drinking and seancing, with demonic consequences; and Mary gets to write her novel, Frankenstein. A fun, but preposterously over-the top piece of gothic self-indulgence. Starring Gabriel Byrne, Julian Sands and Natasha Richardson.

webTitle: Norman at bay over links to firms

fields.headline: Norman at bay over links to firms
fields.standfirst:
New shadow environment secretary gives up directorship but still faces charges of conflict of interest

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Archie Norman, the new shadow environment secretary, yesterday gave up his directorship of Railtrack but sparked fresh charges of conflict of interest over his continuing links with Asda and his own company Knutsford.
fields.body:
Archie Norman, the new shadow environment secretary, yesterday gave up his directorship of Railtrack but sparked fresh charges of conflict of interest over his continuing links with Asda and his own company Knutsford.

As Mr Norman made clear that he would not sell his 10% shareholding in Knutsford, a money-spinning takeover vehicle, Labour and the Liberal Democrats stepped up attacks, claiming that the former supermarket whizzkid's extensive business interests would clash directly with his new brief covering environment, transport and the regions.

The multi-millionaire businessman, who was appointed to the shadow cabinet on Tuesday in a surprise Conservative reshuffle, also faced mockery from opponents when it emerged that he would not lead a Tory-instigated Commons debate last night on greenfield development - an issue at the core of his environmental portfolio.

John Prescott, the environment secretary and deputy prime minister, ridiculed William Hague, saying the appointment of Mr Norman was the worst example of the Tory leader's "appalling judgment". He claimed Mr Norman would be "strangled by conflicts of interest at every turn".

Meanwhile, John Redwood, ousted as environment spokesman to make way for Mr Norman, made clear his "great shock" at his sacking in a handwritten letter to Mr Hague.

Allies of Mr Redwood insisted that he intended to remain loyal, but there were expressions of sympathy from both wings of his party and outrage within his Wokingham constituency party.

There were rumours, too, that Mr Norman had secured his promotion after warning Mr Hague that he would otherwise quit and return to business.

After pressure from Labour and the Liberal Democrats after his appointment, Mr Norman yesterday announced he would step down immediately as a non-executive director of Railtrack, a post he had held since 1994. He will also sell his shares in the company.

However, though Asda yesterday said the MP was no longer on its payroll as a paid consultant, Conservative central office later said both sides were still "in talks" over Mr Norman's contract to act as a paid consultant until June this year. He is expected to leave the post.

Mr Norman, who recently resigned as Asda chairman after turning round the ailing supermarket chain, also remains a director of and share holder in Knutsford, the shell company he helped set up to take over other businesses.

Shares in the company plummeted yesterday amid City fears that he would have less time for searching out investment targets.

Mr Norman is one of four partners - known as the "awesome foursome" - in Knutsford, which was linked with a possible takeover bid for Marks & Spencer.

Central office said last night that he had no plans to step down from Knutsford or from the chairmanship of French plc, a small textile firm. He would reconsider if a conflict of interest arose, central office added.

The multi-millionaire businessman, who was appointed to the shadow cabinet on Tuesday in a surprise Conservative reshuffle, also faced mockery from opponents when it emerged that he would not lead a Tory-instigated Commons debate last night on greenfield development - an issue at the core of his environmental portfolio. fields.headline: Just keep talking
fields.standfirst: Jim White has decided to come out of the closet. Until now, the world has known him as a writer and broadcaster. But he's ready to admit the truth: he's a pundit, and he's proud of it. And if you fancy a share of the action, he has a few tips
fields.trailText: Jim White has decided to come out of the closet. Until now, the world has known him as a writer and broadcaster. But he's ready to admit the truth: he's a pundit, and he's proud of it. And if you fancy a share of the action, he has a few tips
fields.body:
One thing about being a pundit, no one ever calls you that on air. Notice how Lynda Lee Potter is referred to as "the writer and journalist" when she appears on Any Questions to disseminate a world view which makes Jack Straw look a Hampstead liberal. Or how Tony Parsons is introduced as "the novelist and writer" as he prepares to deconstruct cultural offerings. Or the way in which David Starkey, a serial occupier of the punditry pulpit, is described as "the historian" - except when he is called upon to be rude about the royal family, when it is always "the constitutional historian".

Yet we all know what punditry is: the game of providing slanted views for those anxious to maintain a façade of even-handedness. Convention demands that radio or television presenters cannot have an opinion. But since opinions are what the public is deemed to want, producers trawl newspapers for someone less coy about letting the world know what they think. On any subject - from Tony Blair's first 1,000 days to David Beckham's underwear - there will be someone whose opinion will be sought. And occasionally it isn't Boris Johnson.

It is, therefore, a calling that deserves to be recognised by its own title: sing it out, sing it loud, we are pundits and we are proud. Besides, the sheer number of media outlets means that the punditry market is growing so vast, soon there won't be time to be anything other than a pundit. Every day, for instance, the licence fees of several score pensioners are absorbed ferrying pundits in to fill the blank acreage of the BBC News 24 schedule. At any moment, the foyer at Television Centre is awash with the opinionated waiting for BBC taxis to transport them on to their next appointment at Sky News, GMTV, or the Ann Diamond Show at LBC.

Crack it and there is a whole career out there: news bulletins, documentaries, and for the lucky few the very apex of punditry: laughing at Paul Merton's jokes on Have I Got News For You. So, how do you become a pundit? How do you leap aboard a train so awash with gravy it makes the EU express to Strasbourg look ascetic?

In sport it helps if you once played the game - Alan Hansen and Ian Botham have both proven that an ability to hack a ball into row Z does not necessarily preclude you from stringing two or three coherent sentences together. Oddly, in politics, Matthew Parris and Roy Hattersley apart, former practitioners are not welcome. Because there is little chance the presenter will be able to shut them up. In other fields having a degree of expertise can be useful, but it is best not to specialise too tightly. I recall seeing the editor of a magazine devoted entirely to pre-stressed concrete enjoying one of the high points of punditry - being told to "get on with it" by Jeremy Paxman on Newsnight.

Since that appearance discussing the quality of Iraqi bunkers during the Gulf War, however, he has not been a frequent sight on screen. And, though it might seem unlikely to regular viewers of This Morning With Richard And Judy, those wishing to make the leap from mere journalism need to pass some low-level competence hurdles. Sweating, stumbling and swearing are frowned upon, except late at night on Channel 4. Also, it is important to sound authoritative.

To those who have never heard her, Julie Burchill might be thought of as a natural pundit. But the columnist whose every sentence oozes opinion, is rarely invited to broadcast. Not got the voice for it is the received opinion - though, as one of her many fans, I don't think the punditry potential of 200 words per minute delivered in a Bristolian accent via a Minnie Mouse shriek has been fully explored.

Thus armed with opinions, a dusting of specialist knowledge and the right voice (Scottish borders is ideal), the pundit is primed. At this point, it is important not to be too proud: never turn down an offer of work; wedding anniversaries, the birth of first offspring, the next episode of Castaway 2000 can wait, you might never be asked onto Radio Solent again. And though it might not at first seem a match for the Today programme, such a platform represents valuable experience, those £15 fee cheques add up and there is always the chance a producer at BBC News 24 is listening on his way home. From such humble beginnings has many a punditry career blossomed - though off-hand I can't think of any.

Just one word of warning: if you wish to preserve that vital tool of the pundit - self-regard - steer clear of phone-ins. In the early days of Talk Radio, I was occasionally asked to provide punditry on a late-night phone-in and discovered the callers invariably sounded more articulate and better informed than me. It didn't take the producers long to realise there was little point paying for a pundit when there were dozens of them out there whose opinions could be had for free. Which represents a true Warholian democracy: thanks to the phone-in, everyone can be a pundit for 15 minutes.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Great Undertakings 9pm, C4

Undertakers are often feared and misunderstood but, unless you've planned a DIY funeral, they're quite indispensable. Without getting morbid, this six-part series takes an intimate and sympathetic view of that unenviable job. In the opener, Peter and Billy Grant have just lost their mother, Phyllis, and call on the funeral directors who buried their father 15 years previously. Every care is taken to ensure the sons are able to bury their mother in full Caribbean style, giving the less-than-beautiful White City estate in west London a warm and lively spectacle.

Horizon 9.30pm, BBC2

Gloom merchants are always predicting the end of the world, but a recent discovery by scientists heralds, if not the end, then a huge global catastrophe that could be waiting in the wings. The vast Yellowstone National Park in the western United States is home to an enormous supervolcano, which looks, from the surface, like a big crater. Research shows that the effects of the previous blows wiped out huge numbers of both animals and humans, and it is estimated it lets itself go every 600,000 or so years. And when was the last one? Er, about 600,000 years ago.

Dispatches 9.30pm, C4

There's altruism, and then there's selflessness on an almost imaginable scale. In a case of the latter, Ron Johnson made the headlines recently when he responded to a stranger's plea for someone to save his daughter's life. It merely involved the donation of part of a lung, which Johnson agreed to do. He had never met the 10-year-old Israeli girl who was dying of cystic fibrosis, but a previous visit to the memorial at Auschwitz must have left a sense of guilt which this possibly could help to assuage, he admits. His story is unusual but there could come a time when it would be commonplace, as doctors say there is an acute shortage of organ donors and more live donors are needed to save a long list of patients.

fields.headline: Trust me, I'm a hunk
fields.trailText: ER | Soap Secrets 2 | Surrogate Babies
fields.body:
The first law of Hollywood is called The Backdraft Principle, and states that the quickest way to win the heart of the audience with a male lead is to have him carry a small child out of a burning building.

ER (C4) applied this trusty axiom to Luke, "the new George Clooney", who made his entrance by zeroing in on little-girl-lost in the car park, picking her up in his strong Slovenian arms, and striding manfully into the show.

Nurse Hathaway was suitably impressed, offering suture and swabs at eight second intervals. The little girl appeared to have a life-threatening scratch on her finger, so Luke and Hathaway borrowed one of those cosy rooms they have for soft-lit stitching and began to play doctors and nurses.

Apart from securing a replacement for Doug, Hathaway used episode one of the new series to further her transformation from Sister Of Mercy to Angel Of Death. Three seconds after walking out of a coffee shop, a lorry ploughs through the window and kills all the people who were rude to her in the queue. Last series, Hathaway walked into a drugstore to buy some tissues and Ewan McGregor burst in, wielding a submachine gun.

Aside from the usual Caligulan machinations, the ER extras were all out in force: the man with a minor injury who can't wait to get served; the sinful patient who atones just before the end credits to the priest-like Benton.

New hunk Luke, meanwhile, refused to let go of the little girl he'd picked up in the opening scene. "I'm a doctor", he explained after 20 minutes - which doesn't sound so convincing in the week of Harold Shipman. Hathaway seemed unconcerned, and her love only grew as she spied Luke carefully washing out used bandages and syringes - ahhh - because he comes from Kosovo. The fact that you could pick up an ex-doctor from the Eastern Bloc driving any cab in Chicago seemed to have passed Carol by.

When Peter Kingsman sits in his living room in Essex, he can see 70 photos of Noel Gordon at any one time. "That's me with Nolly on the set in 1974. It doesn't look like me, does it?" largely because Peter was 14. Not 40, with no hair. On Soap Secrets 2 (ITV), Peter shared his sociopathic passion for Crossroads by showing an uninterested Dale Winton the full panoply of his obsession: the furniture bought in a job-lot from the set when the show was axed; the actual motel sign, parked in the driveway to provide a Traveller's Welcome Home each night.

Unlike the cast of Crossroads, who got the bus fare and one of Shoey's burnt scones for their efforts, "today's soap stars" - as Dale relentlessly referred to them - earn an average £80,000 a year, with ten grand a throw for opening a supermarket, and fifteen for just one week in Aladdin.

Ten grand was the precise sum that Belinda and Andy, hopeful parents of Surrogate Babies (BBC1) needed to pay for their baby. Opening a supermarket wasn't an option, so they had to sell their house instead.

Surrogate Babies took the prize for mother of all documentary ideas and proved why it can cut to the heart each time it's reworked. Belinda and Andy kept a bottle of champagne under the stairs, waiting to open it when they conceived their first child. It had been sitting there for 11 years.

Marsha lived in a mining village, so desperate for money that she'd decided to rent her womb.

Signed up to Britain's sole agency - the cloyingly named COTS, run by two women out of a League Of Gentlemen-style bungalow in the Scottish Highlands - Marsha and her daughter were posted to London, waiting in best clothes at Victoria Bus Station to meet the middle-class couple who were buying, Paul and Michelle.

Here were class and money and hope and blood and the sheer weirdness of the whole spectacle of surrogacy, all wrapped up in one killer punch. Paul arrived, wearing a Mekon T-shirt, a green foetal shape embossed in plastic. Marsha gave him the once over and he looked at her daughter.

On the South Coast, living in another lifeless bungalowed town, Jill waited in her mum's house to hand over her third surrogate child to an expectant couple, who were waiting in a Volvo outside. She held her baby boy for the last time, weeping silently as the couple explained that "'thank you' is not the right word" to say to Jill. You got that right. COTS notepaper was headed "The Ultimate Gift" with little teddy bears round the words.

webTitle: Bring down the wrath of God on evil men

fields.headline: Bring down the wrath of God on evil men
fields.standfirst: David Hambling  investigates the ultimate psychological weapon - the voice of the Lord
fields.trailText: David Hambling investigates the ultimate psychological weapon - the voice of the Lord
fields.body:
We are in Baghdad in 1991, and something strange is happening. A hush falls over the city as a huge shimmering face materialises in the sky. Soldiers and citizens prostrate themselves as each hears the voice of Allah coming from within, commanding them to overthrow the evil and treacherous Saddam Hussein. Within minutes an angry mob is storming the palace as the guards flee...

This highly imaginative scenario was proposed by US Air Force planners for a bloodless victory in the Gulf conflict. The idea of putting words in God's mouth is not new. Back in the second century AD Lucian described a statue of the god Aesculapius which spoke to believers, aided by a hidden priest with a speaking tube.

The Baghdad plan involved projecting a giant hologram over Iraq. This kind of projection requires a mirror behind it, and the scale of the project dictated a mirror several miles across up in space. Orbital mirrors have to be extremely lightweight, so the construction is based around a very a thin sheet of metallised plastic. It is folded for launch; once in orbit it unfurls itself like a giant umbrella. So far the largest mirror has been 30 metres wide, but the present versions are too small to produce a convincing image at ground level.

Another approach would be to make a mirror out of thin air. When warm air lies on top of cold air, the difference in density is enough to bend light. This causes the familiar illusory puddles in the road on a hot day. At higher altitudes, a mirage can make whole landscapes appear in the sky, an effect known as fata morgana. An artificial mirage could in theory be made by heating the atmosphere with radio waves or microwaves.

The military certainly appears to believe in the potential use of holograms. A USAF think-tank has devised uses ranging from deceptive holographic imaging to the Star Trek sounding distortion field projector. These are described as useful for strategic deception purposes, particularly against an unsophisticated adversary. They would be projected by a special aircraft, the airborne hologram projector. Perhaps the nearest current equivalent is the Commando Solo, a modified Hercules festooned with aerials and antennae and carrying pods of classified electronics. Flown by the 193rd Special Operations Detachment ("We fire electrons, not bullets"), it has been involved in the Gulf and the Bosnia and Kosovo conflicts. Commando Solos equipment can transmit across the electromagnetic spectrum including radio and television signals. Its other capabilities include jamming, deception and manipulation techniques.

T he face of God is not enough on its own. A voice is needed. A new technique using microwaves could produce this. When a high power microwave pulse strikes the human body, a small temperature perturbation occurs. This causes an expansion of tissue which can create an acoustic wave. A report from the USAF scientific advisory board says: "With a pulse stream, an internal acoustic field of 5-15KHz can be created which is audible. Thus it may be possible to 'talk' to adversaries in a way which would be most disturbing to them."

The practical difficulties involved in microwave transmission are formidable. The exact sound perceived depends on the size and shape of the skull of the hearer and their orientation to the source. Microwaves can be reflected or damped by solid objects, so there is a risk that God's voice will have the underwater quality of poor radio reception. And would you believe in a God whose voice drops off when you walk behind a lamp-post?

Although the plan had major technical hurdles to overcome, the main reasons for rejecting it were cultural. Images of Allah are forbidden in Islam. How can you project an image of God when nobody knows what He is supposed to look like?

There is also a fundamental problem with psychology. The plan has Boys' Own Paper view of foreigners as being conveniently superstitious savages, prone to fleeing at the sound of a disembodied voice from a gramophone. This may have been the case in some places a century ago, but the citizens of Baghdad are by no means backward. They have satellite dishes and VCRs like the rest of the world.

People have been exposed to years of sophisticated computer-generated imagery and flashy special effects. If the image of God did appear in the heavens, someone would be bound to look up at the wavering image and suggest that it was all done with mirrors.

These are described as useful for strategic deception purposes, particularly against an unsophisticated adversary. They would be projected by a special aircraft, the airborne hologram projector. Perhaps the nearest current equivalent is the Commando Solo, a modified Hercules festooned with aerials and antennae and carrying pods of classified electronics. Flown by the 193rd Special Operations Detachment ("We fire electrons, not bullets"), it has been involved in the Gulf and the Bosnia and Kosovo conflicts. Commando Solos equipment can transmit across the electromagnetic spectrum including radio and television signals. Its other capabilities include jamming, deception and manipulation techniques. T he face of God is not enough on its own. A voice is needed. A new technique using microwaves could produce this. When a high power microwave pulse strikes the human body, a small temperature perturbation occurs. This causes an expansion of tissue which can create an acoustic wave. A report from the USAF scientific advisory board says: "With a pulse stream, an internal acoustic field of 5-15KHz can be created which is audible. Thus it may be possible to 'talk' to adversaries in a way which would be most disturbing to them." The practical difficulties involved in microwave transmission are formidable. The exact sound perceived depends on the size and shape of the skull of the hearer and their orientation to the source. Microwaves can be reflected or damped by solid objects, so there is a risk that God's voice will have the underwater quality of poor radio reception. And would you believe in a God whose voice drops off when you walk behind a lamp-post? Although the plan had major technical hurdles to overcome, the main reasons for rejecting it were cultural. Images of Allah are forbidden in Islam. How can you project an image of God when nobody knows what He is supposed to look like? There is also a fundamental problem with psychology. The plan has Boys' Own Paper view of foreigners as being conveniently superstitious savages, prone to fleeing at the sound of a disembodied voice from a gramophone. This may have been the case in some places a century ago, but the citizens of Baghdad are by no means backward. They have satellite dishes and VCRs like the rest of the world. People have been exposed to years of sophisticated computer-generated imagery and flashy special effects. If the image of God did appear in the heavens, someone would be bound to look up at the wavering image and suggest that it was all done with mirrors.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Super ant | World's greatest slowcoach
fields.body:
The ant that ate New Orleans
It eats live oaks. It eats telephone poles treated with creosote and underground traffic light switchboxes. It eats the seals on high pressure water lines. It eats whole wharves. The Formosan termite Coptotermes formosanus costs New Orleans $100,000 per city block and will soon cost the US $1bn a year, says the university of Georgia's Mark Hunter, in the Bulletin of the Royal Entomological Society. It could be, he says, the most imortant structural pest of the new millennium. The greedy white ant is an order of magnitude more ferocious than the European termite now gnawing away at some houses in Devon, says Paul Eggleton of the Natural History Museum. "It's a horrible termite, and it gets everywhere. And it is superdestructive. It is a particularly nasty one," he says. "It eats wood. It will chew its way through anything to get to wood."

My mate marmot
Yesterday was the Christian festival of Candlemas. It was also Groundhog Day. American marmots emerge from months of hibernation, blink, look for a shadow and duck back again. The ancient European tradition was brought to America from Germany, where farmers decided that if a hedgehog (or some say badger) saw its shadow at Candlemas there would be six more weeks of winter. Greg Florant of Cororado state university isn't so sure. He believes it is a surplus of linolenic acid that rouses the little groundhog and sets it searching for food at about this time. He's off to Austria this spring to check his theory by measuring fat and prostaglandin metabolism in Alpine marmots, and the role that such molecules play in biological signalling.

Go slow, take the tubeworm
Marine biologists have identified the world's greatest slowcoach. The lamellibranch or tubeworm thrives around fleeting hydrothermal vents that discharge superheated mineral brines on the ocean floor. The tubeworm that that lives off oils seeps in the cooler Louisiana continental slope grows to a length of two metres. But it takes between 170 and 250 years to do so, and that's a conservative estimate, according to a team from Pennsylvania state university, in Nature today. "This amazingly slow growth is in marked contrast to that of its vent relatives, who are among the fastest growing invertebrates on the planet," they report.

A case for the spin doctors
Humans have virtually no memory for the way things spin, according to two psychologists at the university of Texas. David Gildern and Christy Price showed 48 students a series of objects looming large or small on the screen or crossing it, or spinning on it, and then quizzed them. Memory was good for looming and movement across the screen, but no better than chance for spin. If the complexity of the image on the retin has anything to do with brain effort, memory for looming would be the same as for rotating. But it wasn't. Dr Gilden reckons that in a hunter-hunted existence, it would help to understand that another animal looming larger on its retina could be an approaching predator. But nothing in evolutionary history that made it vital to know how things spin.

fields.headline: Under the volcano
fields.standfirst: An eruption once nearly wiped out the human race.  Bill McGuire  reports
fields.trailText: An eruption once nearly wiped out the human race. Bill McGuire reports
fields.body:
Volcanoes are unique among natural hazards in that they can kill, maim, and destroy in a remarkably diverse number of unpleasant ways. Although for most people volcanoes mean one thing only - flows of molten lava - these are actually the least dangerous of all volcanic phenomena and are formed during the quietest volcanic events known as effusive eruptions.

Lavas are highly effective in bulldozing buildings and roads and inundating agricultural land but rarely kill. Most move so slowly that one can simply walk away from them. The really nasty volcanic hazards are generated during much more violent explosive blasts that are sometimes energetic enough to shatter a volcano entirely, sending gigantic plumes of gas and debris into the stratosphere.

The reason some volcanoes explode with such violence is that the molten magma that feeds them is particularly rich in gas - mainly steam, but also containing carbon dioxide and sulphur gases. While the magma remains beneath the surface, this gas remains dissolved in the liquid magma, rather like the carbon dioxide in a bottle of soda before the cap is broken. In the same way that bubbles pop into existence and froth upwards when the bottle cap is removed, so the gas contained in a body of magma forms bubbles that explode outwards and upwards when the seal on a simmering volcano is broken.

The amount of energy involved is trillions of times greater, and within fractions of a second the bubbles rip the magma to shreds and blast it tens of kilometres into the atmosphere faster than a Concorde. The magma fragments may pour down the flanks of the volcano as hurricane-force blasts of superheated gas and semi-molten ash known as pyroclastic flows or be carried far and wide to rain down as ash hundreds or even thousands of kilometres away. Shock waves from the blast may flatten everything within thousands of square kilometres while rains triggered by the eruption turn the ash into destructive torrents of mud.

Around 50 volcanoes explode every year, but their impact is normally confined to the vicinity of the blast. About every hundred years on average - a volcano explodes with enough violence to hurl its sulphur gases into the stratosphere where they slowly spread out across the planet, cutting out some of the sun's radiation and lowering surface temperatures. In this way the 1991 eruption of Pinatubo in the Philippines cooled the Earth by about half a degree Celsius, while the 1815 blast of the Indonesian volcano, Tambora, led to the bitterly cold "Year without a summer" in North America and Europe. Volcanologists have known for some time that even the Tambora catastrophe pales into insignificance beside the greatest volcanic explosions.

Fortunately only a couple of these super-eruptions occur every hundred millennia. Somewhat worryingly, however, the last great blast was over 70,000 years ago when a super-volcano blew its top at Toba in Sumatra. The gases contained in the magma beneath this part of Indonesia were under such incredible pressures that in perhaps less than a day they blasted out enough debris to bury greater London - from Slough in the west to Romford in the east - to a depth four times the height of Canary Wharf.

Along with the gigantic volumes of ash, sulphur gases were blasted more than 50 kilometres into the stratosphere, where they mixed with atmospheric water to form up to five billion tonnes of sulphuric acid.

As the sun struggled to penetrate a global veil of dust and acid, temperatures plummeted by perhaps five degrees Celsius and the planet was plunged for years into deepest volcanic winter. Recent biological evidence paints a terrifying picture of how our ancestors fared.

Examination of mitochondrial DNA from human cells shows that it varies much less than expected across the peoples of the Earth. In other words all humans, whatever their race or colour, are - genetically speaking - very similar, much more so than they should be given the length of time they have lived on the planet.

The horrifying explanation for this is that around the time of the great Toba blast, human beings were almost wiped out. Only a few thousand survived from which all six billion souls on planet Earth are descended. Whether or not the appalling legacy of Toba was responsible for taking our race to the brink of extinction remains to be confirmed, but this apocalyptic blast is the best candidate we have.

With the next super-eruption technically overdue, perhaps the government should be looking not to the stars but beneath our feet for the source of the next global catastrophe.

Supervolcanoes is broadcast as part of the BBC2 Horizon series at 9.30pm tonight

 Bill McGuire is the Benfield Greig professor of geohazards and director of the Benfield Greig Hazard Research Centre at University College London. His new book Apocalypse: A Natural History Of Global Disasters is published in paperback by Cassell at £14.99

fields.headline: Rock on
fields.standfirst: Douglas Palmer  on the rescue from extinction of Britain's unique records of its geological anatomy
fields.trailText: Douglas Palmer on the rescue from extinction of Britain's unique records of its geological anatomy
fields.body:
Britain is the only country to have its prehistoric rock record legally protected. A network of more than 2,300 geological Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSIs) has been chalked up to describe our unique geological heritage.

It is also the only country to systematically record its rock record on tablets of stone and publish the results. Recently, the whole enterprise very nearly collapsed when the publisher, Chapman Hall, was bought by the Dutch publishing empire of Kluwer.

But the Joint Nature Conservation Committee (JNCC) took on the publication of the remainder of the series. The first of the JNCC produced volumes, British Tertiary Stratigraphy (volume 15 in the Geological Conservation Review series) has just been published.

The testimony of our SSSI rocks tells the incredible story of the geological anatomy and foundation of these islands, which has been cobbled together over more than a billion years. The industrial revolution was founded on our coal, ore minerals and limestone. And we are still dependent on geological materials to the tune of over £29bn worth of traded goods each year.

Only in the last decade or so have geologists been able to make real sense of our rock heritage. But outside the academic world, few people realise that 500 million years ago (in late Cambrian times), there were no British Isles as we know them today. Britain was split in two with an ocean called Iapetus separating the halves. Southern Britain was part of North Africa and lay near the South Pole.

On the other side of Iapetus, nearer the Equator, lay northern Britain, joined to North America. Then around 400 million years ago, the Iapetus Ocean was shut down as southern Britain broke away from Africa, swept northwards and crashed into North America. The collision threw up the Caledonian mountains and formed the geological basis of the British Isles.

Today British rocks range from the northernmost 380 million-year-old red sandstones of Orkney and John O'Groats to the southernmost Quaternary age landforms and deposits of the Scilly Isles, just a few tens of thousands of years old. The rocks of these small islands of Britain record an unusually good sample of the last billion years. Many of our geological sites are of international importance.

All over the world, rock strata that record the history of the Earth between 545 and 354 million years ago are referred to periods of geological time which were first recognised and named in Britain. The Cambrian Period (from 545 to 495 million years ago) is from the Latin name for Wales and was founded on the strata and fossils of North Wales. They were named by Adam Sedgwick, a Cambridge professor, friend of Wordsworth and Darwin's tutor in geology. The Devonian Period (417 to 354 million years ago) was also named by Sedgwick and Roderick Murchison, a young gentleman geologist and ex-military man who had fought at Corunna in the Peninsular wars. The rocks of our SSSIs have also provided some of the oldest known fossil fish (Orkney), reptiles (Edinburgh), dinosaurs (Sussex), mammals (Bristol) and land plants (Herefordshire).

Much of our understanding of the effects of global warming, is derived from the ice age events of the past two and a half million years. Their history is recorded in the landforms of upland Britain and glacially derived sediments of the lowlands (such as the Scilly Isles).

Britain played a seminal role in the 19th-century development of geology. Reminiscent of the great Victorian blue books, the Geological Conservation Review (GCR) series will comprise 42 volumes. Sixteen have been published, three are in press and the remaining 23 have been commissioned.

The most recent, British Tertiary Stratigraphy, details the network of 58 SSSIs that record life and environments between 65 and 2.6 million years old. During this time, the North Atlantic Ocean was opening up as North America moved away from Europe. Huge volcanoes in the west of Scotland poured out lavas, many hundreds of metres thick, over the landscape. Global climates were at least 10 degrees warmer than now (the London area gently simmered with mean annual temperatures of between 20C and 25C) and sea levels were significantly higher.

Shallow seas flooding over the south of England were crammed with fish, sharks, rays, crocodiles, turtles, snakes, corals and clams. The coastline was fringed with mangroves, reed swamps and palms. Inland there was lush semitropical rainforest full of newly evolved mammals and birds. This rich tapestry has been reconstructed over the past 200 years by amateur and professional geologists from sites such as today's uninspiring foreshore muds of Herne Bay and the Isle of Sheppey in the Thames estuary.

The geological richness of these sites gives them an international importance and SSSI status. And, several of our most important offshore oil and gas fields (e.g. Frigg, Forties, Montrose) are hosted in Tertiary age sediments. Over the past 12 years, the Frigg Field has produced more than 20 million cubic metres of gas and the Montrose Field over 90 million tonnes of oil. Rocks still have economic clout.

 Information about GCR publications from the GCR Unit, JNCC, Monkstone House, Peterborough PE1 1JY. Books from NHBS Mailorder Bookstore (tel 01803 865913, email cuserv@nhbs.co.uk and www.nhbs.com prices from £50-£150. Douglas Palmer is the author of Atlas of the Prehistoric World (Marshall Publishing and Discovery Channel)

webTitle: Dewar's dream job turns into a nightmare

fields.headline: Dewar's dream job turns into a nightmare
fields.standfirst:
Scotland 'Weak' leader has no plans to step down

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The shine is wearing off Labour's devolution dream in Scotland. A catalogue of internal crises, policy fumbles and accusations of serious misjudgment have left the man once regarded as the safest pair of hands in Scottish politics reeling. Donald Dewar is on the ropes and Downing Street may yet have to come to his aid.
fields.body:
The shine is wearing off Labour's devolution dream in Scotland. A catalogue of internal crises, policy fumbles and accusations of serious misjudgment have left the man once regarded as the safest pair of hands in Scottish politics reeling. Donald Dewar is on the ropes and Downing Street may yet have to come to his aid.

It was not supposed to be like this. When the new parliament opened to great fanfare last spring, Labour believed they had really delivered. But now, as hardly a week goes by without fresh calamity befalling Mr Dewar's administration, there is growing dismay that the dream has been allowed to sour. "We just watch with bemusement," said one Westminster minister. "There is real frustration that the good things that are being done by the government are being eclipsed by all these fiascos in Scotland."

The problems are manifold. In the last week alone one of Mr Dewar's key aides was forced to resign over two drink driving offences, one in Glasgow's red light area; another came under pressure to resign; and a third was forced to publicly apologise to a fourth - who was himself forced out last year. Then there is the outcry over the handling of the section 28 repeal, the fall-out in England over the deal struck on student tuition fees; and very real fears that it could all mean a trouncing for Labour in the crucial forthcoming Ayr byelection.

Tony Blair is said to be increasingly worried and his trip north next month is seen by some as an attempt to convince Scots that home rule can work. Meanwhile, those who would succeed Mr Dewar are said to be positioning themselves to strike. It has been suggested, if officially denied, that the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has his eye on the first minister's job. There is also talk of appointing a deputy to try and shore up Mr Dewar, and, for the first time rumblings of discontent about his leadership are emerging from those closest to him.

"The realities of being first minister have come as a great shock to him," said one colleague. "Donald felt very secure as secretary of state for Scotland; he was well protected and well-supported. But I feel he is really quite weak now. He handles conflict so badly. He just runs away. I think he could become so depressed and jaded if another series of things happen when he might say at some point enough."

Mr Dewar rejects such notions out of hand. In recent days he has gone on the offensive, stressing he has no plans to step aside. "Don't listen to gossip," he says tersely. "It's a very different job. It's a more satisfying job. It is one that I suppose if I'm being honest that I have dreamt of; and I'm not a great dreamer."

He admits the past few weeks have been a particularly difficult time. "It's the old, old cry of, 'events, dear boy, events,'" said Mr Dewar. "I take these matters seriously but what counts is the progress you are making with your programme and the confidence that you have in colleagues and they have in you." He is particularly proud of the deal carved from the Cubie report into higher education funding, and moulded to keep the coalition pact with the Liberal Democrats in place, despite deep disquiet in Westminster about the ramifications of the scheme outside Scotland. "I think it is a progressive scheme, imaginative and well worked out and it has been praised by a lot of figures in higher education. Our opponents said this was the rock on which we would perish and we certainly have not perished."

The relatively simple aim of repealing Section 28, meanwhile, has grown into a monumental policy dispute. A heated campaign to keep the clause, which bans promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools, has forced the executive onto the defensive. Mr Dewar denies he misjudged the public mood.

"Some of the reaction has been based on honest misunderstanding," he said. "We said from the beginning, from the first day, that proper safeguards have to be in place."

Despite all the sniping, Mr Dewar knows he can still draw on the well of affection he engendered as one of the architects of devolution. "No one is suggesting that the Scottish parliament has been a false step for Scotland," he said. "I think we have done an enormous amount and the system is settling down well."

Those close to him, however, worry that unless he starts to present himself in a better light, his reputation as the father of the nation and his chance of a second term will be irreparably damaged.

But now, as hardly a week goes by without fresh calamity befalling Mr Dewar's administration, there is growing dismay that the dream has been allowed to sour. "We just watch with bemusement," said one Westminster minister. "There is real frustration that the good things that are being done by the government are being eclipsed by all these fiascos in Scotland." The problems are manifold. In the last week alone one of Mr Dewar's key aides was forced to resign over two drink driving offences, one in Glasgow's red light area; another came under pressure to resign; and a third was forced to publicly apologise to a fourth - who was himself forced out last year. Then there is the outcry over the handling of the section 28 repeal, the fall-out in England over the deal struck on student tuition fees; and very real fears that it could all mean a trouncing for Labour in the crucial forthcoming Ayr byelection. Tony Blair is said to be increasingly worried and his trip north next month is seen by some as an attempt to convince Scots that home rule can work. Meanwhile, those who would succeed Mr Dewar are said to be positioning themselves to strike. It has been suggested, if officially denied, that the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has his eye on the first minister's job. There is also talk of appointing a deputy to try and shore up Mr Dewar, and, for the first time rumblings of discontent about his leadership are emerging from those closest to him. "The realities of being first minister have come as a great shock to him," said one colleague. "Donald felt very secure as secretary of state for Scotland; he was well protected and well-supported. But I feel he is really quite weak now. He handles conflict so badly. He just runs away. I think he could become so depressed and jaded if another series of things happen when he might say at some point enough." Mr Dewar rejects such notions out of hand. In recent days he has gone on the offensive, stressing he has no plans to step aside. "Don't listen to gossip," he says tersely. "It's a very different job. It's a more satisfying job. It is one that I suppose if I'm being honest that I have dreamt of; and I'm not a great dreamer." He admits the past few weeks have been a particularly difficult time. "It's the old, old cry of, 'events, dear boy, events,'" said Mr Dewar. "I take these matters seriously but what counts is the progress you are making with your programme and the confidence that you have in colleagues and they have in you." He is particularly proud of the deal carved from the Cubie report into higher education funding, and moulded to keep the coalition pact with the Liberal Democrats in place, despite deep disquiet in Westminster about the ramifications of the scheme outside Scotland. "I think it is a progressive scheme, imaginative and well worked out and it has been praised by a lot of figures in higher education. Our opponents said this was the rock on which we would perish and we certainly have not perished." The relatively simple aim of repealing Section 28, meanwhile, has grown into a monumental policy dispute. A heated campaign to keep the clause, which bans promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools, has forced the executive onto the defensive. Mr Dewar denies he misjudged the public mood. "Some of the reaction has been based on honest misunderstanding," he said. "We said from the beginning, from the first day, that proper safeguards have to be in place." Despite all the sniping, Mr Dewar knows he can still draw on the well of affection he engendered as one of the architects of devolution. "No one is suggesting that the Scottish parliament has been a false step for Scotland," he said. "I think we have done an enormous amount and the system is settling down well." Those close to him, however, worry that unless he starts to present himself in a better light, his reputation as the father of the nation and his chance of a second term will be irreparably damaged.

fields.headline: Assembly mutiny may bring chaos
fields.standfirst:
Wales Critics want Labour to take on London

Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: First secretary Alun Michael will next week face a joint attempt by opposition parties in the Welsh national assembly to topple his minority regime amid accusations that Labour is selling Wales short over the crucial issue of European funding for the most deprived areas of the country. The stage is set for a motion of no-confidence that could throw devolved power in Cardiff into a period of political paralysis.
fields.body:
First secretary Alun Michael will next week face a joint attempt by opposition parties in the Welsh national assembly to topple his minority regime amid accusations that Labour is selling Wales short over the crucial issue of European funding for the most deprived areas of the country. The stage is set for a motion of no-confidence that could throw devolved power in Cardiff into a period of political paralysis.

While European funding is at the heart of the row , frustration has also long been brewing with what is perceived to be the almost dictatorial style of Mr Michael's regime.

The opposition charge against the Michael administration is that it has simply not come to terms with the fact that Labour is a minority power in the assembly - it secured just 28 of the 60 assembly seats in last year's election.

Critics complain about a bland, ultra-cautious agenda that has not been prepared to challenge the New Labour orthodoxy in London over issues such as performance-related pay for teachers or free dental checks and eye tests for the people of Wales.

"We have not been able to have a radical policy agenda which shows that the assembly can make a difference to people's lives," says Ieuan Wyn Jones, acting leader of Plaid Cymru, the largest of the three opposition parties. "The structures are in place to have a more open debate about a specific Welsh agenda. We have the tools but we are not being allowed to use them."

Labour's vulnerability to concerted attack was exposed when opposition members joined forces last year to censure the Welsh agriculture secretary Christine Gwyther. Now, though, the stakes are considerably higher.

Mr Michael, who has faced a torrid time as first secretary since being reluctantly parachuted into Cardiff by Downing Street following former Welsh secretary Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on Clapham Common, challenged Plaid to come clean about why it was prepared to bring "chaos and confusion" to the assembly without offering a credible alternative.

Brussels has promised grants of £1.2bn to revitalise the economies of west Wales and the valleys as part of its so-called Objective 1 programme to help the poorest areas of Europe. But the EU money has to be matched by the treasury before it is handed over.

Mr Michael claims the opposition parties either don't understand the arguments over European funding or are deliberately trying to create an artificial hook on which to hang a no-confidence motion. "I think it would be damaging to the perception of the assembly and in the long run more damaging to the image of the other parties," he said.

Assembly arithmetic means a united opposition assault could force Mr Michael's resignation if that is the way they are determined to go. But the threat to unseat him begs the question of what would happen next. Any impasse cannot be resolved by fresh elections as the assembly is elected for a fixed four-year term. Labour, if defeated next week, might be able to continue as a minority under a new leader more open to opposition concerns. But the party has said publicly that Mr Michael will be its only nominee for the vacant post if the motion succeeds.

If he is renominated the assembly could be left facing a farcical period of what some have dubbed "yo yo politics" with Mr Michael being repeatedly voted out of office.

The Liberal Democrats are known to be particularly concerned to have something better to put in place of a defeated minority administration. But their group leader, Mike German, has made it clear there will be no climb down on the no confidence vote "unless the chancellor is prepared to guarantee Wales its due."

If Plaid Cymru have given thought to the question "what happens next?" they are giving nothing away beyond ruling out a Plaid-Tory coalition.
