webTitle: Clash imminent in Indonesia as general twice defies president

fields.headline: Clash imminent in Indonesia as general twice defies president
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Indonesia's fledgling civilian administration and its politically powerful armed forces appeared set on a collision course yesterday after senior security minister General Wiranto defied a second order in as many days from President Abdurrahman Wahid to resign for his role in last year's violence in East Timor.
fields.body:
Indonesia's fledgling civilian administration and its politically powerful armed forces appeared set on a collision course yesterday after senior security minister General Wiranto defied a second order in as many days from President Abdurrahman Wahid to resign for his role in last year's violence in East Timor.

The growing crisis sparked new fears that a coup was imminent and rocked Jakarta's financial markets.

Only hours after Mr Wahid, who is on a 16-day overseas tour, had said in London that he wanted Gen Wiranto to resign immediately, the cocksure former armed forces commander strode confidently into yesterday's cabinet meeting and sat down next to Mr Wahid's empty chair.

He smiled for the cameras but declined to answer questions on his future, which has hung by a thread ever since the country's human rights commission on Monday implicated him in the crimes against humanity committed by the Indonesian army and police during and after the independence referendum in East Timor.

The report said Gen Wiranto had full knowledge of the widespread murder, arson, forced evacuation and sexual abuse of women by his troops, but did nothing to stop it.

After the report was published, Mr Wahid immediately said Gen Wiranto should step down, although he did not say when.

On Tuesday, Mr Wiranto belligerently ignored the demand and said: "As a soldier, I am going to continue to fight to reveal the truth." He insists that rather than being involved in the violence, he was instrumental in efforts to maintain the peace in East Timor.

Mr Wahid, who is keen to demonstrate his adherence to international standards of human rights, fired back that it would be better if Gen Wiranto temporarily resigned at once. But the Muslim cleric turned politician is not thought to be helping his own cause.

For reasons that he is not willing to explain, Mr Wahid is refusing to confront Gen Wiranto personally, but is instead acting through the media and intermediaries.

The first order for Gen Wiranto to resign was given during a press interview, while the second was made via the minister of defence, Juwono Sudarsono, who technically is Gen Wiranto's subordinate.

Mr Sudarsono was mysteriously absent from yesterday's cabinet meeting.

"Gus Dur [Mr Wahid's nickname] has his own way of emphasising things," said the veteran politician Sarwono Kusumaatmadja. "His way of working is quite original, but it has worked so far." By keeping people guessing and off balance, Mr Wahid has thus far managed to juggle the many competing political elements in his cabinet.

However, analysts and diplomats were less confident about Mr Wahid's actions. "If Wahid was not willing to wield the axe himself, he should have told Megawati [Sukarnoputri, the vice-president] to do it," one western diplomat said. "Perhaps he does not trust her."

Adding to the dilemma is the military's failure to support Mr Wahid. In addition to backing Gen Wiranto, senior spokesman Major General Graito Usodo yesterday also rejected calls to suspend five other generals named alongside Gen Wiranto in the state-sponsored human rights report.

"They are still active," he said of the generals. "They are still working as normal. The legal charges have to be proven first and then we will act."

However, he reiterated that the military was not planning to seize power. "That's not true. That's not true," he said. "I strongly believe it won't happen in Indonesia." Mr Wahid is also confident that no elements within the military, which is far from united, will turn against him.

Jakarta's financial markets are certainly jittery about the mounting political uncertainty. The stock market has tumbled 5% in the past two days.

The country's currency, the rupiah, has taken a similar hit, despite the heartening news that international donors yesterday pledged £2.9bn in new loans to help Indonesia's faltering economic recovery.

webTitle: Saharans see glimmer of hope in young king

fields.headline: Saharans see glimmer of hope in young king
fields.standfirst: The war ended in 1990, but the two sides are still at odds
fields.trailText: On the outskirts of this windswept Saharan town is a miserable collection of breeze-block huts. They have no water, but a satellite dish sprouts from every roof.
fields.body:
On the outskirts of this windswept Saharan town is a miserable collection of breeze-block huts. They have no water, but a satellite dish sprouts from every roof.

The people who live here are victims of one of the world's most neglected conflicts. Another 150,000 of them linger in refugee camps across the border, near the Algerian town of Tindouf. All are waiting to see if one day they will be allowed a voice in their future.

"We don't know when it will happen," said Kher Ahmed, a former rebel fighter who now heads an aid organisation for families separated by the war. "All we've had is propaganda, propaganda, propaganda for years and years and years. Now with the new king, maybe things will change - but I'm not holding my breath."

It is now 25 years since King Hassan II of Morocco ordered 350,000 of his loyal subjects into this desolate north-west African territory, an area slightly bigger than Britain, to pressure the occupying Spanish forces to withdraw.

When they eventually did, the independence fighters of the rebel Polisario Front, armed and backed by Algeria, lost no time in declaring a Saharan Arab Democratic Republic in exile, and embarked on a sporadic war of attrition.

After one failed reconciliation attempt in 1981, a United Nations deal finally ended the fighting in 1990. It foresaw a ceasefire, an exchange of prisoners, a partial withdrawal of Moroccan troops and a referendum allowing the people of Western Sahara to choose between independence and integration with Morocco.

Ten years on, the region's estimated 300,000 inhabitants are still waiting for the poll, amid an extraordinary dispute about who is qualified to vote.

At first, the electorate was to consist of voters identified in a census by the Spanish in 1974. Then the UN decided to broaden the criteria by admitting members of all 88 clans of the 10 nomadic Saharan tribes listed in the Spanish survey.

Polisario objected furiously, considering it an attempt by Morocco to pad out the electorate with descendants of tribesmen who may have migrated elsewhere but who were likely to be loyal to Rabat.

Morocco argues that in a nomadic, largely illiterate society, the evidence of ties to the region and eligibility to vote can only realistically be based on oral testimony, rather than formal documents a quarter of a century old.

"We had examples in the same family of fathers being accepted and sons or brothers or aunts being rejected," said the Moroccan prime minister, Abdulrahman Youssoufi. "It was an absurd situation: under the original criteria the present leaders of Polisario themselves would not be eligible to vote."

For six years the two sides have been haggling over the cases of some 200,000 potential voters, under the glazed eyes of the 350-odd members of the UN mission for the referendum in western Sahara (Minurso).

It is an exhausting process, and it is why so many unhappy families are still in those shacks outside Laayoune. They are photographed, fingerprinted, then interviewed by UN officers in the presence of officials from both sides.

Oral testimony of their Saharan origins can only be provided by sheikhs recog nised back in 1974. Since many of those have died or are too weak to travel, the whole process is delayed further.

In the meantime Rabat has invested massively, building schools, hospitals and sports centres in what looks like a blatant attempt to buy loyalty.

To win over voters, the new young king, Mohammed VI, has founded a royal commission to look into the Saharan people's grievances, and he seems as popular here as he is elsewhere in Morocco.

But equally importantly, he has made overtures to the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, and hinted at the possibility of limited autonomy for the region if it remains under Moroccan sovereignty.

This, the returned Moroccan leftwing leader Abraham Serfaty argues, is the first glimmer of hope in decades. "A referendum is not the answer," he said.

"Victor and vanquished cannot be a solution in such an explosive region. The two sides need to sit down and hammer out an arrangement."

For six years the two sides have been haggling over the cases of some 200,000 potential voters, under the glazed eyes of the 350-odd members of the UN mission for the referendum in western Sahara (Minurso). It is an exhausting process, and it is why so many unhappy families are still in those shacks outside Laayoune. They are photographed, fingerprinted, then interviewed by UN officers in the presence of officials from both sides. Oral testimony of their Saharan origins can only be provided by sheikhs recog nised back in 1974. Since many of those have died or are too weak to travel, the whole process is delayed further. In the meantime Rabat has invested massively, building schools, hospitals and sports centres in what looks like a blatant attempt to buy loyalty. To win over voters, the new young king, Mohammed VI, has founded a royal commission to look into the Saharan people's grievances, and he seems as popular here as he is elsewhere in Morocco. But equally importantly, he has made overtures to the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, and hinted at the possibility of limited autonomy for the region if it remains under Moroccan sovereignty. This, the returned Moroccan leftwing leader Abraham Serfaty argues, is the first glimmer of hope in decades. "A referendum is not the answer," he said. "Victor and vanquished cannot be a solution in such an explosive region. The two sides need to sit down and hammer out an arrangement."

webTitle: Spanish left joins forces for election

fields.headline: Spanish left joins forces for election
fields.trailText: Spain's socialists and communists have agreed to bury their historic differences and form an alliance aimed at ousting the centre-right government led by Jose Maria Aznar in a general election on March 12.
fields.body:
Spain's socialists and communists have agreed to bury their historic differences and form an alliance aimed at ousting the centre-right government led by Jose Maria Aznar in a general election on March 12.

After 10 days of fraught negotiations the two parties announced yesterday that they would campaign on a joint manifesto and govern together under the socialist leader Joaquin Almunia if they won.

The pact is the first time Spain's divided left has come together since the country became a democracy after the death of the dictator General Francisco Franco in 1975.

Mr Aznar had been the favourite to win but the pact now puts him neck and neck with Mr Almunia. An opinion poll published last weekend by newspaper Vanguardia gave the conservative Popular party 42.5% of the vote, the socialists 37% and the mainly communist United Left (IU) 7.5%.

The announcement of an alliance came after days of tense talks in which the IU firmly resisted a Socialist proposal that it refrain from fielding candidates in provinces where it had never won a seat.

Mr Almunia, a Basque lawyer who took over from the long-serving prime minister Felipe Gonzalez after he lost the last election in 1996, argued that Spain leaned naturally to the left and that both parties needed to exploit that advantage. In 1996, the Socialists and United Left won 2.5m votes more than the PP which, he said, could have meant a 24 seat advantage in parliament.

Sharp personal differences between the leaders of the two parties at the time made an alliance impossible and Mr Aznar scraped into power with a narrow one percentage point lead. His minority government has relied on support from Catalan and Basque nationalists.

Mr Aznar warned voters that a leftwing government could be "a serious risk to prosperity".

fields.headline: Mexico's striking students arrested
fields.standfirst: Hundreds held as nine-month campus occupation boils over in fighting between pro- and anti-strike students
fields.trailText: Hundreds of students were being held by police yesterday after violent clashes at Latin America's largest university in Mexico City.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman  and AP in Mexico City
fields.body:
Hundreds of students were being held by police yesterday after violent clashes at Latin America's largest university in Mexico City.

Students and university staff, angry with striking students who have been occupying the main campus at National Autonomous University of Mexico, threw stones and bottles at the activists during the battle on Tuesday, injuring 37, four seriously. The strikers were protesting against increased tuition fees.

The two groups, brandishing poles and stones, fought for most of the day. At the end of the day the strikers remained in control of the campus

The fighting began early on Tuesday when 200 students opposed to the strike forced their way onto the campus and ejected the strikers. Members of the university's security staff then arrived in an apparent effort to help the anti-strikers defend the campus. But by late afternoon, more strikers had arrived. Brandishing poles and chunks of concrete, they retook the campus.

"War has now been declared," art student Carlos said through the wire mesh barricade blocking the university's main entrance, following the worst scenes of violence in the conflict so far.

Police arrested 251 people on the campus, three of them for possessing explosives. The rest were booked for disorderly and riotous conduct. Outside the university, hundreds of strike supporters chanted "Stop hitting them! Don't take them away!" Strikers accused the university authorities of provoking the violence.

Mexico's interior secretary Diodoro Carrasco said the university had requested the police intervention, despite laws forbidding police from entering university grounds.

Mr Carrasco denied a report that one person had been killed in the conflict. An ambulance driver had said that a man was killed by stab wounds to the chest.

In the wake of the violence the rector, Juan Ramon de la Fuente cancelled a plan to go on to the campus yesterday in an attempt to persuade the radical student leadership to lift the strike.

"This has been a day of profound sadness for the university," the rector said. "Violence is the antithesis of the university."

The strike which began on April 20 last year initially enjoyed wide support. However, a referendum of the university community on January 20 showed that an overwhelming majority now wanted the strike to stop.

fields.headline: What Austria's papers say
fields.standfirst:
The Austrian far right in power: special report
Freedom Party
People's party
fields.trailText: Der Standard
fields.body:
Der Standard

[French] President Jacques Chirac had some Gaullists who wanted to form a coalition on a regional level with the National Front removed from the party. The Belgians have their hands full with the Flemish faction, while the Swedes struggle with gangs of extremists. It is pure hypocrisy, if Wolfgang Schüssel now says that the EU states did not consult Austria. Perhaps his political ability to listen is on the wane because he wants to become chancellor at any price.

Kurier Online

Austria sits metaphorically in the foreign policy dunces' corner. Punished like a third-rate dictator, isolated like Serbia under Milosevic. The main responsibility for [the EU's] over-reaction lies with the big-mouthed speeches from Jörg Haider.

The second guilty party is Wolfgang Schüssel. How isolated must this minister be, must his diplomats be, that they received not one advance warning from the 14 friendly nations?

Kleine Zeitung

How on earth can a normal relationship with Austria ever be found again when it is possible to offend the principles of the European family to such an extent that one member gets a beating?

The threat to excommunicate Austria will probably have the opposite effect to what was intended. In a new election, Haider would now really profit.

Die Presse

The EU threatened Austria that there would be no "business as usual" if the Freedom party came to government. Are they allowed to do that? And behind that is the question of whether in future EU countries will be allowed to prescribe which governments are acceptable.

fields.headline: Former sumo champion alleges match-fixing
fields.trailText: Having echoed through the modern worlds of business, finance and government, the calls for fairer competition and greater transparency in Japan were directed yesterday at one of the country's most traditional and secretive institutions:sumo.
fields.body:
Having echoed through the modern worlds of business, finance and government, the calls for fairer competition and greater transparency in Japan were directed yesterday at one of the country's most traditional and secretive institutions:sumo.

In rare public criticism of the ethics of the national sport, a former top wrestler has turned whistleblower to allege that bout-rigging occurs on a daily basis - and that even some of the most venerated grand champions accept bungs to take a dive.

Keisuke Itai, who fought for more than a decade in sumo's top ranks, said that the prevalence of fixing was damaging the popularity of the sport, which has suffered a slump in attendance in recent years.

"No other sport in the world has so many fixed matches," he said, admitting that he had thrown hundreds of bouts for money or promises of having the favour returned.

During Japan's economic boom in the late 1980s, when wealthy patrons showered top wrestlers with money, he said that the results of 80% of the contests had been decided before they began.

Now, he said, the number of rigged bouts has fallen -along with the size of the cash gifts, which were as much as 50m yen (£260,000) per tournament 10 years ago. At that time, he said the going rate to buy a contest between top wrestlers was 300,000 yen (£1,700).

But he claimed that between one and five contests every day were still rigged in the top division. At the most recent tournament last month, he said the huge Hawaiian-born wrestler Akebono, who holds the coveted title of yokozuna (grand champion), had thrown at least one bout for money.

His allegations have drawn intense domestic media attention as a rare glimpse into a feudalistic world and the practice of yaocho (match-fixing), which has until now been the subject of much rumour but little concrete detail. The last time such a senior figure made such damaging allegations was in 1996, when Itai's stablemaster alleged that the ancient sport was poisoned with match rigging, tax evasion, yakuza (gangster) links, drugs and orgies.

Shortly before he was due to repeat these claims in public, he and another whistleblower died from pneumonia amid widespread suspicions that they were murdered.

The Japan Sumo Association said it was considering legal action against Itai following his claims. "The practice of yaocho has never taken place," said the chairman, Tokitsukaze.

fields.headline: Steven Norris's favourite smell
fields.standfirst: Oliver Burkeman  on the wealth of telling detail about the London mayoral candidates to be found in celebrity Q&A columns
fields.trailText: Oliver Burkeman  on the wealth of telling detail about the London mayoral candidates to be found in celebrity Q&A columns
fields.body:
The race to be London's mayor is, as we're constantly reminded, a battle of personalities. This is usually held to be a bad thing, an easy opportunity for backstage spinners to murmur that Frank Dobson is depressed, Steven Norris is sexually incontinent, or Ken Livingstone is a "sad and lonely" egomaniac - and heaven forbid we should ever get one of those in a position of political power.

But those who criticise the focus on personalities seem to have overlooked a side-effect of the phenomenon which has rather happier ramifications for voter education. Instead of being forced to rely on indigestible manifestoes, or five-second policy soundbites, Labour members choosing their candidate and voters choosing their mayor will have access to a vast, intimate and revealing storehouse of information: the seemingly endless column-inches of "Me and My Toothbrush"-style celebrity question-and-answer features in the press into which all concerned have been vigorously insinuating themselves for the best part of a year.

So what if you can't put a cigarette paper between most of the contenders on poverty, housing or public transport? Far more telling, in this contest of personalities, are the full facts about Glenda's most memorable holiday, Frank's favourite play, Ken's most enjoyable sitcom and, most intriguing of all, the smell that Steven Norris thinks is second only to sex. (It's the smell in the kitchen just before Sunday lunch is served, if you were wondering. Try finding that in his official manifesto.)

On one level, of course, these slots provide unbounded opportunities for the setting out of political stalls. Norris is particularly unsubtle in this respect, as he demonstrates in the Daily Mail's Me and My Health. "Physically, you could say my greatest qualification for being mayor of London is my thoroughly aldermanic figure," he notes optimistically of his 17-stone vastness.

There's plenty of consolation here for those who seek a strong sense of family values in their politicians. Courtesy of countless "What I did on New Year's Eve" pieces we learn that Livingstone spent "an evening with friends and family"; Dob son's December 31 was "very much a family occasion", while Norris and girlfriend Emma Courtney enjoyed champagne with "my best mate and his family", before trekking into central London. How Jackson spent the evening remains a mystery - instead, we learn (from the Sunday Times's Me and My Hols) that she was once very impressed with the way a woman bought eels in La Rochelle market, and (thanks to the Observer) that she'd rename Heathrow airport after Amy Johnson if it was up to her, which, as mayor, it wouldn't be.

Scratch the surface, though, and a few genuine hints of possible future policies begin to appear. We might, for example, expect some radical action on public transport from Jackson, who told the Sunday Times's Best of Times, Worst of Times that she lost her first acting job thanks to "a bus which was going the wrong way" - though, worryingly, she still seems also to believe (according to Me and My Hols) that "trains [are] still, to me, a very romantic way of travelling". A closer reading reveals that she's talking about the Orient Express, not Connex South Central - but still.

At least Londoners won't lack public toilets if Norris learns the lessons of his New Year's Eve, as revealed to the Daily Mail's Millennium Eve Candid Camera: "We were expecting plates, glasses, canapes and loos," he moaned of his aborted party plans. "Instead we spent the night swigging out of bottles and working out where the hell we were going to take a leak."

Meanwhile, in the Guardian's My Cultural Life, he dispenses with the clubber's vote in a trice: "I'm not sure all this disco club rap will survive, and techno is the antithesis of music..."

Weird parallels emerge between the candidates. From this paper's My Media and My Cultural Life we learn, for example, that all three Labour nominees share a taste for hard-boiled American crime cinema and fiction: LA Confidential and Cop City for Livingstone, Elmore Leonard for Jackson and Raymond Chandler for Dobson; Livingstone and Jackson admit to a shared passion for Friends, Frasier and Larry Sanders. If the vote goes the right way, it seems, vital strategy meetings between the mayor and his deputy could yet take the form of TV dinners. Far more condemnatory, though, is a devastating admission made by Livingstone which, had Millbank picked up on it, could have saved them all the fuss of a whispering campaign: among his favourite programmes, it transpires, are repeats of Star Trek: The Next Generation. Voters, beware.

webTitle: The quest for Cuba's lost gold

fields.headline: The quest for Cuba's lost gold
fields.standfirst: According to 20,000 Cubans, the Bank of England's vaults  are stuffed with treasure which belongs to them. They believe they are the heirs to a fortune sent to this country for safe-keeping in 1776. But does it even exist? Tom Gibb on a 400-year-old mystery
fields.trailText: According to 20,000 Cubans, the Bank of England's vaults  are stuffed with treasure which belongs to them. They believe they are the heirs to a fortune sent to this country for safe-keeping in 1776. But does it even exist? Tom Gibb on a 400-year-old mystery
fields.body:
When Norma Perez brought the news to the small town of Esperanza, it spread as only rumours in Cuba can. A spindly woman in her 50s, Norma talks in an urgent conspiratorial whisper, at a speed which even Cubans find hard to follow. The Contreras fortune, she told people, really exists. The money is sitting in the vaults of the Bank of England waiting to be claimed. She heard it from a friend who used to be a bodyguard of Fidel Castro, who had heard them talking about it in the Council of State. It must be true. The other heirs were already organising to reclaim it. If the Contreras did not hurry, they would get left out.

Norma's news unleashed a gold fever which has spread the length and breadth of the communist-ruled island, even crossing over to the mainland US and Florida. The story of the Contreras lost gold is an old one, passed down over at least a century. But it has found its most fertile ground to reflower in today's Cuba of frustrated dreams, uncertainties and shortages.

The full version is told in a series of highly sensationalist articles published in the Cuban magazine Bohemia in 1946, now being photo-copied and passed from hand to hand in villages across the country.

The tale starts with Don Francisco Manzo de Contreras, King Phillip II of Spain's chief justice for the Indies. He arrived in Cuba to clean up smuggling in 1599. He settled in the town of Remedios on Cuba's north coast and over the next 150 years the family became exceedingly rich.

In 1776, according to Bohemia, the sole heirs of the fortune were three nuns. The articles describe in great detail how, frightened of pirate raids, they secretly took six chests of gold from their hiding place in the walls of the Santa Clara convent in the dead of night and sent them off to London with a trusted nephew, Joseph Manzo de Contreras y Perez de Prado.

The magazine quotes florid conversations between Don Francisco and his trusted servant and between the nuns and their nephew, along with descriptions of the voyage and a portrait of Joseph standing proudly in London - all, it seems, the product of the journalist's highly vivid imagination.

The final article features a group of humble sweet-makers in the small village of Majagua in central Cuba - heirs of the "bounteous fortune", who, says the chronicler, are about to become millionaires. Fifty-four years later, Angel Contreras, one of those interviewed, is still waiting for a fortune which so far has only brought the family misfortune.

Majagua is a hot, dusty little town with a typical Cuban mix of old-style red-tiled houses and Soviet apartment blocks. There is a factory for canning fruit preserves, but the family sweet-making business long since succumbed to collectivisation. Angel assures me that in the 1920s his great-grandfather once had the receipt from the Bank of England. But it did him little good.

"They put him in a madhouse," Angel says, "and then they killed him. All for greed. They wanted the money." Angel is never precise about exactly who "they" were. However, they never got the receipt because his uncle had hidden it. Unfortunately, he too was murdered and the receipt has remained lost ever since.

Of course in Cuba such things no longer happen, he tells me. But outside, in London or the capitalist world, he warns, I had better be careful.

"You should have a bodyguard," he says. "And make sure you are not followed. Otherwise they will wait until you are close to the inheritance - and then kill you!"

After Fidel Castro's 1959 revolution, Cubans had other dreams to occupy their minds and the inheritance was forgotten for a while. The new National Bank president, Ernesto Guevara, summed up the revolutionary attitude to money by signing the notes with a derisory "Che".

But the collapse of the Soviet bloc has brought the island back down to earth with a crash. There is still support for the practical achievements of the revolution, the health and education systems and low levels of crime. But the end of the millennium has left many people casting around for something in which to believe.

The news that Norma brought spread quickly. Members of the Manzo and Loyola families, also heirs, were organising to get the money, she said. The Contreras - who are mostly descended from African slaves - were going to get left out.

Over the next six months, led by a fiery orator called Roberto Perez, who is married to a member of the family, the Contreras got to work. They put out messages on the local radio to contact all the possible heirs. Committees were formed to draw up family trees. Roberto travelled up and down the country holding public meetings in town halls, accompanied always by a large man of few words who he only half-jokingly referred to as his bodyguard.

Roberto spoke with the passion of a born-again preacher - but using the slogans of the revolution. He assured people that the inheritance had never been recovered before the revolution because only individual heirs had applied. It would be different if all the heirs reclaimed it.

"I've said it a thousand times," he told a crowd of several thousand in the city of Camaguey. "Our strength is in unity."

It's a slogan which everyone in Cuba has heard many times. Through unity, Roberto said, they would also find the missing documents needed to prove their claim.

He called the meetings "family gatherings". He assured his audiences that he had informed the Council of State what they were doing. But, he said, the state is not involved.

Of course no one believed him. For 40 years nothing has moved in Cuba without Communist party authorisation. How could such a movement grow up, with announcements on state-controlled radio, without government involvement?

"Why don't they just tell us whether it is true or not?" was the constant complaint.

Roberto was too autocratic to last long. He was also accused of deviating funds to hold unauthorised events, such as a pig roast. He was ousted from the leadership by a collective decision - intended to re-impose order. In fact it led to more division. The family is now split into two main groups - with a total of some 20,000 possible heirs affiliated.

What is happening pales alongside their cousins' experience in Florida. The Manzos in Miami are waging their own battle. Last month they occupied the street in front of the British consulate in Miami. They shouted slogans against the Queen, accusing her of sending their money to the tyrant Fidel Castro through British aid programmes in Cuba. Nine of them were arrested for causing a disturbance.

Every day there is a line outside her door of possible heirs looking for the documents to prove their descent. Try telling that to the Cubans.

A spindly woman in her 50s, Norma talks in an urgent conspiratorial whisper, at a speed which even Cubans find hard to follow. The Contreras fortune, she told people, really exists. The money is sitting in the vaults of the Bank of England waiting to be claimed. She heard it from a friend who used to be a bodyguard of Fidel Castro, who had heard them talking about it in the Council of State. It must be true. The other heirs were already organising to reclaim it. If the Contreras did not hurry, they would get left out. Norma's news unleashed a gold fever which has spread the length and breadth of the communist-ruled island, even crossing over to the mainland US and Florida. The story of the Contreras lost gold is an old one, passed down over at least a century. But it has found its most fertile ground to reflower in today's Cuba of frustrated dreams, uncertainties and shortages. The full version is told in a series of highly sensationalist articles published in the Cuban magazine Bohemia in 1946, now being photo-copied and passed from hand to hand in villages across the country. The tale starts with Don Francisco Manzo de Contreras, King Phillip II of Spain's chief justice for the Indies. He arrived in Cuba to clean up smuggling in 1599. He settled in the town of Remedios on Cuba's north coast and over the next 150 years the family became exceedingly rich. In 1776, according to Bohemia, the sole heirs of the fortune were three nuns. There is a factory for canning fruit preserves, but the family sweet-making business long since succumbed to collectivisation. fields.headline: A bridge too far
fields.standfirst: Meet Robbie. He won't pay tax, he parks on double-yellow lines and he's been arrested for impersonating a Nigerian diplomat. But when he turned his righteous anger on the Skye toll bridge, his tussle with the authorities got serious - and costly.  Gerard Seenan  meets a problematic Pict
fields.trailText: Meet Robbie. He won't pay tax, he parks on double-yellow lines and he's been arrested for impersonating a Nigerian diplomat. But when he turned his righteous anger on the Skye toll bridge, his tussle with the authorities got serious - and costly.  Gerard Seenan  meets a problematic Pict
fields.body:
There was a slight problem with the diplomatic vehicle. The white Mercedes - a vintage model a few decades old - wasn't moving. It was propped up precariously on a pile of bricks but was still replete with tyres; the rust made it clear the only place the Merc was going was to pot.

Not to be put off by mere trifles such as a wrecked car - which in times of crisis also doubles as the diplomatic residence - we arrange to meet the statesman-cum-legal-warrior in his village. Dunvegan is to be found at the not-so-pretty north-west corner of Skye: it's the village that coach tours pass through on the way to the castle, though the less upmarket ones occasionally stop off at the shabby hotel.

For the moment, it is also the home of Robbie the Pict, founder of the state of Pictland of Alba, and, as far as the Scottish executive and anyone with even a passing connection to the Skye bridge is concerned, the biggest pain in the arse to descend from the Highlands since accordion music.

Robbie the Pict presents many problems - not least being how you address him: Mr Pict, Mr The Pict or just plain Robbie? But it's the one-time roadie' s obsession with the minutiae of British constitutional law and the lump of concrete and steel which joins Skye to the mainland that offers the greatest pique to all those concerned with such matters.

Shortly before Christmas, Robbie lost a long-running appeal about the legitimacy of toll collection on the Skye bridge. As always, he represented himself in court. Robbie may be self-taught, but he is experienced in all things legal. So far, on the matter of the bridge alone, he has represented himself in 56 court cases. In theory, there are another 53 cases to come. There's also the small matter of organising the defence of around 400 other people. And plans to mount yet more legal challenges.

It is hard to put an exact figure on it, but the tall Highlander with the ginger hair and tweed cap must have cost the various tiers of British government several hundred thousand pounds in legal fees. And even more in annoyance.

Along with the continuous court challenges on every possible detail of the bridge, Robbie refuses to pay tax, he has prosecuted the English crown for reset (handling stolen property) and he drives around - when the Merc is not propped up on bricks, that is - in a car with diplomatic number plates and a tax disc registered to Pictland of Alba. There are legal justifications for all these actions, but, when they're found insufficient by courts - and it happens frequently - he happily goes to prison. Then he thinks of some other ground to fight from.

"Being a pain in the arse is not a factor that I am mindful of at all," he says, straight faced. "You can sit and say, 'I would rather drink beer', or you can take responsibility, do what you can do, and it only takes one guy in a court." Since the early 80s, Robbie has frequently been that guy. To the rest of us, his initial motivation may seem a little bizarre, but, to the monotonously serious Robbie, it fanned the flames of ancient anger.

The one-man legal crusade began with the passing of the British nationality act 1981. Not, all things considered, the most contentious piece of Tory legislation (even internet search engines can only find one mention of it, and that's information on how to buy it). But the act changed the national status of Scots from subjects of the kingdom of Scotland to citizens of the Westminster parliament. This made Robbie rather angry. He began mounting his invariably well-researched, if occasionally unlikely, legal challenges.

To help him on his way, a solicitor friend on Skye gave Robbie an acre of land to act as base camp for his constitutional crusade. He declared it Pictland of Alba, the Pictish free state. That was just the start.

"I stopped responding to any tax demands and road-tax demands. I registered my vehicle with Pictland of Alba, Rigg, Skye," he says. "I had my own road-tax disc and I put diplomatic plates on the car, for a bit of fun." There were plenty, though, who were not exactly amused by Robbie's peculiar wheeze.

On the face of it, it appears to be just a blatant attempt to wind up the authorities. But Robbie claims it is an example of the situationism apparently practised by Dutch peasants (it seemed best not to demand further explanation). Shortly after registering his car to Pictland of Alba, he began parking it on double-yellow lines across Edinburgh. Nothing happened; no ticket appeared. Undeterred, he continued parking the car illegally but, after six weeks, still there was nothing.

For those who know Edinburgh, this is immediately apparent as nothing short of a miracle: it was obvious that either ethereal forces were involved, or Pictland had been given diplomatic recognition. It was not until Robbie made a trip to Perth a few days later that things started to go a bit wrong, or, for Robbie at least, have the desired intention.

While driving through the town, he was stopped by a local policeman. The bobby was mildly amused by Robbie's tales of Pictland, but he phoned through to check the diplomatic number plates. They were the same as those used by the Nigerian embassy. Robbie was arrested for, among other things, impersonating a Nigerian diplomat.

"I went to Perth sheriff court and then to the high court. I was fined but I didn't pay so I went to prison for 40 days," he says with discomfiting nonchalance. "Jail is just an occupational hazard if you decide to take on imperialism." His crusades have supplied him with numerous criminal convictions, but, in 1994, Robbie tried to return the favour to the home office. He began a prosecution of the English crown for reset over the stone of destiny. But, 24 hours before the case was due to be heard on July 13, 1997, the stone was on its way back to Scotland. Maybe it was coincidence.

Robbie's next big legal preoccupation began in 1995 - and continues to this day: the Skye bridge.

When, in October of that year, Skye was joined to mainland Britain for the first time in thousands of years, the locals did not take kindly to the costs.

Tolls to cross the bridge - built under the hugely controversial private finance initiative and currently owned by the Bank of America - were fairly hefty. (Now they are levied at a much-reduced level of £4.70 each way.) So the islanders, led by Robbie, began a campaign of non-payment.

This, though, was not the usual island revolt. The campaign group, Skat, didn't want a political solution; only a legal one would do. Around 400 people were charged with a criminal offence for refusing to pay the toll.

The campaign group managed to get 270 off not guilty. The sheriff court in Dingwall has been overrun with cases ever since.

Alongside this have been other legal challenges from Robbie: from the legitimacy of collection methods to upsetting the Act of Union. And he has also reported the bridge's operators to the VAT man (although, ironically, the EU is now planning to add VAT to tolls).

So far, it's been to no avail. But he is undeterred. "I am attempting to expose what I think is one of the biggest examples of across-the-board criminal and government corruption," he says.

In between this, he has stood for the Scottish parliament. He had to sell his caravan to make the £500 deposit, so he lived in the diplomatic car for a while. But that was an aside. It's the bridge that annoys and obsesses him. "This will go on through generations. My kids will carry on," he says, before going off to prepare more legal work. Even Perry Mason wasn't this committed - or bizarre.

fields.headline: No: 1570 Jeeves
fields.trailText: Born: 1917, in PG Wodehouse's short story, The Man with Two Left Feet.
fields.body:
Born: 1917, in PG Wodehouse's short story, The Man with Two Left Feet.

Function: Manservant to upper-class twit Bertie Wooster, and practioner of such withering looks that it was often observed: "Ice formed on the butler's upper slopes."

Last outing: 1971 in Much Obliged, Jeeves, four years before his creator's death.

Except, that wasn't quite his last outing, was it? No. He has achieved what some might call a cheap, posthumous life as the frontman to Ask Jeeves, a California-based internet search-engine.

Come now, "some might call"? All right, PG Wodehouse's literary agents, AP Watt.

They're not happy, I take it? Most decidedly not. In fact, they have had their lawyers threaten legal action against Ask Jeeves Inc.

Is Jeeves so badly served by the website? Well, he appears in cartoon form on the homepage with all the satirical bite of a doughnut. But that isn't the point.

What is the point? That, in a damnable breach of etiquette, the founders of Ask Jeeves didn't gain permission before using him.

Ah. Jeeves has been in tighter corners than this, though: Undoubtedly. A typical episode finds him saving Bertie from humiliation at the hands of Barmy Fotheringay-Phipps at the annual Drones Club golf tournament.

And it will take more than a couple of Californians to tarnish his image: Naturally, he will rise to the occasion with his inimitable dignity. Recall if you will, the time when "Jeeves lugged Bertie's purple socks out of the drawer as if he were a vegetarian fishing a caterpillar out of his salad." (My Man Jeeves, 1919).

Still, bit of a liberty and all that: Oh yes, not strictly cricket.

One can only imagine what Jeeves would have to say about it: Something along the lines of, "How charming," in a low, cold voice, as if he had been bitten in the leg by a personal friend.

Don't say: "Jeeves? Isn't he that guy who set up the website?"

fields.headline: Gardeners' legacies
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Two things are guaranteed to lift my spirits at this time of year. One is the lengthening of the days: mild days in February often deliver false promises of spring, but progress towards longer evenings is a relentless, celestial certainty - at least until midsummer's day. fields.body:
Two things are guaranteed to lift my spirits at this time of year. One is the lengthening of the days: mild days in February often deliver false promises of spring, but progress towards longer evenings is a relentless, celestial certainty - at least until midsummer's day. The second event, the appearance of snowdrops spearing through the soil all along the valley, is a consequence of the first.

Many people doubt that snowdrops are native in Britain, and several colonies hereabouts must have been planted. The carpet of snowdrops between the gravestones in Hamsterley's windy, hilltop churchyard represent an ecclesiastical link with the planting of this flower that dates back to monastic times.

Another colony, along the base of a hedge in Wolsingham, is composed entirely of double flowers, that never set seeds and are clonal descendants of bulbs carefully planted by a gardener. Another is in woodland, intermingled with winter aconite.

Colonies like these are ghostly survivors of gardens around houses that have long- since vanished. Introduced or planted, the snowdrop is a great survivor. The thick patches of the flower beside the River Wear at Witton-le-Wear are sometimes drowned under winter floods but still manage to force their way up through several inches of sandy silt every year. All down the dale they share this riverbank habitat with daffodils.

Some of these have a greater claim to native status in the Wear valley, but many daffodils whose leaves are beginning to appear in the riverbank woodlands show clear signs of the attentions of a plant breeder. They are most likely the work of local banker and landowner William Backhouse, who bred more than 200 named cultivars of daffodil before he died in 1869.

Great swaths of his daffodils still flower every spring on his former property. It seems likely that some daffodil wildlings in the dale - particularly the sterile, double- flowered varieties with no trumpet that closely resemble plants in Backhouse's own former garden - are the result of his careful springtime cross pollinations, made more than 150 years ago.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: M&S seeks new ad agency
fields.body:
M&S seeks new ad agency

Marks & Spencer will hire a new advertising agency as it strives to rebuild its battered brand image - and is believed to have set aside a budget of about £15m for the campaign in the first year.

A big TV advertising push, designed to restore the store's reputation, is likely to be part of the new campaign. The ailing firm wants to hire a leading creative mainstream agency and is drawing up a shortlist for the pitch.

Until now M&S has used one main agency, BMP4, on a contract basis and brought in other agencies for special projects.

An M&S spokesman said: "We are now looking for one big creative agency who will be a strategic partner to build on the strength of the brand."

As a result BMP4 - which masterminded the firm's fashion advertising last year - will not be part of the repitch, although M&S has not ruled out its parent company.

Granada bid faces delay

Media and leisure group, Granada, saw its shares fall 29p to 619p yesterday as chairman Gerry Robinson said a competition commission investigation of the firm's proposed takeover bids for Carlton Communications and United Newspapers may take longer than the minimum three months.

The group, which expects to hear within the next 10 days whether the office of fair trading will call for a full inquiry of its two-prong intervention in the proposed merger between Carlton and United, said trading in the first quarter of the current financial year had started well and the strong 1999 performance was continuing. Advertising sales were ahead 9%, while and hotel sales were up 5%. The Travelodge business saw its income climb 16% and there was a 5% advance in revenues from the food services and roadside travel catering divisions.

The OFT yesterday sent its recommendations to the department of trade and industry on whether to refer the planned Carlton-United tie up to the competition commission.

Shoppers head back to basics

Off-licences and speciality foods shops suffered from a new year hangover last month, as shoppers went back to basics after splashing out in December.

Retail sales growth slowed in January according to the latest snapshot of the sector published yesterday by the Confederation of British Industry. Hardest hit were the shops which had supplied parties over the Christmas and new year period.

Off-licences reported that sales were flat, while specialist food shops recorded a fall.

The CBI said the figures showed that the economy was already slowing in the aftermath of the three rises in interest rates since last September.

However economists said the underlying picture was strong.

PO spends £6m on French firm

The Post Office continued its expansion into Europe with the £6m acquisition yesterday of Crie, a Paris-based express mail business and the Post Office's fifth international acquisition in the past 12 months. John Modd, managing director of International Services, said: "By controlling operations overseas, we not only improve reliability of service but become more competitive and flexible in meeting customers' requirements."

fields.headline: Membership swings back into fashion
fields.trailText: Sir Ken Jackson, arch-Blairite proponent of partnership agreements with business, was in ebullient mood on Tuesday at the Gay Hussar, a traditional watering hole for Old Labour stalwarts.
fields.body:
Sir Ken Jackson, arch-Blairite proponent of partnership agreements with business, was in ebullient mood on Tuesday at the Gay Hussar, a traditional watering hole for Old Labour stalwarts.

He, soberly, foresaw membership of his union, the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union (AEEU), rising 50% within the next 18 months alone from its current level of 732,000.

Sir Ken said this did not take into account the planned merger with the Manufacturing Science Finance Union, which claims 420,000 members. The two are due to merge next January and, on Sir Ken's basis, could enjoy a combined membership of 1.7m towards the end of 2001, making the new union Britain's biggest.

Prima facie, the AEEU leader's estimates are wildly, naively, optimistic and that was the reaction among many of his colleagues. Trade union membership in Britain has fallen from a peak of 12m in 1979 when Margaret Thatcher won power and initiated a series of measures to curtail "union power", to today's 6.8m.

What is more, as the TUC pointed out in a paper discussed at its annual congress last September, there are no union members present in 47% of all British workplaces - compared with 36% in 1990.

In only 2% of workplaces are all employees union members (7% in 1990) and only one in five workers in the private sector are unionised. Only 6% of employees under 20 are union members - rising to 19% of those between 20 and 29.

That is the scale of the problem confronting Britain's unions but Sir Ken was undaunted. He foresaw TUC membership as a whole rising from its trough by 40% within two years, implying that many other unions would enjoy successful recruitment campaigns.

"It took 20 years to get overall membership down to below 7m," one sceptic said. "It ought not to take 20 years to build back towards that level but a 40% increase in just two years is a pretty tall order."

The reason for Sir Ken's optimism about his own union is not hard to find. Last month the TUC reported that confidence about winning recognition is at an historic high among unions, with a record 75 deals signed in the 10 months from January to October last year.

Many of these - perhaps as high as 80% - are signed by the AEEU, which has become a by-word, certainly among its critics, for "sweetheart deals" with business that effectively give away the right to strike in exchange for single union recognition and increased consultation.

Sir Ken pointed out that employers are voluntarily recognising unions before measures contained in the new employment relations act take effect later this year. These award automatic recognition when 50% plus one of the bargaining unit are union members and give recognition if a majority - and at least 40% of those eligible to vote - demands it in a secret ballot.

David Coats, head of economic and social affairs at the TUC, said many firms sought voluntary agreements rather than go through the procedures laid down by the act, including judgment in dispute cases from the central arbitration committee. But there are other, more epochal reasons than friendly legislation for the prospect of increased union membership - and density - and not just in older, more established firms. Corporate culture, Mr Coats pointed out, has changed substantially from the days of Lady Thatcher and John Major which were noted, in TUC eyes, for the "failure of top-down, command-and-control, hire-and-fire management strategies".

Earlier this week, Juan Kelly, chairman of Cammell Laird, the ship repairers, said the partnership "single table" deal he had signed with the AEEU and GMB unions "sits well with our stakeholder culture" - and the two unions' "powerful political lobby" would help the group "nurture its relationship with government".

Trade unionism, as Sir Ken said, is no longer a dirty word, strikes (pace yesterday's announcement that the Ford white-collar staff who have voted for action) are rare, and companies, under New Labour, see virtue in embracing a more consensual culture, partly under the influence of Europe and the advent of works councils.

"The old, more adversarial approach did not close Britain's productivity gap with Europe nor improve workers' performance or increase their commitment to the workplace," said Mr Coats.

The TUC's partnership approach has been endorsed by groups such as Unilever whose chairman, Niall FitzGerald, said: "We passionately believe that the effective contribution of our people is not an optional extra but an imperative to deliver the business strategy."

Recent surveys of employee attitudes and of company performance, the TUC says, show a strong correlation between union recognition and employee involvement as a force for greater shareholder value, better output and performance, lower turnover of labour and absenteeism.

But not every company, and especially not the newer ones in growth industries, are convinced of the need to embrace the culture of "mutual gains". Sir Ken's ambitious target may yet prove unattainable in a world of WAP technology.

webTitle: Britain prolongs hunt for new IMF leader

fields.headline: Britain prolongs hunt for new IMF leader
fields.trailText: Britain is continuing to withhold its support for the campaign to make Germany's Caio Koch-Weser the next head of the International Monetary Fund despite reports that France is the only European government opposing the appointment.
fields.body:
Britain is continuing to withhold its support for the campaign to make Germany's Caio Koch-Weser the next head of the International Monetary Fund despite reports that France is the only European government opposing the appointment.

Although the UK might eventually endorse Mr Koch-Weser, other candidates are under consideration, suggesting the race to succeed Michel Camdessus as IMF managing director could have some way to run.

The treasury last night refused to discuss Mr Koch-Weser's suitability for the job, but it is understood he came to London for a private meeting with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, last month to seek his support.

While not ruling out doing so in the future, Mr Brown has yet to offer his endorsement, suggesting he wants the search for an alternative candidate to continue in the interests of securing the best person for the job.

Mr Brown chairs the IMF's policy-making committee and his views carry considerable weight.

The principal opposition to Mr Koch-Weser is thought to come from the French government, but there are also doubts about whether his views on the IMF's role conform with those of Larry Summers, US treasury secretary, who has the most powerful voice in financial diplomacy.

In a recent speech at the London Business School, Mr Summers said he wanted the IMF to scale down its long-term lending and concentrate on financial crisis prevention and management.

fields.headline: Norman to retain Knutsford link
fields.trailText: Knutsford, the shell company formed to take over an ailing retailer, has insisted that former Asda chairman Archie Norman is to remain on its board despite his new role within the Conservative party.
fields.body:
Knutsford, the shell company formed to take over an ailing retailer, has insisted that former Asda chairman Archie Norman is to remain on its board despite his new role within the Conservative party.

Mr Norman yesterday resigned as a director of Railtrack and as a consultant to Asda after his appointment as spokesman on the environment, transport and the regions.

Speculation that Mr Norman would also resign his Knutsford directorship or at least scale back his responsibilities at the company was dismissed by a spokesman: "Mr Norman remains a non-executive director and will keep his shareholding."

The market remained unconvinced by the assurances and Knutsford shares, which have been heading south since takeover talks with conglomerate-cum-venture capitalist Wassall were called off at the end of last week, closed down a further 17% at 104p.

Dealers said that when Knutsford was set up it gave the impression that Mr Norman would play a key role in managing any business it acquired but it was unclear how much time he could now devote to the company.

Liberal Democrat environment spokesman Don Foster added to the confusion by saying that he had written to Conservative leader William Hague demanding that Mr Norman place all his holdings in a blind trust.

Knutsford shares surged in November when Mr Norman, Julian Richer, Nick Leslau and Nigel Wray bought into the company and turned it into a vehicle to bid for a major retailer. Last month it surprised many observers by picking Wassall as its first target.

Takeover talks between the two were abandoned last week when institutions said they were not prepared to underwrite Knutsford shares at a fraction of their price then of 175p. Knutsford was looking for the shares to be underwritten at 60p.

fields.headline: Tarpan
fields.trailText: Shares in Tarpan, the cash shell controlled by entrepreneur Neville Buch, leapt to new heights yesterday amid expectation that it is poised to relaunch on AIM tomorrow as an investment vehicle specialising in internet companies.
fields.body:
Shares in Tarpan, the cash shell controlled by entrepreneur Neville Buch, leapt to new heights yesterday amid expectation that it is poised to relaunch on AIM tomorrow as an investment vehicle specialising in internet companies.

The shares closed up 18%, or 120p, at 775p after touching a new high at 785p. The surge came as investors focused on Tarpan's potential, backed as it is by Buch and other heavyweight industry players such as Robert Ware, deputy chief executive of property company MEPC.

Tarpan will be reborn as i2s with a view to raising £5m to invest in internet companies. The company said at its interim results in December that it would seek to take advantage of the strong position held by its broker, Peel, Hunt and Company, in the internet and technology flotation market.

Buch was chairman of Blenheim Group before its takeover by United News & Media in 1996. He has steadily sold off property and trading assets at Tarpan to reposition it as an internet investment fund.

Buch's aim will be to participate primarily in second round financing, where internet companies have completed development work and are looking for funds to make their operations commercially viable.

Buch chairs Tarsus Group which said it was planning to buy the business to business portal Martex Communicators for £16.5m. The company also said it was raising £10.2m through a rights issue, partly to finance the acquisition and partly to provide extra capital.

Tarsus shares closed 5% up at 580p. The shares have doubled in the past two months and risen 15-fold since flotation 18 months ago.

webTitle: BT needs lessons in how to communicate

fields.headline: BT needs lessons in how to communicate
fields.standfirst: Size no defence against volatility
fields.trailText: It used to be a common assumption that since FTSE Top 100 companies were researched to death by scores of City analysts, it was near enough impossible for outsiders to spot value not already reflected in a big company's market rating.
fields.body:
It used to be a common assumption that since FTSE Top 100 companies were researched to death by scores of City analysts, it was near enough impossible for outsiders to spot value not already reflected in a big company's market rating.

Given its size and importance, the telecoms sector probably boasts more (and better paid) analysts than any other sector. On a knee-jerk basis then, we might assume that there was a collective misunderstanding about British Telecom's prospects ahead of yesterday's third quarter figures given that the shares fell a full 17% - wiping £14bn off the company's market value.

But then, glance across the business landscape and it quickly becomes clear that size is no longer a buffer against the extraordinary volatility which now sweeps the City on a daily basis. While BT was heading for the doghouse, it was time to celebrate in the software sector where, paradoxically, shares were going up because of all the choice work they are getting from telecoms companies.

CMG grew by a fifth on the basis of its deal to supply Vodafone with wireless application protocol technology, and Logica jumped by almost the same margin simply in sympathy. Even the Woolwich got in on the action after, er, doing a telecoms deal with Vodafone. The shares shot up by almost 10%.

Telecoms companies, of course, are now routinely bundled together with other media and technology stocks. The market gets edgy when trying to work out what is "old" and what is "new." Reuters and Reed-Elsevier both suffered hugely over recent months as analysts focused on their prospects in this new world rather than the immediate outlook for their established operations.

In BT's case, chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield admits that the company needs to provide much more detail about its operations in the hope that the stock market will appreciate its real worth. If this approach fails, he will consider floating parts of the business, such as the Concert joint venture with AT&T, to force the issue - just the sort of talk guaranteed to create even more volatility.

Mirror magic
It is said that if you were stand at Liverpool Street station before eight in the morning, watching the City's stock broking community arrive for work, you would be able to count as many copies of the Mirror as the Financial Times tucked under commuters' arms.

There is a good reason for this: the red-top newspaper's daily City Slickers column. This is like no other "financial section". Over the past 18 months, its two young authors have entertained us with some of the most outrageous examples of reporting the City has ever seen. A few of the business stories run in the Mirror have even proved to be true and, apparently by pure coincidence, the Mirror's editor, Piers Morgan, happened to buy shares in a company - Sir Alan Sugar's Viglen Technology - where the Slickers got it right.

But the resultant storm over Mr Morgan's clairvoyant approach to investment masks something much more worrying: the systematic fleecing of inexperienced investors who follow the Mirror's "tips".

Here's how it works, using a recent real-life example. At the beginning of January, shares in 3D software group Superscape began to climb from 300p. On January 19 the price reached 465p, at which point the Slickers decided to tell their readers to buy.

London's market makers, having read the Mirror on the train early in the morning, hoisted the price to just under 600p first thing, so when amateur investors finally got through to their stockbrokers they were paying a price inflated by almost 30%.

By last night, the price of Superscape had fallen all the way back to 426p, so the Mirror investors who followed this tip have now lost a third of their money in the space of two weeks - ignoring costs, the bid/offer spread and stamp duty.

There are scores of similar examples. There is nothing illegal in all this and the phenomenon is not restricted to the Mirror's investment advice. The fact is, City professionals can react quicker than private investors, and when the investors are really speculators and dealing without thinking, the City takes money off them - even if this necessitates first buying a paper they would not normally read.

Evidence arrived just this week, with the warning from investment bank Close Brothers that it is going to make rather better profits that everyone expected. It owns Winterflood Securities, the market-making firm which exerts special control over trading in many of the smaller, illiquid companies now being recommended to the public.

In the current atmosphere, where hundreds of thousands of people have taken up stock market punting for the first time with little or no knowledge about how markets work, all those dispensing investment advice, not just newspapers, have a duty to protect their "clients."

CMG grew by a fifth on the basis of its deal to supply Vodafone with wireless application protocol technology, and Logica jumped by almost the same margin simply in sympathy. Even the Woolwich got in on the action after, er, doing a telecoms deal with Vodafone. The shares shot up by almost 10%. Telecoms companies, of course, are now routinely bundled together with other media and technology stocks. The market gets edgy when trying to work out what is "old" and what is "new." Reuters and Reed-Elsevier both suffered hugely over recent months as analysts focused on their prospects in this new world rather than the immediate outlook for their established operations. In BT's case, chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield admits that the company needs to provide much more detail about its operations in the hope that the stock market will appreciate its real worth. If this approach fails, he will consider floating parts of the business, such as the Concert joint venture with AT&T, to force the issue - just the sort of talk guaranteed to create even more volatility. Mirror magic It is said that if you were stand at Liverpool Street station before eight in the morning, watching the City's stock broking community arrive for work, you would be able to count as many copies of the Mirror as the Financial Times tucked under commuters' arms. There is a good reason for this: the red-top newspaper's daily City Slickers column. This is like no other "financial section". Over the past 18 months, its two young authors have entertained us with some of the most outrageous examples of reporting the City has ever seen. A few of the business stories run in the Mirror have even proved to be true and, apparently by pure coincidence, the Mirror's editor, Piers Morgan, happened to buy shares in a company - Sir Alan Sugar's Viglen Technology - where the Slickers got it right. But the resultant storm over Mr Morgan's clairvoyant approach to investment masks something much more worrying: the systematic fleecing of inexperienced investors who follow the Mirror's "tips". Here's how it works, using a recent real-life example. At the beginning of January, shares in 3D software group Superscape began to climb from 300p. On January 19 the price reached 465p, at which point the Slickers decided to tell their readers to buy. London's market makers, having read the Mirror on the train early in the morning, hoisted the price to just under 600p first thing, so when amateur investors finally got through to their stockbrokers they were paying a price inflated by almost 30%. By last night, the price of Superscape had fallen all the way back to 426p, so the Mirror investors who followed this tip have now lost a third of their money in the space of two weeks - ignoring costs, the bid/offer spread and stamp duty. There are scores of similar examples. There is nothing illegal in all this and the phenomenon is not restricted to the Mirror's investment advice. The fact is, City professionals can react quicker than private investors, and when the investors are really speculators and dealing without thinking, the City takes money off them - even if this necessitates first buying a paper they would not normally read. Evidence arrived just this week, with the warning from investment bank Close Brothers that it is going to make rather better profits that everyone expected. It owns Winterflood Securities, the market-making firm which exerts special control over trading in many of the smaller, illiquid companies now being recommended to the public. In the current atmosphere, where hundreds of thousands of people have taken up stock market punting for the first time with little or no knowledge about how markets work, all those dispensing investment advice, not just newspapers, have a duty to protect their "clients."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A sharp slide in British Telecommunication's stock was offset by strong gains from Vodafone and other companies exposed to mobile telephony as the FTSE 100 closed narrowly higher.
fields.body:
A sharp slide in British Telecommunication's stock was offset by strong gains from Vodafone and other companies exposed to mobile telephony as the FTSE 100 closed narrowly higher.

The benchmark index edged up 11.9 points to close at 6,302.8 after overcoming the early shock of a 20% fall in BT shares after disappointing results.

BT eventually closed the session down 18%, or 218p, at 972p.

Vodafone was the main driver of the rally, adding 42 points to the index amid increasing confidence that it is on the verge of winning its bid to buy Mannesmann. Together the two telecom firms accounted for more than 30% of a total trading volume of 1.98bn shares.

The Vodafone magic cast a spell on information technology group CMG, which has been chosen by the mobile phone operator to provide it with software which will allow users to access the internet through their handsets. Its shares leapt 818p to £48.45.

Logica, which operates in the same space, climbed 267p to £19.18.

Media stocks enjoyed a good trading day. BSkyB continued its recent strong run and - as speculation around Vivendi's stake in the broadcaster continued - climbed 69p to £14.50. BSkyB stock has now risen by almost 45% this year.

United News & Media also edged up 20p to 750p after Granada used its annual general meeting to reiterate its interest in bidding for more television assets.

Pearson rose 59p to £21.51, while Reuters added 40p to 971p on homes of internet related corporate activity.

Telewest Communications was up 10p at 382p as analysts highlighted its Active Digital interactive TV service prospects.

Microchip designer ARM Holdings continued to reclaim the decline of previous weeks as investors continued to digest better than expected results announced at the start of the week. It closed the day 286p higher at £41.60.

Among the smaller stocks 365 Corporation climbed 16% to 232p after a mention here yesterday. The provider of online sports and entertainment content is thought to have an acquisition in the pipeline.

Publisher Highbury House added 19p to 93.5p as the market warmed to its £39m acquisition of magazines group Nexus.

Among the tiddlers Arthur Shaw & Co edged up 3p to 17p on rumours it is about to sign another high-profile artist. The Spice Girls and Shirley Bassey are already on its rosters.

fields.headline: A modern mariachi
fields.standfirst: Sixty years after his death, Silvestre Revueltas is finally getting the acclaim he deserves.  Andrew Clements  discovers one of the greats of Latin music
fields.trailText: Sixty years after his death, Silvestre Revueltas is finally getting the acclaim he deserves. Andrew Clements discovers one of the greats of Latin music
fields.body:
Michael Nyman and the conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen are among Silvestre Revueltas's biggest fans. And yet, apart from a handful of discs and the occasional appearance in concert programmes, his music is hardly known on this side of the Atlantic. In the US and his native Mexico, however, Revueltas's reputation is slowly being consolidated. His centenary - he was born on New Year's Eve 1899 - has given the cause a decisive push. The recent Revueltas festival in Santa Barbara included no fewer than 18 of his works alongside other pieces from Latin America, plus screenings of three films for which Revueltas wrote the soundtracks, a puppet show and an exhibition of manuscripts.

The connection between Revueltas and the Californian city is conductor Gisele Ben-Dor, the Uruguayan-born musical director of the Santa Barbara Symphony Orchestra, who has fervently championed his cause for years. It's entirely due to Ben-Dor's energy and enthusiasm that the Revueltas festival took shape: she planned and conducted all the programmes, and brought in the Revueltas scholar Roberto Kolb-Neuhaus from Mexico City to prepare new editions for some of the works. It was a real labour of love for all involved, and endlessly fascinating and revealing for those like me who arrived knowing barely a handful of Revueltas's pieces.

It turns out that the man was as colourful as the music he wrote, and that the few of his pieces that are known - the orchestral Sensemaya, the abrasive Ocho por Radio, the naggingly compulsive Homenaje a Federico Garcia Lorca - are by no means just inspired flashes in the pan. In the 30s, the decade in which Revueltas composed all his major works (he died of alcoholism and pneumonia in 1940), he was a consistent and distinctive voice in contemporary music. His work, like that of all true originals, remains obstinately unclassifiable.

He's been called a Mexican Charles Ives, but that's a misleading parallel. Ives regularly introduced popular songs and hymn tunes into his scores as points of reference, but he regarded himself as a high-art composer. Revueltas's intentions were very different: he was aiming for a genuine synthesis between popular Mexican music and the Western art-music tradition. The bright, brittle sound of his scoring, the complexity of his rhythms and the acid tang of his harmonies owe as much to the mariachi bands of northern Mexico as they do to the modernist world of Stravinsky, Varese and Bartok, who seem to have been his major European influences. His body of work has a real radical agenda; Revueltas was a revolutionary, and the barriers he sought to break down were musical as well as social.

Born in the Mexican province of Durango, Revueltas trained first as a violinist. He studied in the US and remained there to earn his living conducting and playing in theatre bands. During that time he composed very little; the pieces that he did write have a vaguely French flavour and, apart from the odd flash of sardonic humour, neither show individuality nor hint at the music to come. A little piano study from 1924 has no claim to distinction apart from its title, Tragedy in the Form of a Radish, which pokes not-so-gentle fun at Erik Satie.

It was only after Revueltas returned home in 1929 to become assistant conductor of the Mexico Symphony Orchestra that his creativity exploded and the first distinctive pieces began to appear. With his fellow conductor-composer Carlos Chavez and painters like Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo, he champi oned the cause of a nationalist Mexican art. When a left-wing government was elected in Mexico in 1934 he began writing socialist realist music for the state-sponsored cinema. Some of the films haven't aged well, but Redes (one of Fred Zinnemann's early successess as a director) was screened in Santa Barbara with Revueltas's wonderfully paced, humane score played live by the SBSO under Ben-Dor.

In the next five years Revueltas wrote another nine film scores and a stream of concert works; in 1937 he travelled to Spain to join the fight against Franco. He was an alcoholic and possibly a manic depressive, yet his music retained its ebullience to the end of his short life. It's in the clashing mariachi-isms of Ocho, the busy, almost dangerously vapid outer sections of Homenaje, framing a heartfelt lament for Lorca, and the gentle, rather surreal humour of the children's ballet The Wandering Tadpole.

Revueltas's pieces, their sound world, their collage-like patterning of themes and essentially non-developmental forms, are products of a genuinely modernist sensibility. He often relies on three-part, fast-slow-fast structures, but within that simple shape the ordering of events and the shifts of perspectives have their own logic, sometimes almost a constructivist basis.

Occasionally the language clings too closely to the models: the recently rediscovered children's entertainment Once Upon a Time There Was a King, from 1940, is heavily mortgaged to Stravinsky's Soldier's Tale, while the string-orchestra version of Cuauhnahuac (1931) sounds more like Bartok than Revueltas. But a work like Planos (1934), with its sensuous superposition of independent rhythmic and melodic layers, or the explosive, virtuosic Toccata (without a Fugue), a condensed, one-movement violin concerto from 1933, or the Two Little Serious Pieces for wind (1940) which are anything but conventionally serious, could only have been written by Revueltas.

Establishing the boundaries of that creative identity was the Santa Barbara festival's aim. The programmes were sometimes too long (prefacing the screening of Redes with the US premiere of Villa-Lobos's interminably rambling Tenth Symphony was a mistake) and the performances weren't always perfect: this is music that requires rhythmic tautness of a very special order, and the kind of technical expertise that makes the hardest passages seem effortless. Yet they demonstrated inescapably that this is important, devastatingly endearing music. There's no doubt that alongside the Argentinian Astor Piazzolla, and (on a good day) the Brazilian Villa-Lobos, Revueltas is the most considerable figure that Latin American music has yet produced.
