fields.headline: Cellulite for sore eyes
fields.standfirst: They're naked, middle-aged and proud of it.  Chris Arnot meets the women behind Outrageous Agers
fields.trailText: They're naked, middle-aged and proud of it. Chris Arnot meets the women behind Outrageous Agers
fields.body:
Within minutes of meeting Rosy Martin, I'm sitting in her flat in an old council block in Islington watching a video of her dancing stark naked. Friend and fellow artist Kay Goodridge is there with her, starkers too.

They disrobe during a lengthy striptease set against the pure white background of Goodridge's Cambridge studio, the two serenading themselves with the music of old Greek Street strip joints. Off come the sensible, lace-up shoes, followed by the long, black coats. Tops and trousers hit the floor some time before black bras and panties, the intervening period taken up by the unveiling of arms and legs encased in yards of white Tubigrip elasticated support bandage.

These are women who want us to know they're feeling their age. (Goodridge is 46, Martin 53.) "Sometimes I have the energy I had when I was 30, but I can't rely on my body any more," Martin says. "When I sprained my ankle, my Mum sent me some Tubigrip and I began to think of it as the new Lycra. It ends up looking like the underwear Victorian men used to look at in medical catalogues..."

Martin and Goodridge are confronting the issue of the ageing female body head on, challenging assumptions with wit and a defiant, if rather desperate, air of celebration. Soon the video will be playing on a continuous loop in the Lighthouse Gallery in Wolverhampton, where the duo's exhibition Outrageous Agers opens tomorrow.

There are photographs as well. A large bottom stretches tight leopardskin to comic-postcard parody. A big bare thigh, pitted with cellulite, protrudes from a short skirt below a bare, bulging midriff. The unsightly lumps are juxtaposed with lovely feminine shoulders and hints of cleavage.

"All my work's pitched between glamour and ugliness, desire and discontent," explains Martin. "We're bred to be never quite content because of the way the image of femininity is constructed by those who want to sell us products. We can't spend our lives in denial of who we are. So we're subverting the cliche of 'mutton dressed as lamb', and saying, 'So what? Enjoy it'. There's permission-giving here as well as mockery."

The two artists felt as though they needed permission to go into Top Shop in Oxford Street. "It's almost as though there's a sign over the door saying 'No woman over 30 need enter'," says Martin, for whom the shop was a regular haunt as a student in the 60s.

When she went with Kay, Martin says they attracted "very funny looks from assistants young enough to be our daughters. One told us off for taking photographs. She said it was against company policy. So I switched off the flash and shot in a tiny space with the help of a little spotlight above the mirror. I had to open the aperture as far as it would go, which emphasised how squeezed we felt in these totally unsuitable clothes. There was a sense of how we squeeze ourselves into an identity."

The Top Shop assistants will probably never know they were visited by two serious artists. Martin has had exhibitions in New York, Chicago, Winnipeg, Nantes and Dublin as well as in various London galleries. She met Goodridge at a conference, they got on well and found they had a mutual interest in using photography as a form of therapy.

Whether other middle-aged women will find their exhibition therapeutic remains to be seen. Initially, they may have difficulty identifying the close-ups of naked body parts - sagging buttocks, wrinkled navels winking from fleshy stomachs, "love handles" like ripples of Mr Whippy ice cream. "These are the bits you're distressed about as a female, but we wanted to aestheticise them, isolate them from the body, and make them ironically beautiful in their own right," says Martin.

There's also a sequence of black-and-white pictures of the artists' naked bodies, on to which are projected starkly depressing quotes about ageing females from such luminaries as Sigmund Freud and David Reuben, author of Everything You Wanted to Know About Sex But Were Afraid to Ask.

"Most of us project ageing on to somebody else," Martin says. "But, eventually, you have to face up to the fact that you're the one in the seat of these negative perceptions. The 60s generation has always found a way of defining the world through itself. First youth culture, then feminism, then the concerns of middle age and now the issues of an ageing population - ourselves."

She asks: "How do we cope with being the people we fought against?"

If this exhibition's anything to go by, the answer would seem to be by growing old disgracefully.

fields.headline: Let HB be
fields.standfirst: Rents charged by local councils or housing associations may vary from borough to borough in the same city, and the costs are still rising
fields.trailText: Rents charged by local councils or housing associations may vary from borough to borough in the same city, and the costs are still rising
fields.body:
Radical reform of how low income families get help with their rents - long threatened, much promised - has been put on the back burner. There is a green paper out shortly on public housing, in which a quarter of all households live: it will not, after all, get to grips with housing benefit (HB).

This government wanted to reform (ie cut) HB because it accounts for 12% of social security spending. More important, it stands in the way of the work incentives which Chancellor Gordon Brown has been keen to promote - "work pays". Reforming HB was a Tory ambition too - but they failed to deliver, shaving away at the edges and creating more hardship.

One problem is that rents charged by councils and non-profit housing associations bear little relation to the desirability or value of the property. Adjoining London boroughs may have a £15 difference in weekly rents for council dwellings. In Southampton for example a three-bed council house is typically £24 cheaper than a similar property let by a housing association. Yet the occupants might well pay the same amount because of the way HB works. The government wants greater differences between rents of smaller and larger dwellings, so that a single elderly person (say) has an incentive to move to a smaller house or flat releasing the property for a family.

The treasury's starting point was to relate rents to price on the open market. But doing this produces enormous rent increases in places such as Kensington and big cuts in many northern cities. The result would be turmoil. Existing tenants would want to move but new tenants could not afford to move in.

Other permutations have been tested, all of them modifying the market rent but seeking to make changes less drastic. Yet even modest movement creates difficulty. It is the rents charged by housing associations that are most likely to have to change; but they are meant to be independent. Tenants might well resist rent increases prescribed from above; equally, associations might well want compensation if rents are cut. Cutting their rental income could affect associations' financial viability.

Since they have borrowed from banks and building societies City loans might be at risk. Perversely, in the north, where rents would be most likely to fall, landlords' income has already been affected by a fall off in demand for housing.

For the still sizeable group of tenants who have jobs and pay their own rents, the issue of how much rents rise is crucial. The last thing that councils want is to drive out the minority of working tenants who will be tempted to buy their own homes if their rents rise. They are calling for rent levels in each area to relate, in part, to incomes in the same locality, as well as reflecting market values. This would reduce the rent rises that might otherwise result, especially in southern England.

If reform does eventually go ahead, there would have to be a compromise of some sort. Perhaps rents might reflect the location and size of a dwelling. Both market values and local incomes would be taken into account in rent-setting. But rent restructuring would have to take place over five or 10 years to make changes more palatable.

Changing rents only makes sense if they affect tenants' choices. But except for those in work who earn too much to receive benefit (or refuse to claim it), tenants now see no effect from changes in their rent if their benefit goes up or down by the same amount. Many may not even know what their rent is, because their HB goes straight to their landlord.

A recent report by Professor Peter Kemp of Glasgow University for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation sets out some of the options if tenants are going to be put more in touch with what their housing costs. He commends "shopping incentives", to encourage tenants to choose more carefully both landlord and accommodation. In practice, though, it is mainly private sector tenants who can exercise choice. Council dwellings are allocated rather than chosen. Kemp therefore suggests that shopping incentives be created first for the private sector and introduced later for council tenants, as rent reform takes effect.

Under the Kemp proposals, housing benefit would be split into two components, a flat-rate housing allowance incorporated into income support; the remainder would stay as housing benefit. For private tenants, the top-up received through the benefit scheme would be based on a local "benchmark" or average rent, not the money actually paid. HB recipients would then have a clear incentive to find accommodation at or below the benchmark rent.

For councils and housing associations, Kemp does not suggest going so far, but argues that tenants should at least be responsible for paying the part of the rent that is covered by the flat rate allowance included in their income support. Kemp would also like to end direct payment of benefits to councils. He wants all tenants to be responsible for paying their rent, even if (as now) most are fully recompensed through the benefit scheme.

The signs are that the government is interested in reforms like these but has been put off by the cost of giving everyone a flat-rate allowance (which would logically extend to low-income home-owners too). There is a political dimension, too, since some tenants will lose out - by how much depends on the precise way in which the changes are introduced, and whether existing tenants are protected until they change tenancy. But this is a social and financial problem deferred rather than solved.

webTitle: Disgruntled NatWest shareholders try to avoid split

fields.headline: Disgruntled NatWest shareholders try to avoid split
fields.trailText: A secret pact is being explored by NatWest's big shareholders to ensure that a split vote does not allow the bank to escape its Scottish predators.
fields.body:
A secret pact is being explored by NatWest's big shareholders to ensure that a split vote does not allow the bank to escape its Scottish predators.

The informal soundings are expected to take place amid concerns that investors might be divided in their support for the competing £23bn bids by Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland, or independence for NatWest, which would prevent either of the Scottish bidders reaching the 50% takeover hurdle.

The anxiety has failed to diminish since the two Scottish bidders revealed their final bids - a complex mix of cash and shares - for NatWest, neither of which was the "knock out" blow which the City had hoped for.

"Institutions are notoriously bad at having conversations with each other (but) we'll put feelers out to find out which way people are leaning," one major NatWest shareholder said.

The shareholder said he had not decided which bidder was better. "But what do we do? NatWest has been such an embarassment for so long (it's hard) to allow it to continue."

While difficult to instigate, the private conversations, appear to be an alternative route to pressurising Sir David Rowland, chairman and chief executive of NatWest, to recommend to his board to agree to a takeover.

Few shareholders are prepared to reveal their decisions until they have seen the final presentations from the top executives of all three banks. While a few have indicated that they do not want NatWest to survive - notably Standard Life and Jupiter - no British institution has publicly backed either Scottish bank. Others have said they have not yet ruled out backing the newly installed NatWest management team.

Shareholders have until Valentine's Day to decide, while analysts are starting to make their recommendations, with WestLB yesterday said to have joined Commerzbank and Teather and Greenwood in backing NatWest.

NatWest's shares ended 24p lower at £11.34 - below the value of both bids - while BoS slipped another 13p to 585p while Royal gained 8p to 979p.

webTitle: Broker valued for secrecy and top tips

fields.headline: Broker valued for secrecy and top tips
fields.trailText: Anthony Laiker, who purchased Piers Morgan's shares on his behalf, is not your average clean-cut stockbroker, plying a dull but profitable business within the City's confines.
fields.body:
Anthony Laiker, who purchased Piers Morgan's shares on his behalf, is not your average clean-cut stockbroker, plying a dull but profitable business within the City's confines.

Ten years ago, when he was 29, Mr Laiker opened the door to his home in Loughton, Essex. Two men were standing there, one armed with a shotgun. The stockbroker slammed the door shut, but the blast caught the side of his face. He almost died.

No one was ever prosecuted for the attack. Mr Laiker himself blamed a row over building work, but he prefers not to discuss the incident. His colleagues, then at stockbrokers Kitcat & Aitken and subsequently at a string of fringe City firms, have always assumed that there might be more to the story.

Over the years Mr Laiker has built a reputation for secrecy and for his ability to lay his hands on top quality information - "tips" and whispers on likely corporate action that made his speculating clients good money in a perfectly legal manner.

He is known to have extensive contacts among north London's Jewish community and has established relations with a string of prominent businessmen.

Mr Laiker has also become known as one of the few City players with extensive contacts among the "Monaco Mob" - a group of ex-stockbrokers who now live in the principality but continue to trade on the London stock market.

Yet despite his contacts, Mr Laiker has spent his career outside the blue-blooded City establishment, working for a string of second-division broking firms, two of which closed down partly because of debts run up by his clients.

Mr Laiker was not returning calls yesterday.

fields.headline: Smudging the contour
fields.standfirst:
Britten Sinfonia/ Nicholas Daniel
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Britten Sinfonia/ Nicholas Daniel
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.body:
The title of John Woolrich's A Litany for oboe and strings disguises its dramatic gestures and melodic fragments. Nicholas Daniel, who performed the solo role as well as directing the Britten Sinfonia, emphasised the music's ritualistic circling. Daniel was both impassioned cantor, leading his congregation of strings in song, and plaintive declaimer.

As Woolrich describes it, A Litany is a "creative transcription" of his 1998 Oboe Quintet, also composed for Daniel's effusive talents. The metaphor of rewriting runs through A Litany, which continually reveals and recomposes the same ideas in different contexts. An emphatic string swoop morphs into a dusky rustle, while a sinewy melodic line distorts into an abrasive, grating tug across the strings. This orchestral richness is an obvious bonus over the possibilities of a quintet line-up. But Daniel's emotive performance could not mask a fragmented, bitty structure, enhanced by the instrumental extremes employed by Woolrich.

There was fragmentation of a different kind in Strauss's Metamorphosen. This elegy for the destruction of German culture at the end of the second world war is focused around a block of thematic rubble from Beethoven's Eroica Symphony. The Britten Sinfonia and Daniel, this time as conductor, launched enthusiastically into Strauss's searing polyphony, but the effect was breathless rather than transcendent.

Metamorphosen may well strike the death-knell for German romanticism, but in Britain, musical conservatism took longer to expire. Finzi's Dies Natalis, his miniature cantata for tenor and strings, uses its own romantic immediacy for precisely the opposite purpose to Strauss. Dies Natalis sets Thomas Traherne texts in a pastoral celebration of the Christ-child's thoughts on entering the world. Ian Bostridge's reputation rides high in this repertoire, for which his air of composed vulnerability seems perfectly matched.

In this account, however, the marriage between Bostridge and Finzi was made rather in an idealised heaven than harsh reality. Bostridge overlaid Finzi's poised meditations with quasi-operatic rhetoric and affectation. This turned the dance of the third movement, The Rapture, into a joyously vivid outpouring, but unsettled the radiance of the other vocal movements. Daniel's ebullient direction helped dramatise the work, but it also smudged the delicate contours of Bostridge's dynamic range.

webTitle: How can I keep my customers happy when I'm getting no support?

fields.headline: How can I keep my customers happy when I'm getting no support?
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I work for a firm dealing with imported biomedical equipments in India. I am the only person to provide sales and service support to the hospitals we supply.

My head office is in Delhi. My problem is that I do not received any support from my head office and am therefore not able to provide good sales and service to the customer, although I am held responsible for this. I am a service engineer for the eastern part of India, but I am also responsible for the sales side of things, which I don't really enjoy or feel capable of doing properly. My customers seem happy with my work, however. Please advise me what to do.

The solution

The nub of your concern - lack of support from your managers - shows that many work problems are common the world over. You are trying to provide the best service possible to your customers, but without the appropriate back-up, your aims are thwarted, leaving you feeling stressed and frustrated.

The best way to solve this problem, whether in the UK or India, is to take a cool, rational approach, along the following lines:

The first thing to do is collect evidence. Rather than just vaguely complaining to your manager about not being given enough support, be as specific as possible. Keep notes of situations over a period of a week or a month, when you feel that the service you are offering suffers because of back-up problems. State the outcomes (eg customer is dissatisfied) and what support you need.

Then arrange a meeting with your manager. Present a report, outlining the problems you are experiencing (using the evidence you have collected) and suggesting what is needed to improve operations. Make it clear that, whilst the situation is leaving you feeling unhappy, the bottom line is that customer service is being adversely affected. Don't threaten to walk out, lose your temper or get angry. Just state the facts calmly, while not being afraid to show how concerned and unhappy you are.

A manager would be foolish (and yes, some are) to ignore a well-thought-out, rational argument for improving operations, so here's hoping the above strategy works for you.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

webTitle: One-track Wales: Prism seeks to integrate transport systems

fields.headline: One-track Wales: Prism seeks to integrate transport systems
fields.trailText: An integrated travel system covering the whole of Wales would cut journey times, boost the number of services and produce up to 500 new jobs, a train operating company predicted yesterday, writes Geoffery Gibbs.
fields.body:
An integrated travel system covering the whole of Wales would cut journey times, boost the number of services and produce up to 500 new jobs, a train operating company predicted yesterday, writes Geoffery Gibbs.

Prism Rail, which already operates two franchises in Wales - including the Heart of Wales - is proposing that a single Wales-based company should have overall responsibility for train services throughout the country when franchises come up for renewal.

The ambitious proposals, which have been submitted to the shadow strategic rail authority for consideration, would not include long-distance inter-city services operated by First Great Western or Virgin's cross-country service into Wales.

Unveiling its plans in Cardiff yesterday the company said its blueprint for the development of public transport over the next 20 years envisaged an unprecedented degree of integration of rail with other forms of transport.

It called for a new network of express coach links to close gaps in the network created by the Beeching cuts of an earlier era.

The company, which is believed to face competition from two other bidders for an all-Wales franchise, says its plans would result in a 50% increase in train miles in Wales.

webTitle: Exchange members in line for £1m each

fields.headline: Exchange members in line for £1m each
fields.trailText: The 298 members of the London stock exchange will vote in March on a demutualisation which could unlock windfalls of at least £1m each.
fields.body:
The 298 members of the London stock exchange will vote in March on a demutualisation which could unlock windfalls of at least £1m each.

Senior directors, including chief executive Gavin Casey, also stand to gain from the plan, which is designed to give the 200-year-old institution more commercial freedom. They will be awarded share options for the first time.

While the exchange does not intend to list its shares on its own market, they will be tradable through broking firm Cazenove.

Firms will be limited to owning up to 4.9% of the exchange, which Mr Casey said yesterday might eventually merge with other bourses.

The prospectus, published yesterday, did not put a value on the exchange but sources suggested it was worth at least £300m, which would be shared among the 298 members who own the company. Many of them are expected to reinvest in the shares.

Among firms which are likely to be biggest beneficiaries of the demutualisation are Old Mutual of South Africa, which owns six seats after recent acquisitions, including Gerrard last week, while ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, has three seats.

The change to the ownership of the exchange, which last under went a radical revamp in the 1986 "big bang", comes at a time of intense competition for traditional share-trading operations from the internet and other electronic start-ups.

The London exchange is also trying to forge an alliance with bourses across Europe, the next meeting for which will be held today.

The prospectus shows that the share trading centre moved into profit three years ago and made £17.5m last year.

webTitle: Regulators expected to block BP Amoco bid

fields.headline: Regulators expected to block BP Amoco bid
fields.trailText: American regulators were reported to be ready to block BP Amoco's proposed $35bn (£22bn) takeover of Atlantic Richfield (Arco) as they met in Washington yesterday.
fields.body:
American regulators were reported to be ready to block BP Amoco's proposed $35bn (£22bn) takeover of Atlantic Richfield (Arco) as they met in Washington yesterday.

If the vote by the federal trade commission goes against BP Amoco the resulting court battle is expected to set a new legal framework for the oil industry.

FTC staff have recommended that the commission blocks the deal on the grounds that it would give BP Amoco too much power over oil production in Alaska and over petrol prices on the US west coast.

Their report comes amid wide-scale consolidation in the industry and increasing political fears over rising global oil prices.

Last year, the FTC approved the merger of two American oil companies, Exxon and Mobil. It also approved BP's own acquisition of Amoco but is understood to have become increasingly concerned about the concentration of power within the industry.

John Browne, BP Amoco's chief executive, flew to the US last week in a last-ditch attempt to get the Arco bid approved. But there are understood to be key differences of opinion over whether the deal should go ahead.

The oil group offered to make several concessions by divesting itself of oilfields in the contentious areas.

In earlier negotiations with Alaskan officials, the company had agreed to sell up to $4bn of assets in order to weaken its hold on the region.

However, cost savings were the main rationale for the deal. At the time the takeover was announced, BP Amoco said it expected cost savings of about $1bn in 2001 as a result of buying Arco.

It is unlikely to want to give up a significant part of those savings and feels that it can argue that its acquisition of the Alaskan sites could actually lower prices.

The FTC meeting to decide on the issue started at 1.30pm in Washington yesterday, when it is likely to seek a court injunction to block the deal, set to be completed on Monday. The legal battle is expected to result in a landmark ruling.

fields.body:
A clutch of Europe's leading telecoms and technology companies yesterday outlined how they plan to enable mobile phone users to access the internet through their handsets.

UK information technology company CMG saw more than £1bn added to its market value after Vodafone announced it had chosen to install CMG's internet enabling software in its mobile phones.

Shares in CMG, a FTSE 100 constituent, jumped 20% or 818p to a record high of £48.45 on the news that its wireless application protocol (WAP) brokerage system is to be adopted by the world's largest mobile phone company, with 31m subscribers across 24 countries.

Alan Harper, managing director of Vodafone UK, said the technology would give its mobile phone users easy access to services and information available on the internet while they are on the move. He said Vodafone would be able to offer groups of users personalised services even if their phone was not WAP-enabled. However, the exact terms of the deal and likely revenues to result from it have not been disclosed.

Marc Geal, information technology analyst at Schroders, said: "It opens a lot of doors at a very big player. If Vodafone wins Mannesmann it will be an even more significant deal, particularly if Vodafone does look to standardise its telecom solutions."

The news also excited Logica and Sema, two IT companies who have exposure to the rapidly evolving telecoms market. Logica shares jumped 16% or 267p to £19.18, while Sema climbed 36p to £11.46, even though, as Vodafone's existing supplier of short messaging services, it might have hoped to win the WAP contract.

At the GSM world congress 2000 trade show in Cannes mobile phone manufacturer Siemens announced that all its new phones would have direct access to WAP content from internet portal Yahoo.

The two parties are working on technology that will connect users to localised content.

Virgin Mobile said at the same exhibition that it will introduce a "SIM card based" web-browser that allows mobile phone users access to any WAP web sites regardless of the type of phone they use. The technology, to be introduced in the spring, will be developed by Gemplus, a founder of the SIMalliance which is developing a smartcard based web-browser.

fields.headline: Mannesmann pressed for friendly merger
fields.trailText: Talks between Vodafone and Mannesmann's advisers about a friendly merger intensified yesterday as a surge in both group's shares sent the value of the British group's hostile bid to £107.5bn.
fields.body:
Talks between Vodafone and Mannesmann's advisers about a friendly merger intensified yesterday as a surge in both group's shares sent the value of the British group's hostile bid to £107.5bn.

Mannesmann's supervisory board meets for an extraordinary session in Düsseldorf today amid febrile speculation that leading members are pressing the main board, led by Klaus Esser, to reach an agreement with Vodafone before its offer closes at 2300 GMT on Monday.

DaimlerChrysler chairman Jürgen Schrempp, Henning Schulte-Noelle, Allianz chief executive and Klaus Zwickel, head of the powerful IG Metall union, are said to be the main proponents of a friendly deal.

Mannesmann sought to put a damper on such expectations, insisting that the supervisory board meeting was purely informative, but it emerged that channels of communication between the two group's sets of advisers had opened wide.

It is believed that Mr Esser and Chris Gent, Vodafone chief executive, met in Düsseldorf this week. The Mannesmann chief has scaled down his demands for his company's share of the enlarged group from 58.5% to 52% in recent days.

Mr Gent, who has dismissed such demands as over the top, has offered 48.9% if the Mannesmann board recommends the bid, which is rapidly approaching the upper limit of 350 euros (£210) per share that Mr Esser has put on his company's value.

Markets in London and Frankfurt bet heavily on a Vodafone victory, with more than half a billion shares in the British group changing hands yesterday and the stock rising 26.5p or 7.5% to close at a record 386.5p.

In concert Mannesmann shares surged 28.70 euros or 9.7% to 325 euros, with the discount between this and Vodafone's offer down to 4.5%. Vodafone's "see-thru" offer is now worth 340 euros or £107.45bn.

The only fly in the ointment came in the form of a European Commission statement that it would study carefully Vodafone's plans to divest Mannesmann's mobile phones operation Orange to secure approval for its bid.

Vodafone doubts whether it faces a full-scale investigation and has laid complex plans for Orange if this happens. Brussels said the group had to say how it would divest itself of Orange in the event of a successful merger with its German prey.

fields.headline: Fairport Convention
fields.standfirst:
Roses Theatre, Tewkesbury
****
fields.trailText:
Fairport Convention
Roses Theatre, Tewkesbury
****
fields.body:
Fairport Convention epitomise the 60s phenomenon of British folk-rock, but they have gone through many changes since then. They last played live as a four-piece acoustic outfit; this tour, which coincides with their first studio album for some years, The Wood and the Wire, sees them transformed into a five-man electric band that puts the emphasis on rock rather than folk. Their excellent performance was both shaped by the band's history and surprisingly fresh.

Founder-member Simon Nicol's guitar work was impressive. Violinist Ric Sanders gave his Celtic reel, country and bluegrass a touch of scorching atonality. His slick fiddle duets with Chris Leslie were a joy. Leslie, Fairport's latest recruit, wrote much of the new album; despite their unfamiliarity, these compositions were as well received as old favourites such as Crazy Man Michael, Bowman's Retreat and Hiring Fair.

Nicol and Leslie sang with brio; joined by bassist Dave Pegg, their harmonies in Wandering Man were haunting. The lyrical numbers - Close to You, Heart of the Song - counterpointed the harder edge of pounding numbers like Rocky Road and Still a Mystery. Driven by Gerry Conway's solid percussion and Pegg's subtle basslines, these were satisfyingly gutsy.

Best of all were the slamming version of Matty Groves, snarlingly sung by Nicol, and the encore, Meet on the Ledge - the nearest thing there is to a Fairport greatest hit.

Fairport Convention play Buxton Opera House (01298 72190) tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Firestorm of sound
fields.standfirst:
Mark Latimer
St John's, Smith Square, London
****
fields.trailText:
Mark Latimer
St John's, Smith Square, London
****
fields.body:
It was a mild disappointment to find that the name of Alkan really does turn up in the tributaries of 19th-century musicology. The little-known French pianist/composer's circumstances seem to echo those of his young piano-virtuoso champion Mark Latimer in uncanny ways, for a start. There have even been suspicions that Latimer might have invented the mysterious Alkan and his hour-long unaccompanied piano concerto.

Yet Alkan is in the reference books, an assumed name for one Charles-Henri-Valentin Morhange - a French keyboard genius to challenge Liszt and Brahms, whose friends included Chopin and Victor Hugo, yet whose insularity kept him off the Paris recital circuit, locked inside the world of his own obsessively complex compositions.

Latimer delivered Alkan's Concerto for Solo Piano as the first half of his St John's show (Exhibitionist at the Pictures), and a somewhat unexpectedly straightforward jazz trio set as the second. The Alkan concerto is in three breathtaking movements, the first alone running to 1,400 bars (more than Beethoven's entire Hammerklavier Sonata, as Latimer points out). The piano almost sounded like a small orchestra in Latimer's hands, and an orchestra calling on a medley of musical references from the baroque to the modern era Alkan never encountered at that. An opening of jackhammer chords is only fitfully alleviated as a gentler lyrical line develops into a firestorm of sound. A hyperbolic reiteration of thunderous climaxes and brief retreats characterises the entire work, which also suggests everything from battlefields to pealing churchbells, to fairground roundabouts and speeding trains. Its fury and impatience with conventional narrative development makes the concerto's obscurity unsurprising. But Latimer's single-minded inspiration about it may change all that.

When the dust had settled after the interval, Latimer's classy jazz trio (Mario Castronari on bass, Harold Fisher on drums) first explored standard songs with a diffident, understated elegance that initially made it hard to believe that the same player was at the keyboard. Monk's Round Midnight and an uptempo bop original were followed by Latimer's Exhibitionist at the Pictures suite, a pleasant blend of soft funky grooves, Latin rhythms, urbane walking-blues and fast postbop, with some very inventive improvisation from Castronari. But the free-jazz finale, a piano/ bass duet developing into flying, Cecil Taylor-like percussive chords, both made the connection with the Alkan concerto and seemed closer to Latimer's idiosyncratic soul.

fields.headline: Mirror editor faces share inquiries
fields.standfirst:
Related stories:
Column that turns City into showbiz
Broker valued for secrecy and top tips
fields.trailText: Piers Morgan, the editor of the Mirror, was last night under investigation by the Press Complaints Commission and the department of trade and industry after it emerged that he bought around £20,000 worth of shares in a technology company the day before his newspaper ran a story which doubled the company's share price.
fields.body:
Piers Morgan, the editor of the Mirror, was last night under investigation by the Press Complaints Commission and the department of trade and industry after it emerged that he bought around £20,000 worth of shares in a technology company the day before his newspaper ran a story which doubled the company's share price.

The PCC inquiry, expected to last about a month, will have to establish whether Mr Morgan had advance knowledge of the story. The PCC code of practice states that even where the law does not prohibit it, journalists must not use for their own profit financial information they receive in advance of its general publication. In the wake of the inquiry, the Mirror is expected to introduce its own guidelines in this area for staff.

Mr Morgan, who yesterday maintained that he did not act improperly, has been the subject of a full stock exchange investigation into his purchase of shares in Viglen Technology, Sir Alan Sugar's computer hardware firm.

The DTI will decide on the merits of a criminal prosecution after carrying out its own investigation.

Shares in Viglen doubled from 188p to 355p on January 18, the day after the Mirror's exclusive story that the company was launching a separate internet division.

Mr Morgan maintained that he was unaware of the story, written by the paper's financial team Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, known as the City Slickers, until after he had bought the shares. Their colourful city coverage has gained a loyal following for its celebrity-driven and gossipy share tips.

Mr Morgan said: "I have never bought and would never buy any shares knowing what the City Slickers' tip was going to be the next day."

The City Slickers, who regularly feature Tottenham boss and Amstrad founder Sugar, claim their top 10 share tips for 1999 enjoyed gains of 159%.

According to Mr Morgan, he decided to buy the shares as a long-term investment after consultation with his uncle and dealer following a number of stories tipping the company, including three by the City Slickers this year.

"I don't think there's any breach of any code of conduct," he said. "I'm always scrupulous. It's just not worth it for a couple of thousand pounds."

webTitle: British car prices start to tumble

fields.headline: British car prices start to tumble
fields.trailText: Car prices dropped last month as the motor industry was claiming that the government's "rip off Britain" campaign had unfairly targeted the industry.
fields.body:
Car prices dropped last month as the motor industry was claiming that the government's "rip off Britain" campaign had unfairly targeted the industry.

The Alliance & Leicester's monthly car price index showed an average 2.4% drop in the price of a new car for December 1999 against a year previously.

The bank said the December figure showed the largest monthly fall last year.

Earlier this week the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said its members - which include Ford and Vauxhall - would not cut prices despite a fall in the number of new cars bought.

It is understood to be waiting for the delayed report into pricing practices to be published by the competition commission before sanctioning cuts. But Audi, Daewoo and Mitsubishi have all announced price cuts, while other car makers have dropped prices on selected models.

Sellers of city cars such as the Ford Ka or Volkswagen Lupo, cut prices most dramatically, by an average of 10.9%. Used cars, more than three years old, fell by 12.8%.

webTitle: Barclays is given a NatWest nudge

fields.headline: Barclays is given a NatWest nudge
fields.trailText: Pressure is mounting for the new Barclays chief executive to stun the City with a revamped strategy when the bank reports its profits in a fortnight
fields.body:
The wall of silence which Barclays has maintained since the arrival of new chief executive Matthew Barrett is causing some frustration.

Pressure is mounting for Mr Barrett to stun the City with a revamped strategy when the bank reports its profits in a fortnight.

He has the dubious honour of meeting the City for the first time on the day after the four-month NatWest saga will be concluded, and analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson suggest that debacle might contain some lessons.

"He could do worse than study the NatWest day 39 defence document and borrow liberally," the research from DKB says.

While DKB's corporate finance arm is one of the main advisers to NatWest, the analysts are on the other side of the so-called "Chinese wall" cited by analysts for their independence stance. The note points out that they are not predicting the outcome of the NatWest battle.

They see the problems Barclays faces as similar to those hurting NatWest: cost reduction, business focus, revenue enhancement and capital restructuring.

For Mr Barrett, this means taking a "dispassionate look" at the business inside Barclays Capital, the rump of the investment bank left after the sale of BZW.

The analysts wonder whether Mr Barrett should also "search for a better owner" of Barclays Global Investors, the vast "index tracking" fund management business it bought in 1996.

They also suggest Barclays sell its non-European retail operations, primarily in Africa, while the few operations in Europe could be retained to offer overlap should Barclays decide to merge with a European bank in the future.

Cutting costs, one of the big NatWest bugbears, is also important and the DKB analysts suggest Barclays will announce further "cost reduction measures" in coming months, in addition to the 6,000 job cuts on the cards.

It is all slightly tongue in cheek, and the analysts maintain their "buy" recommendation on Barclays on the basis of of good operating profits growth against its low relative valuation on the stock market.

fields.headline: Subscriber sues AOL for $8bn
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, is facing a lawsuit from disgruntled customers which could lead to an $8bn (£5bn) payout.
fields.body:
America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, is facing a lawsuit from disgruntled customers which could lead to an $8bn (£5bn) payout.

Kenneth Yates, one of AOL's 21m subscribers, lodged the class action suit along with another customer after installing the latest version of the group's software, version 5.0.

Mr Yates, a lawyer specialising in internet law, found he was no longer able to access another internet account because version 5.0 changed his computer settings. "AOL is making people use the net the way they want it to be used," he told the Washington Post. "The internet is supposed to be like free speech, with open access."

The lawsuit accuses AOL of deceptive trade practice and of violating consumer protection and computer-tampering laws. The plaintiffs are seeking damages of up to $1,000 for each of the 8m people who installed the new version, largely delivered through a blanket mailing of free CDs by AOL.

The internet service provider is expected to rest part of its case on the fact that changing a customer's default settings is common practice in the software industry. It is also likely to argue that customers are asked while installing the software whether they want 5.0 as a default setting.

Internet lawyers suggested that rival companies might be able to claim damages also if Mr Yates's case succeeds. Customers often phone rival operators seeking a fix to the AOL problem.

As well as Mr Yates, the lawsuit involves Gathings, Kennedy and Associates, a firm which specialises in class action lawsuits.

"The complaint that has been filed has no basis in fact or law," a spokesman for AOL said.

 America Online said yesterday its core AOL service has more than 21m subscribers, compared with 5m four years ago. More than 3m of them live outside the US.

America Online also operates CompuServe, which has another 2m members.

The company said more members joined AOL on Christmas Day 1999 than on any other day in its history, as consumers went online from new personal computers.

Its subscribers spent an average of 63 minutes a day online in the past month. More than 1.6m people now use the service during peak periods, compared with 1m a year ago.

Members send about 110m emails daily, compared with 50m a year ago.

fields.headline: BT profits fall shocks City
fields.standfirst: Share price drops as declining fixed-line revenue means 3,000 managers will go
fields.trailText: British Telecom stunned the markets and its own staff yesterday when it announced a drop in profits and sweeping job cuts.
fields.body:
British Telecom stunned the markets and its own staff yesterday when it announced a drop in profits and sweeping job cuts.

The market reacted adversely to the news by marking the group's shares down by more than 17%, reducing its stock market value by £13bn to £63.5bn.

The company said it plans to shed 3,000 middle managers over the next nine months in an attempt to reduce the costs of its traditional UK phone business. The decision to axe one in 10 of its management jobs followed a 6% slump in third-quarter profits.

fields.headline: Checkov smoulders
fields.standfirst:
The Seagull
The Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon
***
fields.trailText:
The Seagull
The Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon

***
fields.body:
In 1896 Chekhov's play had a disastrous first night in St Petersburg. In Stratford-upon-Avon it nearly had an incendiary one. In the first act the curtains of Konstantin's mock-theatre brushed against candle-flame and caught fire. Prompt action by the production manager, Jasper Gilbert, who leapt up on stage and put out the fire prevented the flames spreading and may well have helped save this beautiful wooden theatre. After 10 minutes or so, the play resumed but it was an unnerving experience for actors and audience alike.

But how did you enjoy the play, Mrs Lincoln? In the circumstances, it is difficult to say but I feel Adrian Noble's production is a mixed affair. It is full of acute detail, heightens the play's Hamletesque references and has a very Russian sense of atmosphere. Gulls cry, the wind sighs in the trees, waves lap against the lake shore. There is also a heartstopping moment when the characters sit and listen to the sound of distant music and laughter. It not only evokes past happiness but achingly counterpoints the lovelorn sadness that taints Chekhov's people.

If there is a reservation in my voice, it has to do with the need for the RSC to revive The Seagull so soon after Terry Hands's superlative production in The Swan. Without wishing to be ageist, Noble's cast is also, in several crucial cases, much older than Chekhov states -something that may not matter in Shakespeare but that is important in realistic drama. The novelist, Trigorin, is meant to be under 40. Nigel Terry, however, presents us with a grizzled figure who makes up for in energy what he lacks in youth. Dorn, the debonair doctor, is only 55. As played by Richard Johnson he becomes an older figure full of grave melancholy.

In the case of Penelope Wilton's superb Arkadina, however, age is simply irrelevant. Wilton presents us with an instantly recognisable figure - the dedicated, self-centred actress determined to keep professional or sexual rivals at bay. When she hisses at her son that his symbolist play is "decadent" it is because she senses a threat to her own conventional style of theatre. And when she tells Nina "I'm sure you must have talent" it is with the casual disdain of someone who spies a potential erotic challenge.

Wilton does not judge Arkadina. She shows how talent is always accompanied by insecurity. Justine Waddell's Nina also presents a genuine threat. She has beauty, spirit and the single-minded intensity of the genuinely ambitious. She also makes sense of that treacherous last act where Nina returns emotionally devastated but determined to endure. There is much in Noble's production, as well as Peter Gill's new version, to admire. But it needs time to mature before it sets out on a UK tour - and fireproof curtains.

Until February 24. Box office: 01789 403403. This appeared in some editions yesterday.
